I'm writing this after playing for the first time and only 2 hours in-game under my belt. 

This game is flippin' GREAT. It has a very rough-n-tumble charm with fun graphics, fully voiced characters who love to shout, and some pretty cool music. I did the tutorial and then played 2 missions with a complete stranger and it was just awesome fun.

update : they added in-game ads and also use the steam updates channel to spam ads in it

the tutorial map shows basically everything this game has to offer : not much

i would also warn about the game being oddly optimized. in the beginning it made my graphic card roar way too much and i had to disable the shadows, and lower other settings (but the fps were pretty fine). also, it started dropping steam cards only a few minutes after launch, which as far as i know disables refunds

from the store page and the reviews, i would have expected much more open and varied areas and a much more dynamic gameplay, but it's always the same boring pattern of dark caves that are very frustrating to navigate with a map that does not help much in which we perform the same boring tasks, even with the class with the best mobility (scout)

the game revolves around getting into a map, completing a mission of a specific type among several (like gathering resources, hunting, building a pipe system) and then backtracking to leave. completing a mission can take dozens of minutes, so it might not be ideal for people with not a lot of free time, especially in multiplayer as one griefer would be enough to waste a play session.

overall it's not fun, it's bland and shallow  and it's more like a job

gathering is unfullfilling, and frustrating at times, with the resources required by the tasks too difficult to find (usually they don't exist in enough amount, only what is required by the task) and too difficult and time-consumming to mine, sometimes requiring dozens of minutes of running in circles around the entire map to find all of them, that, or have to waste all that time and end giving up on the side mission. said resources are then used to buy meaningless, superficial upgrades that exist in very small amounts for the pieces of gear, and that may just as well not be used at all, which is fine balance-wise, but in this state, just boring. and all that to go and grind more meaningless resources. as a bonus, the mining is rather slow, tedious, and boring. at least, as a solo player we can get around this with a companion robot that can mine stuff for us and do it faster

the weapons and gadgets are pretty boring to use, and the too limited ammo (especially for some gadgets) makes it worse. there are games with much more dull gunplay than deep rock galactic, but it's still not great. plus, the enemies are boring and are almost always the same, with little variation. it's not that bad, but it's not really fun or engaging either. at times, spiderman-ing all over the place with the scout's grapling to perform different actions in a hurry during combat can be somewhat interesting, but again it's still not really great, especially given the rest of the game's environment.

the difficulty levels ranging from 1 to 5 are dumb and unbalanced. 4 and 5 are a "the developpers did not test their own game" situation and losing or not does not depend on players skill and the mobs and combat mechanics are fucking lame and overpowered. even the event tasks in any difficulty. the game heavily discriminates against and punishes solo players for being solo players, as companies do as usual, but they make shitty events that may let players earn rewards, well maybe or maybe not, who knows, because a timer is imposed there and there is just not enough time to complete them, so that you did everything right, like having 2 minutes to go and killing health sponge mobs and collecting and bringing 6 resources from them that you have so slowly carry to some pod, and have the timer end 2 or 3 seconds before you can use the pod while you are next to it. very few games make me go "wow this is so lame and such a waste of time, what a shitty game, let's do something else" and alt f4 midplay and this "game" is one of them
 
account and characters level ups let players unlock and buy more upgrades but also cosmetics. but after about 10 hours of active playtime, the game has nothing to show for it. there are very few unlocks and they are barely visible, are very similar to eachother, and pretty ugly and uninteresting. it's very meager. i did not even bother with them and mostly kept the base looks because there is no point to it. a few cosmetics can also be unlocked by having a chance to have a chest-like event spawn in a mission or reaching milestones, or completing tasks in the time-limited battle pass (which does not cost additional money and, according to what i read, let players access to all items from the previous ones, which is how it should be, so supposedly it's not the typical super-hard fomo kind of battle pass), but here again, the cosmetics are pretty ugly and uninteresting. and not just that, but cosmetic chests are very rare in game, i've had 3 in over 25 hours and 1 set of skins for 1 class that were ugly, doing "endgame" content after about 30-40 hours, so you could play hundreds of hours and not getting what you want/get only ugly things. there is also some paywalled content as displayed on the store page

along with the boring cosmetics, the graphics are pretty plain and dull, and the humor is bad

the online sucks. join a host and they kick you before the mission ends or you brought all the resources needed for a task. host a game so that you can't be kicked and others put efforts into griefing you by activating things without waiting (including the exit event when you are not ready, not with them, and don't know the way back), starting end of mission event, and entering the exit and then blocking it to try to prevent you from successfully finishing the mission. otherwise it's struggling to get everyone at the same place or finding the way to get back to them even with the 3D map because it's terrible

i kept playing after the tutorial thinking that there would probably be more, but even being past completing the hours-long introduction and its series of missions and having played in all zones, unlocked new weapons and reached max level and prestiged on a class along with a few perks, it's never really the case (around 25 hours playtime, 50 steam hours is due to idle). spending a decent amount of hours and nothing to show for it and just not really having fun because this game has nothing much to offer. it's not the most terrible game there is, and i might still play it, but it's rather a bland game, and certainly not a super fun jesus game like the very overhyped reviews and ads make it out to be

You have probably heard about the how the game is just fun or maybe it is just the wholesome community. I am willing to admit I don't have an incredible amount of time in game, but I value my time none the less. I wouldn't recommend getting this game, because you likely will LOSE ALL YOUR PROGRESS WITHOUT CAUSE OR REASON. Sure I don't have 4k+ hours in game.(this could just as easily happen to someone who does) However I did buy several cosmetic packs in game, because I really appreciated my time, and wanted to let Ghost Shit Games know they made an awesome product(huge dumb ass move). Unfortunately and stupidly thought I could return and play at my leisure. Unless you are willing to dedicate hard-drive space, and never upgrade your computer I wouldn't bother buying. Before you go telling me I'm wrong or look in my steam common folder for saved data, but why should if have to edit files like I'm living in the dark ages. Truthfully I spent the better part of an hour looking for a solution edited the files in question only for the game to crash immediately when trying to do anything that has a menu, several times. This is by far the last game I expected to get fucked over by, but then again they already got my money so I guess jokes on me.

Edit 1:
- I stopped playing due to how stale the game got, half of my playtime (the last 400 hours) was just to carry or fill in friends parties.
- Then I tried the game again recently and after a whole year avoiding this game due to toxic community outside the game I thought it was time to give it a chance one more time:
- And in a single mission I found bugs that haven't been fixed since I bought the game (glacial heat vents) and not a single one of the issues I had with hitboxes from dreadnoughts were fixed.
- On top of that I actually found a few visual glitches that I didn't noticed before (Drak weapon switch smoke). 

Well done DRG, actual game development stopped long long ago and all that's left is pumping content...

+ I still keep this review as positive recommended because even though I hit the skill ceiling a long long time ago and am severely disappointed at the devs and the community, this is still an amazing game and worth it for most people. 
- I might come back when new seasons are released but since each season has longer intervals between releases and it's mostly cosmetics and gimmick mission mechanics or gimmick equipments, nothing to improve the skill ceiling so I don't have much hope on the new seasons.

A lovely game in total, you select your tasks, go to a mission and you kill and mine your way through. The game is by far the best example for live service, as it keeps getting updated and it doesnt have any stupid microtransactions, you can only buy skin dlc packs. Personally it does get boring eventually when you've seen everything, but for exactly this we have updates. More mission types would be nice, but it is what it is. For a multiplayer game, I must say, toxicity is rare and that's known by everyone. 

Though a fair warning to those coming in the next following seasons, the current game progression is starting to become a bit too luck based. There's upgrades which you get by pure luck, as updates roll around these upgrades become harder and harder to get, atleast the specific ones. Same with skins, though you don't have to fear missing out, the chance you'll get the specific thing you want will become smaller and smaller as more updates come. I really do hope they'll fix this. 

I'd say with 300 hours I can only say the games damn worth it.

Have you always been a fan of Sandbox games, but think that they didn't put enough focus on the fighting mechanic or enemies in general? 
Did you always like the trips into the caves the most when playing Terraria, Starbound & co?
Do you hate Elves, and love Dwarves?
Well then Rock and Stone Brother, cuz this game is perfect for you!


It's all about that cave exploring, whilst fighting hordes of enemies L4D style.
But most importantly you can be one of four classes and screw over your friends (sold separately) by not fulfilling your role.

Or, if friends are too expensive for you, rely on randoms, because that's completely foolproof and is totally not going to end in chaos (but let's be honest though... this is exactly what you want, isn't it?).

Or, if you're so bad at socializing that even randoms aren't an option, then let me present to you your new (and only) robot friend: Bosco! 
He does all the work for you, while you're out of ammo and busy running away from all the aliens (trust me, I've got experience on this matter... ).

Well, what are you waiting for? Buy it! Do it for Karl!

Genuinely one of the most engaging and fun games I've ever played, and easily my favorite extraction type game.
Its been a bit of a wait for the new season but there was plenty of content for the last one, and they've added stuff in the meantime. 
It really feels like the team cares deeply about this product and as much about it as the community; and lemme tell you, these players LOVE this game. And people just love doing their jobs and cooperating. Sometimes 5 seconds of nonverbal communication puts a whole team of randos in sync. 
DRG is really magical like that.
Also the mod scene is really healthy and that arm of the community is super welcoming and loves new ideas. Lots of great QoL stuff out there, and I personally recommend the Googly Eyes mod for maximum hilarity.

I think I saw a meme about this game and then forgot; only to be reminded of it months later and finally trying it after a group of buddies were going to. The start felt confusing and long for the most time; but one day everything clicked and I began getting better and better. I reacted and shot faster; experimented with builds, and began testing my limits by going solo on Hazard 5 or even solo Elite Deep Dives and began winning. It is very rare that a game has me wanting to test myself in this way and I have just about enjoyed every hour pushing what I could do and finally getting every achievement.
With any online random players there are bound to be shenanigans; but over 700 hours I played I only recall like 2 or 3 tops; a staggering feat this community is aware of and proud.

While there is nothing left to gain for me here as I feel completely accomplished; I salute to any dwarf ready to take this journey on. Rock and Stone.

This game really grew on me. It's a fun, quirky first person shooter that provides exploration, customizable loudouts, plenty of cosmetics to unlock (the vast majority of which can be acquired without DLC), and the choice to either tackle a mission alone, invite friends and coordinate abilities, or join an online game. Each of the four dwarf classes feel distinct from one another, and encourages cooperation with other players. The weapons and equipment have great customization options between the selectable perks and "overclocks" which provide substantially different effects that change the way you use them.

While the mission types and objectives start to feel recycled after a while, the maps are randomly generated to offer a new-ish experience every time. Every once in a while, it will toss in a random event or chest to unlock an upgrade or cosmetic.

Overall it's worth checking out, and would definitely recommend it to a group looking for a cooperative multi-player experience, or for lone wolves who want to tackle a cavern themselves. Have it your way like BK.

As a native Hoxxes IV bug, I've had the unique opportunity to play Deep Rock Galactic, a game that I found both exhilarating and a tad melancholic!

Seeing the intricate tunnels of our home rendered with such care and detail was nothing short of breathtaking.

Deep Rock Galactic portrays us, the native fauna of Hoxxes, as mere obstacles, easily squashed under the boots of the formidable dwarven miners. While it's true that we do have our disagreements with the miners over territory and resources (and admittedly, we do occasionally snack on an unwary dwarf), the game simplifies these interactions into straightforward combat encounters.
 
It's important to remember that not all of us are hostile by nature. Many of us prefer to live in peace, away from the booming explosives and piercing drill bits.

The depiction of our kind as simple fodder does a disservice to the complexity of our ecosystems and social structures. We have families, communities, and even cultures that are as diverse as the biomes we inhabit. Some of us are indeed fierce and protective of our territory, but many are just curious or even friendly, merely observing the dwarves with fascination rather than malice.

However, despite these misgivings, I can't help but admire the game's design and the thrilling adventures it offers. The teamwork and camaraderie encouraged among players are truly commendable, and the sense of accomplishment from completing a difficult mission is unmatched.

 The game beautifully captures the thrill of exploration and the relentless drive to delve deeper into the unknown, something both dwarves and bugs can relate to.

Deep rock galactic (DRG) is a breath of fresh air in a market where most "team-based" multiplayer shooters foster toxicity and stress. It's the only team shooter I really enjoy having random teammates. Furthermore, DRG is not trying to manipulate itself further into your wallet. You get a lot for your buck, especially with this game commonly being on sale.

-The game encourages and facilitates comradery and teamwork.
-Because the game encourages comradery, the community in turn is very nice and friendly 90% of the time. (I can count on my hand the amount of times I've bumped into rude teammates.)
-Engaging progressions system.
-Countless fun and viable gun/perk builds between 4 incredibly designed character classes.
-Almost 0 fomo mechanics that give you a false sense of urgency to play the game. (At worst you have to wait a year for a holiday event to come back around)
-The game is as hard as you want it to be but always rewarding.
-There is no stupid rotating cosmetic store.
-This game has had (and continues to have) multiple free massive content updates.
-99% of cosmetic items are earned with the exception of a few rewards from developer supporter packs.

I'm sure there's currently some gigantic live service that the mainstream industry is trying to tout as some modern day pinnacle of gaming achievement, but in my opinion this is truly what a modern, fully featured game should be.

Deep Rock Galactic is a somewhat simple game; you kit yourself out with a loadout that starts basic and grows organically into something more complex and custom. You go down into a gorgeously crafted environment, immerse yourself in brilliant atmosphere and music, focus on extracting minerals and completing tasks while fighting off bugs, and then you are rewarded with better guns, cool cosmetics, and a round at the bar.

Then you go again. That's it.

Compared to a sprawling, epic game that would typically be called an 'AAA' game, Deep Rock Galactic seems to have comparatively little 'meat' to offer. But between the biomes, the mission types, the enemy variety, the classes, the frequent updates, and of course the tantalizing and frequent rewards all create a gameplay loop that is worth coming back to over. And over. And over. 

Yet with that, and the fact that there are multiple DLC offers festooned on this page, all of this sounds less than appealing. Why get into yet another 'live service' and grind for a million hours only to come up just short and have to shell out for a cooler looking helmet? If the glowing praise of the gameplay doesn't interest you enough, then this is what sets Deep Rock Galactic apart and makes it a true modern gem;

It respects your time entirely.

Besides said DLC which are entirely cosmetic, every one of the beard colours, helmets, hair styles, and all other cosmetics can be earned in game. Despite having seasons and a (entirely free) battle pass to work through, said seasonal items are placed into random drops for you after the season is over. These drops are available forever, in any mission, so no matter if you play daily or hop on for a few hours every week or two, the game is always cheerfully ready to reward you for playing it. If there's something you want, you don't have to be browbeaten into spending money to get it... You just have to dig!

In all of this, I could praise the voice work, the writing, the graphics, the gunplay, but the most important thing to point out is that Deep Rock Galactic is an incredibly friendly and wonderful multiplayer experience. You haven't truly grown your whiskers until you've plunged into Hoxxes with a friend (or three) and shown what four drunk midget miners can do to a bug population in half an hour. The PvE design and the clever positive reinforcements the game has in place make it legendary for its friendly community and welcoming atmosphere. It can't be guaranteed, nor can we assure it will always be that way, but it says something about a game when it grows its own wholesomeness, instead of the expected toxicity.

DRG will be remembered in perpetuity. In fifty years, when someone is discussing top tier multiplayer games, Deep Rock Galactic will always be on someone's mind. And in a world where greedy companies are slavering to increase the price and create perpetual whale-draining machines...

It's probably better to go with indentured service to the number one intergalactic mining company instead!

Deep Rock Galactic is a stellar example of the four player co-op formula done right. This game has almost everything going for it and there's not really a lot of areas where I would say it fails. The most obvious trait that sets the game apart are the destructible procedurally generated environments. Not only do these destructible environments set the game apart, but mining your way through levels and creating paths is a very key element of the gameplay. The cave setting also allows the procedural generation a lot of freedom to keep environments unique and the replay value high as a result.

The four classes also present a good amount of variety and good synergy between classes. For instance engineers can fire platforms to reach hard to reach areas and the scout can then use their zipline to access those platforms and acquire the minerals in those locations. Each class has a primary and secondary and 3 options for each. They also have a choice of 4 throwables they can take as well. On top of that they also have two other unique tools specific to each class (ie ziplines, drills, turrets, satchel charges, etc). You can also customize each class beyond just picking weapons by using overclocks to change how weapons function, as well as mods to modify your weapons and gear in different ways, and perks that also impact your gameplay. Then, of course, you have the usual cosmetics of which there is a good variety of ways to customize your look.

Then of course there's the games humor, which you can't talk about DRG without bringing up. You've got amusing voicelines, dancing and mini-games between missions in the space rig, a bar where a good selection of specialty brews can help fuel all sorts of antics, and of course just kicking barrels in to the launch bay to upset mission control. Between missions the bar also offers a beer to purchase that will provide a buff for your next mission, though which beer is available for the next mission is random. The community also has a number of rituals of sorts, such as pinging large mushrooms or gold chunks/bittergems until mission control gets angry and yells at you. There's also the faux pas of leaving your drilldozers head behind in escort missions in spite of no real benefit to bringing it other than the shame of not doing so. You'll quickly discover once you start that this is a very good and friendly community with a lot of rituals and in-jokes to familiarize yourself with.

Long-term replay value is provided not just through the use of procedural environments, but also a large array of mission types, most of which play quite a bit different from one another. If you've come from other co-op games one of my personal complaints has always been the generally repetition of missions regardless of the type. Warframe, for instance, is another game I play which unfortunately tends to play out the same every time regardless of the mission type. In DRG, however, each mission type is pretty unique in what you have to do and how you do it. You've got missions to setup a refinery and build pipes to your pumps, missions to gather eggs or a certain type of mineral, others to eradicate a boss or a number of powerful enemies, and so on. On top of that every mission has a secondary objective to work as well. Then there are also events which have a chance to show up during a mission, each of which are pretty unique from each other in their own right and can range from a unique enemy, or a machine you have to feed a material or destroy, or a machine to hack, or meteors to crack open, and so many more.

Then every week you also have an assignment to earn overclock cores or materials, or do a 3-mission long deep dive or elite deep dive which is more difficult than a typical single mission but also rewards overclock cores. There are plenty of overclock cores to earn as well so you'll have plenty of long-term value if you're someone that likes progressing. There are also seasonal events as well as a number of holiday events which usually provide decor for the Space Rig, cosmetics to earn, and often another side-objective in missions for a bonus.

Another good plus worth mentioning is the games small footprint both in size and in how much it needs from your system. This makes the game very accessible since you don't need a high end machine at all to play it and it doesn't take a lot of space on your machine either. This can be a very good thing when it comes to games to play with friends since we all probably know at least one person with an outdated PC or that's always eating up their drive space.

The only main gripe I have is that the game uses peer-to-peer hosting, similar to Warframe. While this, in itself, isn't completely terrible, it does have the unfortunate side-effect of sometimes causing lag if the hosts connection isn't quite up to the task, and even mission loss if the host should lose connection outright. It's rare, but it is possible if the host drops then the mission is basically just lost. Warframe offers a host migration which is often buggy, but at least it means the players can continue. Sadly in DRG you just get booted from the mission outright if that happens. Now, in my currently 274 hours played, this has only happened twice so luckily it isn't common. Also, I will note, that the effect of lag is not as pronounced as I've noticed in other games that use peer-to-peer hosting.

All in all I would say DRG is definitely one of the better games I have picked up over the past few years. It's great fun with friends, but also completely soloable if that's your thing, and it offers great long-term value. It also receives great support from its developer which is definitely a huge plus compared to a gaming world dominated by the EA's and Ubisofts of the world.

In short: buy it. it's a great game.

Are you ready to embark on an intergalactic mining adventure like no other? Look no further than Deep Rock Galactic! As an avid gamer, I can confidently say that this game offers an unparalleled experience that will keep you hooked for hours on end.

From the moment you step foot into the cavernous depths of procedurally generated worlds, you're greeted with stunning visuals that bring the alien landscapes to life. The attention to detail in the environments is truly remarkable, making each expedition feel fresh and exciting.

But what truly sets Deep Rock Galactic apart is its cooperative gameplay. Whether you're playing with friends or teaming up with fellow dwarves online, the camaraderie and teamwork required to overcome the various challenges is both exhilarating and rewarding. With four unique classes to choose from, each with their own strengths and abilities, there's a playstyle to suit every preference.

The core gameplay loop of mining resources, fighting off hordes of hostile creatures, and completing objectives is incredibly addictive. The sense of progression as you upgrade your gear and unlock new abilities keeps you coming back for more, eager to dive deeper into the unknown.

One aspect of Deep Rock Galactic that deserves special praise is its developer support. The team at Ghost Ship Games is dedicated to listening to community feedback and regularly releases updates and patches to improve the game and add new content. It's clear that they have a genuine passion for their creation, and it shines through in every aspect of the experience.

In conclusion, Deep Rock Galactic is a shining example of what a cooperative multiplayer game should be. With its immersive gameplay, stunning visuals, and strong community, it's a must-play for anyone looking for a thrilling adventure with friends. So grab your pickaxe, strap on your gear, and get ready to delve into the depths of fun!

In the last 3 months I have managed to sink almost 200 hours into this game, and for really good reason! DRG has been a great game to play with friends in private sessions, solo, or online with random players. One key feature that stands out is being able to join a game mid way through without penalty or consequence. 

Fellow dwarves are friendly in the community. Even when you're having a bad day and getting downed people are generally kind. The combination of having rounds that have no negative effect / damage to your overall experience is relieving compared to the competitive nature of many modern games. 

Shooting bugs, mining minerals, and making sure Dotty gets on the escape pod has, and will continue to bring a lot of enjoyment. Raise your glass, dance like nobody is watching, and give out a huge Rock and Stone!
I think about this game every time I'm not playing it.

I have clocked in a great many hours into this game since I picked it up, and like, I have so little going on in my life that I'm not inclined to put it down, but this is probably the most frustrating horde shooter I've played bar none.

- Enemy design is pure garbage. It's just bad. Enemy types entrench the game's stagnant meta strategies with heavy feast or famine practical functionality on higher difficulty settings. For examples, Naedocyte Shockers are small mobile flying electric bugs randomly appearing in large numbers that get rolled over by meta weapons like ECR Lok-1 and PP EPC and make you eat excrement otherwise with their annoying full screen blind and slow and tiny hitboxes that screw over a good number of weapons that already weren't great. Stingtails are designed to be annoying (despite that not adding any unique design language to a game full of annoying enemies) yet don't meaningfully serve as a counter to hold strategies due to the existence of Dash just letting you run back to your hold and instead messing with mobile strategies where you get pulled directly into the swarm you're kiting or more likely into an instant death fall that you don't have any control over because you're not controlling your environment like in a hold strategy. (Just add fall damage resistance when grabbed by stingtails.)
- Seasonal content is implemented horribly. Seasons last until the next seasonal update rolls around, which is simply far too long to be subjected to one sort of thing. Seasonal content is rushed and lacks appeal past the season end date, like Industrial Sabotage which is extremely repetitive in its design (repeat objective twice into boss fight that only changes up its between boss fight ability) and lacks any real longevity despite you now being forced to play it constantly because of the Assignments system. The game will have been plagued by Critical Corruption for a full year when it is finally superseded by Season 5, a season that seems to have actively just been bad for the game. A toggle was added to turn off seasonal content, but doing this means nuking a third of the mission choices off your map and also avoiding the season 3 content (seasons sort of come in two parts). I like getting frequent meteor events, I don't despise rockpox, I just don't want to see the corruptor every time I do an escort.
- The community is okay for a horde shooter. It gets compared to PvP games a lot, but for the genre, it's just okay. Low level of skill amongst the general playerbase makes hosting public higher difficulty lobbies a chore and general community sentiment on places like Reddit is obnoxious and boils down to a toxic positivity that completely evaporates if you word your post passively enough that it doesn't bruise egos.
- Game generally lacks polish in a lot of areas. An enemy like the Cave Leech turns from a minor nuisance to a fun ruining nightmare due to an audio bug easily addressed by mods. Buff beers apply the effect they list twice due to a bug that they decided to keep in but never formalize despite it taking minimal effort to just change the description text on the drinks. Weird ass bugs (not a pun) like Qronar corpses t-posing and moving around distractingly. Antiquated mechanics that haven't been tweaked like one of the Dreadnought bosses moving and attacking really slowly in solo to the point where it's a joke while the other ones that came afterwards are completely unaffected so it's a jarring jump between the two. And many other issues caused either by bugs or incompetence.
- Balance issues. Balance updates are few and far between (the November maintenance update brought some changes, but Feburary did not), and aren't super comprehensive. Why is the MK2 turret still completely useless compared to Gemini? Why didn't you buff the Stubby ammo mods so they still had more total damage than the damage mods? Why is the Springloaded Ripper still only good for killing teammates? Why does the Wave Cooker exist?
- The Overclock end-game progression system that gives weapons cool and fun stats was fun for the first while when the game is showering you in Overclocks from your initial promos and the introductory assignments, but now I just hate that it's a slow ass 90% random grind that handicaps my ability to make new cool builds. Only getting 6 weapon overclocks a week in addition to one every 10 hours from your promos sucks considering how random the system is. There are a lot of overclocks that aren't even very good but sound fun that I want to try making builds with anyways, but I just can't, because I keep getting boring cleans that are straight stat upgrades that take overclockless builds.
- Higher difficulty levels are just not fun experiences. This is due in part to the game's "mantra of the curveball" design philosophy, which is a neat game design hack that works on lower difficulties and lower skill levels of player, but does not work on higher difficulties where the bare workings of the game are more apparent and the game becomes an obnoxious flippy nightmare of either being bored out of your mind or dying instantly. This does not help people have an experience that's consistently engaging, nor does it help people find the right difficulty for them so they don't engage in content out of their league.
- You can block players from joining your game, but like, is there any way for me to block hosts from my server list so I don't keep joining horribly laggy games?

I have more issues with the game than I have listed here, like solo balancing decisions, certain random event designs, more enemy designs, perks, the assignments system, the early game progression, but it's a lot, and I'm not going to beat off the horse. Suffice to say it makes the game a genuinely unfun chore to play at times, more than enough to offset the positive moments. So, why am I still playing this game?

- Practical functionality excluded (some weapons are real bad without overclocks), I think DRG has some of the coolest weapons in all of FPS. The Lok-1 is a genius idea, the Shard Diffractor is a gun that both works on its own right and comes into its own with the most varied selection of overclocks, the Voltaic Stun Sweeper is not technically a very good grenade but I love it anyways and you'll never stop me from using it. If this stuff was in a game that didn't make me irrationally angry, I would be coming non-stop.
- I enjoy the mission type variety. I love building and riding pipes in Refinery, I love the mad dash to shove the final egg that spawns a swarm into the M.U.L.E in Egg Hunt, and I love one-magging Dreadnoughts on Haz 1 Solo Elimination in comedic fashion. Sometimes you're not going to be playing what you want because you're caught in an endless cycles of assignments or the mission type you're in the mood for is in Hollow Bough, or has a bad mutator like Mactera Plague and you don't feel like playing Engineer right now, but I mean, it does make it feel that bit better when you do finally get to play Refinery.
- Uh, mods? I installed a mod that makes Mission Control super entertaining. I would have actually stopped playing the game already if not for Cave Leech Loudener because they are genuinely that bad. I like it when the Lootbugs are cats and play Stockmarket by Weebl.

Other than that, I still play this game because I actually enjoy being angry because it's a preferrable alternative to the horrible intrusive thoughts I would be dealing with otherwise if the game was just boring me to death.

Simply the most fun you can have in a coop PvE shooter. Really, I mean it ! The game takes blatant inspiration from TF2, like its wacky weapon design, highly customizable characters, and different classes with different roles in the team. Being a big TF2 fan, it warms my heart that some more modern games adopt similar design strategies. It offers diverse mission types, and multiple sidegrades and weapon overclocks (that can modify from stats, to core mechanics of a weapon), so there's always something new to try in this game. Of course, I highly recommend that you play it with friends, because, while the game can be fun in solo, it's at its most awesome when "crisis managing" with your buddies, and making it out alive. So, chug your beer, we're heading straight down. Rock and Stone, miner !

I am a 45 yo father, probably one of the oldest people playing this game. I am a single father to my Son, who is 14 now. My son got this game for Christmas in 2021 from his uncle, so we installed it on his computer and he started playing. By the end of the week he had 24 hours on this game. This was horrible for me, as it was already hard for me to find ways to spend time with my son, as he is always out with his friends or just watching YouTube. So i decided to make a Steam account and get this game to see if I could maybe play alongside him. I loaded into the game, picked my character and world and started playing but I was stuck on what you where supposed to do. I asked my Son for help and he hosted a game for me to join. I loved it as it was the best time I had spent with my Son since my wife had died. This game has ever since brought me and my son closer again and now we actually spend time together outside the house together as well. This game reminded me that there's fun to be had in everything, and it has brought both me and my Son many happy memories.

I simply love DRG, it provides one of the smoothest multiplayer experiences you can find on Steam.
Game doesn't cost much, frequently appears on sales and has easy learning curve.
Multiplayer is the most enjoyable part of the game as community is very friendly and patient, if you're beginner don't be afraid to ask about stuff. I generally recommend to avoid playing alone, having Bosco by your side is cool but this is not when the game blooms.
Each character is unique in his own way, have own set of guns, tools and requires different playstyle.

Big chunk of game is locked behind progression which is new guns, modifications, overclocks and access to Deep Dives. Also ton of cosmetics for your characters. So in other words, game gets better with every next unlock.

There's couple of cons I would like to mention:
[list]
  [*] Overclocks unlocks are randomized and you have no control over it, so better try to get advantage from what you have got instead of trying to follow some specific build;
  [*] Resources required for upgrades aren't evenly distributed, so one way or another there will be always shortage of one resource and surplus of another. Thankfully you can buy/sell them;
  [*] I've been playing for a bit longer than year already and would like to say that Season 4 being a bit extended version of Season 3 is quite disappointing. Rockpox isn't the best mechanic, yet you get another season about it, now with even more frustrating enemies. Really looking for game getting some big updates in the future.
  [*] Game really needs shooting range, as you can try your updated build only during missions. I know there's a mod for that, but would really like if it was included in game officially.
[/list]

Still, I would recommend it to everyone, at least to try, pretty sure you won't be disappointed.

-Good graphics
-A lot of different things to do
-Missions are easy to understand but still has room for complex gameplay once you get better
-Weapons are very fun
-AI is very responsive

The Bad:
-Getting matrix cores often feels too tedious 
Score:
10/10

Embarking on an odyssey spanning a staggering 500+ hours within the multifaceted realms of Deep Rock Galactic, my journey through the cosmos of cooperative camaraderie has been nothing short of stellar. Second only to the venerable Earth Defense Force 5 in my pantheon of cherished team-based endeavors, this game has etched itself indelibly upon the canvas of my gaming tapestry. Let us delve into the expansive quarry of reasons that makes this title an exemplar of digital opulence.

Firstly, the optimization prowess of Deep Rock Galactic is nothing short of remarkable, accommodating even the most humble of computational configurations with an unrivaled finesse. The graphical tapestry, while eschewing realism, crafts its own aesthetic allure that resonates seamlessly with the thematic undertones of this celestial escapade. It harmonizes impeccably with the game's essence, a symbiosis of visual delight and functionality.

The hallmark of destructible landscapes unfurls a realm of possibilities where terra firma yields to the incendiary might of our endeavors. A cavalcade of drilling, explosive detonations, and cataclysmic alterations to the very topography itself lends an exhilarating dynamism. Each geological contour, a testament to the malleability inherent in the cosmic canvas we traverse. A symphony of controlled chaos orchestrated to reach point A from B with unbridled creativity.

Dwelling upon the bedrock of Deep Rock Galactic's ingenuity lies its class system, an intricately woven tapestry of symbiotic roles that harmonize seamlessly within the confines of cooperative play. Each class, a distinct facet, coalesces with others to craft an ensemble of versatility. A well-balanced team, a veritable phalanx of varied skills, ensures a harmonious traverse through the cavernous domains that await.

Content, an inexhaustible fount, cascades forth with a profusion that challenges the temporal constraints of mere mortals. Countless hours wane, yet the riches within the game persist, promising ever-elusive depths waiting to be plumbed. The metaphysical quarry, a cornucopia of missions, challenges, and undiscovered treasures beckons with a siren's call.

The whimsical caper of spontaneity unfolds as I descend into the enigmatic maw of random games. A dalliance with fortuity, my companions are not mere cohorts; they are co-architects of our collective destiny. A testament to the amiable player base, where toxicity withers like a parched lichen in the face of cooperative exuberance. For over 500 hours, a transient odyssey with strangers, not a whiff of toxicity, but a tapestry woven with shared camaraderie.

"Rock and Stone," a mantra that transcends linguistic confines, reverberates through the caverns of camaraderie, echoing with the resonance of shared triumphs. As stalwart miners, we traverse the cosmos, leaving naught but the resonant chorus of our endeavors—indeed, we are rich. Rich not merely in gold nuggets, but in the intangible wealth of shared laughter, triumphs, and the enduring bonds forged in the crucible of Deep Rock Galactic.

In conclusion, do I, with the fervor of a prospector who unearths an unparalleled gem, recommend this game? With resounding certainty, I utter the emphatic refrain: indeed, I do. The echoes of "Rock and Stone" pervade my gaming sanctum, a testament to the heartfelt connection that transcends the pixels on the screen. Deep Rock Galactic is not merely a game; it is a tapestry woven with the threads of friendship and camaraderie. We are rich, not just in in-game minerals, but in the wealth of memories forged within the cavernous embrace of this digital cosmos.

A quick summary... This is game involves mining minerals, shooting bugs, and finishing objectives with 1 of 4 different specialised dwarfs. Each dwarf has their own way of doing things, able to go it alone, or even team up to compliment one another's play style. Progression in the game involves levelling up, getting access to alternate weapons, and improving said weapons. Over time you unlock a huge selection of cosmetics to make your dwarf unique among others.

There are many things about DRG I love. The feeling of smacking dirt until breaking into a cavern... the speed in which you destroy a stream of Nitra... the pop a loot bug makes...

Over the years, this came had been polished until it gleams.

Awesome game from the start. What makes DRG stand out is it unique gameplay, awesome dev team, and awesome community(emphasis on awesome). From when I started playing to where i am now, the community has been a pleasure to play with. The devs aren't cash-grabby (*cough* EA *cough*) , so when you pay for the game, you get EVERYTHING the game has to offer. Gameplay is simple and easy: drop in, mine rock (and Stone), do objective, do secondary objective, get out. While the game focuses on multiplayer, singleplayer is also easy and fun (thanks BOSCO). I have so much more to say abt the dev team and the game itself but I'll stop yapping. Moral of the story: it good game so get game. And one more thing: ROCK AND STONE!!

This game has been a lot of fun thus far. The gameplay is enjoyable, and the microtransactions are entirely optional and purely cosmetic.
There are a significant variety of missions, and the progression feels meaningful and deep. At 51 hours in, I've only scratched the surface. 
The devs also have a great sense of humor, and you can tell from all the little touches that they genuinely have fun with this.

I'm not normally a fan of online, non-narrative games. But the cooperative design and addicting gameplay loops always suck me in to DRG every time I come back to it. Such a fun game, whether playing with friends or a podcast. So well designed, with regular updates and no predatory monetisation despite how easy it would be for them. It's an astounding game, and I'm delighted that it's such a huge success.

Very fun game, incredibly well done, beautiful art and sound, as well as hilarious and engaging gameplay. However I cannot say I'd recommend it due to one simple yet abundantly frustrating thing. Korlach the Plant Boss. (Might not be spelled exactly correctly) This boss has single-handedly ended so many runs. full squad, going well, stocked up on nitra, OBJ going well, then plant boss spawns. 20 minutes later we've only done 1/4th of its hp due to its RIDICULOUS regeneration, completely out of ammo and nitra, OBJ about to fail, and 3/4 dwarves are dead. Every. Single. Time. This one single boss has me seriously considering a permanent uninstall. It is nothing more than an Anti-Fun mechanic as it is right now.

This game is easily one of my top three games ever. There are four characters to choose from. A whole lot of different missions from mining, building, and killing very large bugs or machines. Tons of maps each with different mobs, ores, layouts, and more. Different anomalies and warning to make the missions more exciting. The dialogue in this game is funny as hell between the dwarfs and Mission Control. The multiplayer in this game is phenomenal as the dwarfs interact with each other. If you don't like using your microphone then you can let your dwarf speak for you as you play. The single player in this game is also amazing with the addition of Bosco to your team. Most importantly about this game though is Steve, beer, and the unholy amount of bugs. From 1 to 10 this game is a 1000.

The perfect game to play with your bro/s. 

The gameplay loop is perfect for it. The gameplay loop is intuitive and requires a bit of thinking and understanding but once you understand the gameplay types it requires a lot less thinking. This means that while you and your bro/s are going out and completing this task (all of which are pretty satisfying) there's lots of time for laughing, joking, bants.

There are enough assignments and unlocks to keep things interesting for a lot of gameplay. The weekly assignments are nice just for some amount of play but the events have a lot more fun. The guns are great but get unlocked pretty quickly. This is actually great though because then you can experiment with your loadouts to see which works best for you and for each mission type. Past that, each gun has perk slots that you can experiment with to further tweak your loadout. For even longer interest, the overclocks allow you even further tweak your guns or unlock really neat abilities that can really change how each of the guns play.

In my opinion, difficulty 4 is just enemy spam so it makes it more annoying without it being more difficult. 

Overall, buy this with your bro/s and have tons of fun.

Alright, this game is what many games strive to be. I have some key points to put this game through. It excels in many areas of gaming, such as how it is marketed, team building, and gunplay to name a few. I am decently new to the game, so take everything I say with a grain of salt.

      Pros
- Each class is fun to play and balanced
- Requires extensive teamwork and communication
- Great to play with friends
- Almost to no microtransactions
- No adds for the givin microtransactions
- A GIANT cataloge of enemies with a guidebook showing each attack
- Easy for new players to pick up
- A giant hub with tons of stuff to mess around with
- Great randomly generated caves
- Tons of FREE cosmetics
- Satisfying gameplay
- Keeps you thinking

I would like to note, the cons are mostly my opinion, many people might disagree. I will leave a small reason of why I think it is bad. 

        Cons
- Hitscan guns
Makes aiming wayyyyy to easy for most weapons, I feel there should be less hitscan in these games (Like 1
hitscan gun per class or smth)
- Not fun without friends
I love the community of drg, but for someone who is decently introverted, it can be difficult, I am lucky to have a large group of friends to play with, but BOSCO can not replace them.
- Grindy near the end
Overclocks take way to long to get, along with them being mostly RNG
- Not a ton of graphics settings
There are several graphics settings, but I want to count the dwarfs nose hairs, so a "OMEGA" graphics option might help.
- Seasonal events
It feels like season 4 will never end, I want to start a new season and half to grind a ton more.

I know many people would disagree, but it isnt a perfect game, there is no such thing as one. I love playing
this game with my friends, it is some of the most fun stuff ive ever done, so dont take the cons as critisisms,
they are mearly suggestions for updates. Thank you for reading, ROCK AND STONE, my brothers

Been a while since I played, decided to give it another shot. It's just not fun overall. The combat is more fun than I remember, but not great. Surely more fun with friends (was revisiting solo), but I have played the game co-op and it doesn't exactly turn a new leaf. The reality is the moment I start a new mission of a type I have already done, I completely zone out. There isn't a greater goal. The missions themselves are fun in their repetition but don't lead to anything other than doing them again on higher difficulties. I can already solo level 4 missions with level 1 or 2 classes, and the max difficulty is 5, so the challenge isn't a selling point. The setting of the game is great, but I need the game to be engaging, and it isn't. Some people seem happy to run around yelling "ROCK AND STONE" at any and every mention of dwarves like it's a personality trait but I don't know what the average player is really getting out of this game. It's alright but make sure you get it in some combination of: having friends who will play with you, getting it on sale, or you have literally no other game you might like to play.

First off I'd like to say this game is an absolute blast to play either alone or with friends. 

The gameplay instills a sense of camaraderie between complete strangers and has a very positive community that helps and encourages each other to be successful and efficient in the way you play. I've yet to meet a negative person that griefed or refused to perform their job roles when in a match as it does take the help of everyone to get out successfully on the harder difficulties. When playing with friends everyone feels a part of the team and knows they play an important part in helping out which creates this active and inviting nature about the game. The developers actually listen to the community and make updates that keep the player base high and extremely rewarding! All the collectibles in the game are completely free and even the past season's loot is still obtainable. I've now played the game for roughly 130ish hours and I'll prob play it much more in the future as it's a game that I've met so many new friends who I've created exciting and extremely funny moments with.

Finally, I'd like to say if you're considering getting this game either for yourself or a friend you'll feel it was money well spent.
Best wishes and Merry Christmas!

I know I'm almost four years late to the party, but I have to sing the praises of this game. It really is SO good!

The mechanics and missions are nicely varied, the graphics have a nice stylised look to them, and the developers are beyond-awesome with no predatory monetisation. Co-op is a great laugh, and the game is oozing with character and charm. These dwarves are like if the Discworld dwarves were in a sci-fi setting.

That's to say nothing of the enormous and hugely dedicated modding community that will likely keep this game alive forever...

If I had to have a complaint, I'd say it's just one that's endemic to all games with procedural generation. While it works in the context of DRG (adding to the feeling of an unexplored frontier and how caves aren't meant for human navigation) it does mean some levels can end up a complete mess made with spite in mind. Don't even get me started on the fossil objectives...

Nonetheless, I have had a grand time with this game. Absolutely recommended.

This game is a blast with friends or with other people online. But if you cant commit to long periods of time or do not feel like playing with others, the solo mode is damn fun too! Most of my 250+ hours have been alone with Bosco, your friendly drone. He can mine, carry things and light up the caves. It really gives a lot of flexibility and helps to make all 4 of the classes feel well-rounded while playing alone. Also playing alone lets you pause your mission without any worries. Really comes in handy if you find yourself needing to venture away from your PC frequently. 

If you want to explore lots of really cool generated cave systems that seem to stay fresh even after hundreds of missions, shoot lots of bugs, and collect tons of gold; then I would definitely give this game a try.

This game is a fantastic game to just hop in with friends or even to just hop into quickplay with randoms, and that's something rare nowadays. For those that haven't played it, lemme break down how things work in your average gameplay loop:

-Pick mission
-Buy beer (this is not optional)
-Drink beer (Also not optional)
-Go into the drop pod to be dumped in a cave system deep below the surface
-Mine resources, set up pipelines, recover equipment, or something similar, all while bugs try to eat you
-Kill bugs (You guessed it, not optional)
-Complete the objective
-Haul ass back to the Drop Pod for escape
-Buy celebratory beer before doing it all over again

Going deeper into how the game works:

-Players have four classes to choose from, and can have as many or as few of the same class as they like (I once had a team of all drillers and it was a chaotic blast to play).
-Each class provides their own unique playstyle and team benefit in a lineup. Scout is highly mobile and is able to help complete objectives quickly thanks to his grappling hook, as well a being able to light up entire caves, Gunner obviously provides heavy firepower and allows his team to traverse across chasms thanks to his zipline. Driller can tunnel through walls or create enclosed bunkers to funnel enemies into a chokepoint thanks to his drills, and Engineer provides fire support with his turrets. 
-Each mission takes place in a procedurally generated biome, so no two missions will have a cave layout that's exactly alike. Expeditions can be long or short, or somewhere in between, with some missions taking place entirely in one cavern and others that will have you trekking through snaking tunnels that lead you far from the drop pod, making your escape more frantic at the end.
-Biomes also determine what kinds of fauna you may encounter in the area, as well as helping you determine your loadout to take for the mission. For instance, the Driller's Cryo Cannon might be a great weapon, but it's probably not as good of a pick to take into the ice-filled Glacial Strata, so you might consider taking the Flamethrower instead.
-Certain beers provide functional benefits for your team (This is why buying them is not optional) while also getting your character wasted.

In addition to the gameplay being fun as hell, the community and Developers are straight up some of the coolest folks you'll run into. The Devs are openly transparent about the direction the game is going, constantly puts out updates and new seasons, and willingly listens to community feedback to give them what they want. The community is super friendly and is always willing to lend a hand to greenbeards that are just starting out. In all the years this game has been active, it's shocking how few toxic people I've run into over the course of playing it. Everyone is chill as hell and wants to goof around as much as the next guy.

All in all, if you're looking for a fun game that has a live service model actually done *well,* with an active and friendly community, all while playing as a Space Dwarf in a mining corporation, then this game is for you.

I don't feel it is an exaggeration to say that Deep Rock is one of the greatest games ever made. There is no better cooperative team-based shooter on the market right now. 

The guns feel amazing, builds are fun to try out and play with because everything is so well balanced, each class feels incredibly distinct and complement each other well (engineer placing platforms under mineral veins so scouts can grapple up to them being the most obvious example), the devs are the opposite of predatory, frequently releasing FREE content updates and season passes and events. They let you get the cosmetic items from last year's holiday events the next year. The game is polished to a sheen, with every action and every menu being slick as hell. 

Perhaps most impressively is the random generation of the caves. Each mission feels so unique because of it. It just works SO well. 

Difficulty options are perfectly tuned. Depending on what you want this game can be a very chill, relaxing time, something to play while listening to a podcast. Or it can be genuinely brutal and heart-pumping. 

But most importantly is it's just FUN. Every single moment of this game is fun. Nothing feels like work, or a chore, or an annoyance. Every single interaction from mining to shooting to throwing various quest items or minerals around is FUN. It's one of the few games where I don't really care if what I'm doing is giving me some kind of meta progression or not, because the simple act of playing the game is so fun. I'm actually...enjoying playing the game simply for the sake of playing it. Which feels like a WILD concept in 2024 when everything is live service or has a season pass or even if it's single-player it has loot and RPG systems and character progression. It feels like every game is trying to find a better carrot to put on the stick to keep you walking, but Deep Rock throws the carrot in the trash and instead crafts a beautiful hiking trail that makes you WANT to walk through it so you can enjoy the scenery.

It's a very solid Co-Op game with a very good community... in North America.

the South American playerbase is almost non-existant, and the few ones still out there are just Toxic.

Deep Rock is one of the best coop survival games I've played in awhile. The teamwork aspect comes together very well, and diversifying the team really makes a difference, with each having their own abilities to bring forward. The promise of future updates and additional content with planned release dates is reassuring. I'm looking forward to the next update!

Warning: There are 2 versions of this game: Steam and Microsoft store. The Microsoft version can crossplatform with Xbox One, while the Steam version can't, but the Steam version seems to be more stable.... so hopefully there will be a compromise in the future.

I am a 45 yo father, probably one of the oldest people playing this game. I am a single father to my Son, who is 14 now. My son got this game for Christmas in 2021 from his uncle, so we installed it on his computer and he started playing. By the end of the week he had 24 hours on this game. This was horrible for me, as it was already hard for me to find ways to spend time with my son, as he is always out with his friends or just watching YouTube. So i decided to make a Steam account and get this game to see if I could maybe play alongside him. I loaded into the game, picked my character and started playing but I was stuck on what you where supposed to do. I asked my Son for help and he hosted a game for me to join. I loved it as it was the best time I had spent with my Son since my wife had died. This game has ever since brought me and my son closer again and now we actually spend time together outside the house together as well. This game reminded me that there's fun to be had in everything, and it has brought both me and my Son many happy memories.

One of the best games in my list. The objectives are varied and even though you play the same objectives a lot it rarely feels repetitive. The caves are randomly generated but takes different factors into account like the biome you go to or the objective you have. but no cave is really predictable. But at the same time even a team of randoms has enough direction to have succesfull dives on the highest difficulties. 

The 4 classes you play are very easy to pick up on. Scout, Engineer, Driller and Gunner. All of the titles explain their job. But gameplay is different with any player. Based on all the upgrades and as endgame someting called overclocks. wich get after you promoted one of your classes. You can do this after you leveled that class to 25. So you level these classes seperately. 

If you dont want to communicate much you can still have very high difficulty awesome missions because the objectives are clear, you can point out things to other players and loudly announce you did so, regular text chat and you can always see player outlines and objective markers. You can do this by setting your Laser pointer key to "toggle" instead of "hold", then press ctrl for the laser pointer, and then swapping to your main weapon. Now you have player outlines and objective markers permanently.

Oh and free cosmetic-only battle pass, and no shitty micro transaction store with xp boosts or any of that sh*t

However, I cannot recommend this game if you have any other people or devices sharing wifi with you. I cannot remember how many I time I lost connection when doing deep dive elite.

I checked the task manager and closed all the other apps, and turn out to be the host need consistent 300kbps send and 600kbps receive to keep another 3 players online, which is kind of needy. Also, players usually get disconnected during evac or beginning. The connectivity issue is so severe that I have to host every time. I got disconnected in five games in half an hour, which literally means I wasted half of an hour doing nothing. 

The worst thing is there is no option of retry or server history, so if you are lucky enough you may pick up where you have left. Probably next time we should have a wifi or internet hardware benchmark hierarchy in the PC master race. The consumer grade wifi can only hold extra two players if signal is good.

After having put in hundreds of hours into Deep Rock Galactic (DRG), plus TONS of other games in the same genre, I'll tell you EXACTLY why this game stands out.

Since Left4Dead 2 invented the genre we can call "Horde Shooters," games in this genre must come up with unique game mechanics to stand out. You have stuff like the zombie wall-scaling (and class-levelling) of World War Z: Aftermath, and the D&D-like fantasy vibe of Warhammer: Vermintide 2, full of ammo & magic.

So what exactly is it that makes DRG so special? Is it the charm of the dwarves? Is it the interesting weapons you can pick up? Is it the digging mechanic? The challenging difficulty? The variety? All of those help, but they are not the real hero of the game.

The hero of DRG is: The randomly-generated levels.

No other game in this genre has this level of randomization, including the masterpiece L4D2, which instead has a still-vibrant community of modders, creating new levels. But once you've played a level, the familiarity somewhat kills the novelty.

The reason randomization is so important is because you will NEVER have the same map twice, making every mission feel unique. Once you've played through other horde shooters, they tend to feel repetitive once you know exactly where to go. Clocking in at almost 300 hours at the time of this review, I can say this: I'm still not bored.

I'm sure the other reviews discuss other great aspects to it, like the random side-missions that you can optionally complete, the variety of biomes and assignments that you can choose, the different guns you can equip to fit your play-style, etc. Look, there's a lot to love in this game.

But the real reason why you can keep coming back is that once you start getting really good at the game, you can always rely on the fact that you'll find challenges in the randomized maps to fit whatever difficulty level you're willing to play on.

The bottom line: This game is a phenomenal achievement of game development, and has some of the best replay value of any game I've ever played.

Good Coop-Fun. There are 4 classes that complement each other. Missions in proceduraly generated tunnel-maps.

This is one of the few games that I will call a genuine passion-project. The concept has been done, but DRG manages to be the best-in-class and it isn't even close. Maps are proceduraly generated so that no 2 caves will ever be the same, even in the same biomes. Better yet, once you buy the game then everything is yours. The season pass is free, all cosmetics roll over into the random loot pool, and there isn't a single micro-transaction. You can't buy progress, you don't need to dump everything you own for a single upgrade, and the supporter DLC's are well made and genuinely creative. The characters have fun personalities, the theme is perfect for the narrative, and all 4 of the classes play completely different from one another. At this moment each has 3 primary, 3 secondary, and 2 movement tools which are completely unique and exclusive to each of the classes. DRG is proof that games can be fun again.

Deep Rock Galactic : By Triple F

If you've ever dreamt of delving into the inky depths of the cosmos, surrounded by towering alien caves, and battling hordes of extraterrestrial foes, then "Deep Rock Galactic" is the game you've been waiting for. Brace yourself, miners, because this game is an interstellar gem that will have you hooked from the very first plunge.

From the moment you step into the boots of a brave Dwarven space miner, you're thrust into a universe that's both mesmerizing and treacherous. The game's visual aesthetics are nothing short of breathtaking; the dark, mysterious caverns of alien planets are beautifully rendered, and the soft glow of minerals and crystals give an otherworldly ambiance that's hard to resist.

What truly sets "Deep Rock Galactic" apart, however, is its ingenious blend of cooperative game-play and strategic depth. You and up to three other players form a team of badass miners, each with unique skills and abilities, to tackle procedurally generated missions beneath the planet's surface. The camaraderie that develops as you work together to navigate the twisting tunnels, mine precious resources, and fend off relentless waves of alien creatures is unlike anything else in the gaming world.

The class system in the game is a stroke of genius. Whether you choose to be the stoic Driller, the agile Scout, the sturdy Gunner, or the explosive Engineer, your role in the team is crucial, and teamwork is paramount. It's like a deadly ballet of teamwork and destruction, where everyone has to play their part to survive. The way you combine your skills and adapt to the ever-changing environments keeps the game-play fresh and challenging.

"Deep Rock Galactic" is, at its core, an adrenaline-pumping, edge-of-your-seat experience. The swarm encounters are heart-pounding, the boss battles are epic in scale, and the sense of accomplishment when you and your team overcome these challenges is immensely rewarding. The thrill of setting up elaborate defenses and mowing down wave after wave of enemies with your trusty weaponry is intoxicating.

But it's not just about blasting aliens and mining minerals. The game has a surprisingly deep progression system, with character upgrades, weapon mods, and cosmetic options that give you plenty of reasons to keep coming back. The developers have done an outstanding job of providing a continuous sense of achievement, ensuring that every mission feels like a step forward in your galactic career.

And let's not forget about the game's sound design. The echoing caverns, the menacing growls of alien creatures, the thunderous boom of your weapons – it all adds up to an immersive audio experience that further enhances the game's atmospheric brilliance.

To top it all off, the developers at Ghost Ship Games have proven themselves to be masters of community engagement. They actively listen to player feedback, consistently release updates and new content, and host special in-game events, all of which contribute to the sense of belonging to a thriving, passionate player community.

In conclusion, "Deep Rock Galactic" is an interstellar masterpiece. It's a game that combines stunning visuals, intense cooperative game-play, strategic depth, and an incredibly welcoming community. Whether you're a seasoned miner or new to the depths of space, this game offers an unforgettable experience that will keep you coming back for more. So grab your pickaxe, rev up your drill, and prepare to embark on a journey through the cosmos like no other. "Deep Rock Galactic" is the ultimate space mining adventure you've been waiting for. Happy mining, fellow Dwarves!

My major issue with the game is that, when you get disconnected, there's no in-game prompt to reconnect to your last match; it just boots you out and sends you to the hub. I assumed that this meant that reconnecting to a dropped session was impossible, because I found several threads and discord comments complaining about the same issue, and no one suggested simply going into your Steam friends list and clicking "Join Game" again, which is what ended up working for me. I still find it very odd that, when your game crashes, you DO get an in-game prompt to reconnect; they just failed to implement it for regular disconnects, which resulted in a lot of frustration after some particularly long missions ended in failure because of connection issues. 

After about 100 hours I can definitely say that this game has staying power if you are playing with friends. Pathfinding and gathering minerals is relaxing, and since I've only focused on upgrading one class (Gunner) I haven't ever been short on resources or credits. Resources are rare and varied enough that I don't get tired of mining them, and there is a nice flow between gathering them and fighting waves of enemies.

Every class comes with a fairly interesting kit, and the starter guns are more than adequate, to the point where, most of the time, weapon choice is purely a matter of preference. Things change when you get into the higher difficulties and you're choosing specific loadouts according to mission types. Most main weapons have a secondary weapon they pair very well with. Which upgrades you choose can largely depend on which bugs have been fixed. If you are playing casually though, there's not really any drawback to choosing what you think is the most interesting. 

In my opinion, the only "essential" class is Driller. I would probably list the class priority list as Driller > Gunner > Engineer > Scout.  While I'm sure higher skill players do just as well as the Engineer or Scout, the Driller I usually play with has gotten us out of more tense scrapes than I think any of the other classes could deal with. Being able to simply drill through solid rock straight to an objective turns an impossible mission into a merely difficult one. While I personally prefer to play as Gunner, if you are playing solo you have the option of taking the autonomous drone Bosco, who is essentially a mini-Gunner. He can even mine for you, so the hard-to-reach ceiling minerals become an afterthought. 

The most frustrating part of the game, apart from connection issues, is fall damage. It's very easy to slip or get knocked off a precarious platform and plummet into a chasm you didn't even know was there, and for your team-mate to take a tumble into that same chasm trying to save you. It's much less frustrating with the "Bosco in multiplayer" mod, since he can revive you, so I would recommend grabbing that. But it speaks to the fact that this game was REALLY designed to be played with a full party of 4, and if you are playing with less than that, you are putting yourself at a significant disadvantage. Especially if the person you are playing with is not particularly skilled with shooters. *cough*

Speaking of mods, even though there aren't a ton for this game, a few key ones are definitely worth picking up, especially for casual players. The aforementioned Bosco mod is extremely useful, as is the upgraded Doretta (drilldozer) mod that helps with defending a stationary target at higher difficulties. My team-mate was constantly complaining about how dark the game was, until we downloaded the improved flashlight mod. They still throw flares like they're 20's at the club, so I don't think the overall intended experience was ruined, but the complaining definitely stopped. 

Overall, DRG has an almost perfect balance between relaxing resource gathering and challenging combat. It's the only game I've continued to play almost daily since I downloaded it, despite its frustrating flaws. I'm rarely ever bored despite the gameplay loop being fairly simple. I wouldn't play it on my own, but with friends it's a 9/10.

The game forces it's players to grind for upgrades and unlocks by completing a assignment which boils down to a random selection of 3-6 missions which are chosen from 8 different gamemodes and 10 different zones. This feels pretty bad because the player is locked out of the game's content simply by having to play it for a unnecessary long amount of time, and by that point it starts getting repetitive. Additionally there are overclocks which modify the weapon in a minor or significant way. Which suffer from the same issues. Game feels pretty laggy to play even with mods that increase fps especially with 4 people which is counterintuitive because is more fun with in a co-op. Other than that it's a pretty good co-op game but you can play it alone.

Best 4 players co-op game ever made, Rock and Stone brothers !

The dwarves on the Deep Rock Galactic space rig are gathered at the Abyssal bar, chugging down a round or two of their favourite beers. Sharing stories and highlights of their latest assignments in the dark caves on Hoxxes IV, a dangerous planet full of minerals and biomes. Biomes are where the missions take place, and range from galactic salt mines to radioactive tunnels, infested by various swarms of alien arachnids called Glyphids. The Drop pods were getting ready for launch and our miners for a Elite Deep Dive. Ziplines, drills, flares and of course, a faithful pick axe, the team was locked n loaded with heavy fire power in order to make it back alive from the depths. Management gave the last call for everybody to get on board, fearing the worst for their experienced miners and expensive equipment. A lot of green beards have been joining the ranks of DRG, but only the best squads goes to work and gives hell to the aliens of Hoxxes IV. Humming their favourite song, ROCK and STONE !

Wonderful co-op experience with four unique dwarfs to choose from to match your own style of game play. Each and every class synergies amazingly with each other to pull the darkest of situations into a successful mission. The community is quite welcoming and over the top friendly.

No in game purchases to be seen with the only exception to the DLCs that only provide cosmetics. Along with the fact that the battle pass is also free and that all cosmetics can always be found if you miss out on it. 

The replay-ability is just perfect. Special events, different biomes with their own unique world generation and terrain, mission hazards, missions themselves, and finally enough different enemy wave encounters. It's not even close to being stale or dull.

So grab your gear and sharpen your pickaxes,

[h1] The New Most Fun You Can Have Online [/h1]

The Gist: You are a dwarf that works for the titular mining company Deep Rock Galactic. In addition to whacking mineral veins with a pickaxe to harvest them, you also shoot monstrous bugs.

The Good
- There's a decent variety of weapons to choose from, and with lots of mods for each one, there's virtually endless styles of combat.
- The sound design is amazing, making you feel like something could be lurking around every corner.
- There's a surprising amount of humor, typically at the expense of Mission Control.
- The graphics are decent, but the presence of darkness and the need for illumination is actually really immersive and an overall nice touch.
- This game scratches the itch you never knew you had of having to smash mineral deposits and pick up the fallen pieces. 

The Bad
- All four classes of dwarf have more or less the exact same voice, with only the pitch changed for each one. It seems kinda lazy, but it's probably a budget and manpower issue, so I can let that slide.

Pro Tip: When playing with others, ask or respond to others with a simple "R." For example, once the mission quota has been met and the M.U.L.E. can call the drop pod (if the M.U.L.E. is present; it isn't always), type "R?" and if everybody responds with "R", press that button and make a mad dash for the pod.
