[h1]⭐ Game Rating: 9.6 / 10 ⭐[/h1]

Deep Rock Galactic - An amazing, fun, unique game for a cheap price.

Overall thoughts on the game aspects:
-----------------------------------------------------------

Graphics - 9.5/10 , The best poly-type game to give the most immersive graphics you could get with such poly-type rendering

Gameplay - 10/10 , Gives you the true experience and feel of being an actual miner in an alien rock in space, literally

Weapons and variety - 8/10 , unique weapons for each class, just wish there was a few more options.

Atmosphere - 10/10 , Stunning lighting effects.

Price - Worth the full price but buy on sale
-----------------------------------------------------------

Overall, 9.6/10 game, highly addicting and insanely fun with other players. ROCK AND STONE!

Hillarious game, its a must buy if you like co-op games.
I've been looking for fun coop games for a while, and played things like Aliens Fireteam Elite or Killing Floor, its all ok, but Deep Rock Galactic has just way more variety to it. With all the different mission types, classes that have very diverse abilities, the procedurally generated maps, etc.
It can be played for relaxation, just mining some shiny minerals at lower difficulties, or really challenging in other missions, its such a versatile game.
I was at first hesitant because the graphics looked a bit ugly in the videos, but once you get used to its actually all quite pretty, sometimes those huge caves even look amazing.
Good, wholesome, fun.

Great fun with friends, great fun while solo (with bosco). Opportunities to play how you want. No timers on missions allows you to just explore and mine anything/everything. Once you meet the objective, you choose when to start the end sequence. However, you can also choose to just rush the objectives if speedrunning is your thing. Combat is fun, and you choose the difficulty of the mission (and experience is mostly proportional). Interesting and unique maps. Enemies are relatively simple, but the encounters (types and amount of enemies, the landscape) can make every fight unique. Optimizing armor and perks (and fashion) is enjoyable and rewarding.

[h1][b] TLDR: A fun 4-player coop mining adventure with memey dwarves. I expected more from this. It’s not bad, but the repetitiveness leaves something desired. [/b] [/h1]

[b]Genre/Similar Games: a 3D Terraria with dwarves? Left 4 Dead underground and mining and bugs instead of zombies? Yeah, those work. [/b]

[h1]PROS: [/h1]
✅Cooperative experience can be fun, especially when all unique abilities mesh together

[h1]CONS: [/h1]
➖Mostly boring perks lead to lack of build diversity in the name of balance
➖Grinding for cosmetics…who cares? 
➖Not a lot of incentive for solo players

[h1] [b] Content (Game world/Narrative/Lore/Length/P2W/Mods) – [7/10] [/b] [/h1]
In Deep Rock Galactic (DRG), you play as one of 4 classes of dwarf – Driller, Gunner, Engineer, or Scout. You enter a procedurally generated (RNG) cave system to complete a mission. Missions range from things like collecting a specific type of item like ore or alien eggs, to recovering equipment, to killing a big enemy. I noticed about 4 or 5 different types of missions (mine, recovery, kill, collect…).
The game world is split into 2 main parts – your ship, i.e hub, and the mining locale. Since each mining location is unique and different, the ship will remain the only consistent location in the game. 

The narrative is almost non-existent. You are simply an employee of the company Deep Rock Galactic. You take orders from the same “Narrator” dwarf whom is considered management. 
I put in about 20 hours as of this review. This is one of those games that can be an infinite loop if you enjoy it enough. 

There is no P2W here, but tons of cosmetics available to purchase. 

There is also mods available. I did not choose to use any, but I did like how there are two lists of mods – officially accepted and everything else. Since this is largely a coop game, there are modded lobbies you have the option of joining. These lobbies, which are filterable, allow officially accepted mods, all mods, or no mods. 

Overall, DRG has tons of content, if you find it enjoyable is the question. 
[h1][b] Gameplay (Controls/Mechanics/Loop/Difficulty/Bugs) – [7/10] [/b] [/h1]
The gameplay in DRG is good, all the classes are very balanced and control as well as any FPS on the market. 

Mechanically, each class has a variety of their own guns and equipment that make navigating the caves easier. Drillers are exceptional at drilling huge caverns, Gunners have ziplines, Engineers have shootable platforms, and Scouts have a flare gun and a grappling hook. You also have some perks which adds some small passive bonuses to the gameplay. Due to balance being so tight, there isn’t a lot of room to do anything truly unique. Perks like 30% less elemental damage, or run 10% faster after sprinting for 5 seconds, or insta-revive once per match. These are nice, but I’m not seeing the ability to build some really cool things here. 

The general gameplay loop consists of choosing your buildout from guns, perks, class, and if solo, your robot Bosco, then launching into a random cave to complete the mission. Once inside the cave you must endure waves of enemies while you move to complete your objective. You normally have about 1-2 optional objectives to complete, as well as 1-2 hidden objectives like a tower or chest key event. Each match takes somewhere between 15-45 minutes. 

As for difficulty, this is measured in hazard level. It’s generally considered something like:
haz 1 = literally for children
haz 2 = new to FPS or just learning DRG
haz 3 = good for grinding in the beginning levels
haz 4 = main choice after you are familiar with the game and confident in your abilities
haz 5 = professional players only, ridic bullet spongy enemies 

I played mostly on haz3-4. I felt that the difficulty can be wildly inconsistent. There were times when I died 10x on haz 3, then no wipes in haz 4. 
Lastly, for bugs, I did encounter some (pun not intended since the main enemy type in this game ARE bugs). There are sooo many cases where enemies are able to hit you from underneath a platform and you are literally unable to damage them because they are inside the indestructible terrain (mining platform). This lead to many deaths that should have been preventable by the mining platform’s auto guns shooting the enemies before they got there. 

[h1] [b] Graphics (Quality/Art style/Animations/UI/Performance) – [6/10] [/b] [/h1]
Probably due to the procedural nature of the caves, but for the most part, the graphics are not that great, even with everything maxed the inside of a mineshaft can only look so visually impressive, but DRG takes it a few steps even lower. 
If every environment was made like your ship was made, I would probably give this a 7, but the ship is the only thing that was immaculately designed. The art style from all the clutter is great and feels like a lived-in vessel. 

Animations are okay – nothing exemplary but serviceable. 

The UI is good. I feel like one of the devs learned how to program certain things on in-game monitors and threw them EVERYWHERE because they thought it was cool. I do need to call out my hatred for the class colors. Driller is yellow, Gunner is green, Scout is blue, and Engineer is red. Well, it so happens that when a player is downed their class icon changes to flashing RED. This has annoyed me so much when I have engineers in my party, and I glance to see where they are in the cave, I always end up thinking they are down. OR the opposite, I see a red icon and think they are an engineer, then need to look at the health bars. C’mon, there are more than 5 colors here. 

Performance is great, no complaints. I played on my desktop and got a consistent 120 FPS. My rig is:
i9-13900KF | RTX 4090 | 64GB RAM | 1440p @ 240hz | installed on SSD
[h1] [b] Audio (Sound Effects/Music/Voice Acting/Ambient) – [6/10] [/b] [/h1]
ROCK AND STONE! Yeah, this section is hard-carried by the hilarious things the dwarves say. 
The sound effects are good, but aside from the digging of enemies, they are almost completely silent. I want to hear them walking towards me, or grinding their fangs, something! 

The music is limited and/or boring. 

Voice acting is on point and great. 

Ambient is not even noticeable, which is a shame. Game really fails on the immersive aspect and instead focuses on the coop play. 

[h1] [b] Replay Factor (Side quests/NG+/Player Choice) – [8/10] [/b] [/h1]
There is tons of replayability here in DRG. The game is pretty much a gigantic side quest. There is no clear main mission, as you’re just an employee at work. There are multiple areas, each with their own objective and each under constant different effects that alternate missions. I can see this having near infinite replay value and for the cost of the game, it’s a great deal. 

NG+ isn’t a thing. 

No player choice other than what type of match to do. 

[h1] [b] Final Verdict – [7/10] [/b] [/h1]
The core part of DRG is built around cooperative play, and while there is some RPG elements and options for builds, those exist only to provide the player with minimal choices as you happily mine planets forever. It has a lot of heart (and stone), but I can’t help feeling that I want more from DRG, just like Left 4 Dead. After you experience 20 hours of the game you’ve seen pretty much everything there is to see, so what’s to keep people playing? I would reckon on having a static party of friends to liven the experience, but that can be said about most coop games, so I try not to use that as [i] the [/i] determining factor, after all, not everyone has 3 pocket friends to play with at any given time. 

[h1] [b] Recommend? [Y/N] [/b] [/h1]
[h1]Yes [/h1]
While not entirely for me, the content you get for $10 on DRG’s every month or two sale (https://isthereanydeal.com/game/deeprockgalactic/history/) is definitely worth it. 
You can find my curator page here: https://steamcommunity.com/groups/SynikGR

The 2nd best co-op hordes fighting game (after Vermintide 2).
Every pieces of this game works perfectly together: the class, the weapons, the lobby, the art-styles... 30 mins in and you feel like you entered a big universe with a rich lore which is impressive considering there is almost nothing apart from the lobby and the gameplay itself.

The missions are realy different from one another and while you mostly end-up slaughtering lots of bugs and a few bosses here and there, the freedom you have on each run is always compelling.
If you feel comfortable, you can stay and mine as much ore as your dwarven eyes can lay upon, but if you struggle with ammo, you might want to get out as soon as you've done the main objective.

The randomness in map generation is realy fine tuned and even replaying the same mission always give a different vibe.

Difficulty is also modular, going from a walk in the park to a hardcore trail in hell, depending on what you want, but fun is to be had whatever you pick.

4/5 Enjoyable game. I wouldn't say it's the most fun I have had, but I can see why so many people love it.

I've been playing this for a couple of weeks now.
Not what I expected at first, but, better.

You are basically a Dwarf working for an interstellar mining corporation known as Deep Rock Galactic. Your crew is based in an orbital mining rig above the planet Hoxxes. Players select missions and are deployed to beneath the planet's surface in a giant drill pod. You the make your way through the tunnels and caverns, occasionally creating tunnels of your own, until you find what the company sent you in for. Usually some sort of valuable mineral, alien eggs, or even some lost equipment. Once you complete the objectives, a drop pod is sent for you, and it's a race against time to get to it before it leaves.
All the while you must be wary of the Glyphids - arachnid like creatures that inhabit Hoxxes, and are extremely aggressive. Don't worry though, you are well equipped to handle them with a variety of firearms and explosive weapons.
On the way, you can find other items and minerals. Some are secondary objectives for which you earn a bonus at the end of the mission, others are just there, and you can freely take them. These can be used to get money or as materials for upgrading your equipment.

There are 4 classes: Scout, Engineer, Driller and Gunner. Each has a unique set of weapons and equipment. You can do everything that a mission requires with any class, but each class is vastly superior in a certain aspect. For instance, the Gunner has a powerful heavy automatic weapon that is good for firefights, while the Driller has heavy duty mining drills that allow it to dig much faster. The player can switch between classes prior to beginning a mission, but are locked in once it starts. 

There are also a large number of perks that you unlock by completing milestones. I won't go into them all because there are a ton. 
Given the number of available perks, I can see there being a massive volume of different character builds.

I will note that I have been playing solo exclusively. This makes things a bit harder, especially on some of the longer mission types (ie. Onsite refining) but as long as you bring the right kit for the job, it's doable. Even if you don't bring the right kit, it's still doable, it'll just take a lot longer. I was initially put off by this, but after trying a different approach, I got the hang of it. The game is definitely balanced with multiplayer co-op in mind, and up to 4 players can go on a drop at a time. Luckily, solo players get a handy drone that watches your back, shoots enemies, mines hard to reach minerals and can be equipped with a rocket launcher. Not quite as good as a friend, but it'll do.

Also, Fall damage is by far the greatest killer in this game. Watch your step; it's a LONG way down.

If I have one gripe, it's that there isn't much weapon variety. Each class has only 1 primary and secondary weapon to start with. Others can be unlocked when a character reaches level 10, but 18 hours in, I haven't gotten there yet. Then again, I have been switching between characters for variety's sake, so it's probably possible to get there quicker.

All in all, a really solid game. I'm certain that it's even better with friends.

[b]I'm pleased that I bought this game at a discount, but I regret purchasing it altogether.[/b]

It's not a bad game per se, but it becomes tedious and extinguishes any hope for more content quite fast. On the positive side, it's decent for wasting some time and playing with friends on a few occasions. It looks pretty in a few areas. All four classes are more or less fun to play, and that's about it. I can't see this game as anything more than a time-waster if you really have nothing else to do. The reason I kept playing was solely based on the hope that it would eventually get better. However, after playing for 150 hours, I still feel like the game exhausted itself after the 10-hour mark. After that, it was nothing but the same repetition of "clear the 1st cave level, drill into the other one, get the minerals, kill the bugs, return to the drop pod" – nothing more than that.

Objectives change with each mission, but the core gameplay is very bland and overly repetitive. The variety of bugs and weapons doesn't feel special; I've been using the same weapons that deal the most damage from the start until now for each class. Despite differences, they still don't give the feeling of any of them being special. Overclocks aren't fun to use either with a few exceptions (still doesn't matter, because every overclock you get is random).

The developers could've added way more content to make this game less shallow, like flooded caves with giant monsters three times the size of the caretaker, space battles with ship control, and forsaken ancient structures in the caves, etc. The game would've been way better if it were more horror-oriented, but I doubt they'll ever going to add any of this.

In terms of visuals, it looks rather ugly. I've been trying to figure out what it reminds me of and concluded it's like a weird mishmash of western comics, a neon-related look, and lots of chunks of other stuff. However it's one thing being unpleasant to look at and another when you can't tell what you're looking at. Spatial awareness in this game is terrible, and it has nothing to do with its lack of light but rather the developer's art style. Even when the cave is well-lit with no approaching bug swarm; it's generally hard to tell what you're seeing most of the time in terms of terrain or where you are standing. Every each biome with the exception of sandblasted corridors looks blurry. Just a few examples: 
https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=3133331964 
https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=3133332090
It's not that it's dark, it's that the color palette is too monotonous and everything looks too blurry.

The last thing I'd like to address is the community. To be frank, they're zealots. Anyone with any sort of criticism always gets trash-talked, with every issue you may have with the game resulting in a "git gud" or some other more passive-aggressive response from players and developers alike. They remind me of the source-game communities like that of TF2, so complaining about anything or wishing for a meaningful developement here is a waste of time.

Overall, the game really isn't worth its original price. You can play it, but it'll get boring rather fast, even with friends, and there won't be any new meaningful content for a long while. 

P.S. I'm sure that in this game, for most players and all developers, the whole "dwarf" setting is just a fetish.

The developers truly care about this game and the community is fantastic! And since the game is actually quite great thats enough to earn a recommendation in my book!

It is basically the retelling of the end of the Squats in the Warhammer 40k universe to the unnamed Tyranid splinter hive fleet that consumed their homeworlds in the 41st Millennium.. At least before they got reincarnated into the new dwarven AI-worhipers that they are nowadays. With this in mind the game is quite relatable and actually have a story to tell! Otherwise it is a fun take on a shooterfocused minecraft with dwarves digging after treasure on a treacherous planet.

Overall the core gameplay  is pretty fun but the fact that you have to grind up inventory means that you slowly unlock the equipment you need to progress further in the game. This can make it feel tedious to some, others might find value in this method of keeping players engaged. Also, I wish there was a way I wouldn't have to play as one of four burly dwarfs coded as men with more or less obnoxious voices.. Come on developers, its 2024, where are the equality? (and don't give me excuses about rigs/skeletons in a game that introduces new enemies with more and more abstract shapes..) Play it with friends (if you have those) and gallywant on epic raids after precious resources needed to fuel your capitalistic company spacegreed further. It is a Vermintideish game where the theme is switched from dark medieval fantasy to alien(the movie) infused sci-fi mixed with super motherload(the game) and dwarfs.

All in all an enjoyable game to pick up and play on odd moments, rock and stone included!

[h1]The only reason I'm not recommending this is because devs have no clue about balancing and forcing you to cooperate is their only solution to a completely broken end game.[/h1]
(But perhaps that's the point and they only care about farming money using support packs, who knows)

Mind that this is the second account I'm leveling up to the end game and it's the second time I'm deeply disappointed by how they handled Deep Rock's end game, which is always the same from season to season: there's no depth to difficulty and the meaning of difficulty never gets renewed in terms of challenge, missions become repetitive and boring, mechanics are always the same (sadly I'm not joking) and all that changes between higher levels is that swarms get progressively bigger and spawns are annoying - without your ammo or every other spawned resources following up, which makes soloing impossible in a long term unless you have the time to grind tirelessly through the [b]same cenarios over and over and over and over the whole week for at least 12 hours straight[/b].

Map generation is [b]awful[/b] to say the least, where half end game levels have a fucking screwed up layout as the sheer display of hiring someone to design things he/she doesn't have the bare minimum clue about. You're most probably sticking with a character who has some crazy mobility like Scout or some very good utility like Engineer or you probaby won't make it through the first 5 minutes of any intermediate to hard mission.

If you're a casual player who likes to stick with friends and do easy missions, go ahead and waste some time with this. Otherwise, it's way better to [b]avoid and go play something better[/b] like e.g Risk of Rain 2. It just becomes the same, a bullet hell where you just gotta survive but at least there you won't be stuck and hard nerfed by shit devs, depending solely on your skill/a bit of luck.

I don't mean to hate, as I love the game. Deep Rock is brilliant and stands out from almost everything in the store when the topic is multiplayer fun, but it is [b]broken at its core and devs aren't giving a shit nowadays about balancing or fixing issues, they just wanna make "battle passes" and events with boring recycled themes and mechanics.[/b] Being that the utmost and most painful fact that holds this gem down, it would be unfair telling someone to ignore everything else because shouting ROCK AND STONE nonstop at missions and laughing at friends being instakilled by supply drops is awesome. You [b]will[/b] be disappointed as soon as 50 hours (tops) hit and you realize you can only play with friends to make this work.
--
--
PS to all brainless fanboys in the review section: nope, Deep Rock devs doesn't deserve a Labor of Love award.

This game has charm, solid mechanics, and challenge, which are usually what win me over with any game that isn't story-based. 

The charm is in the art style, and the dwarves you play as having a real personality. With several voice lines and the funny memorable moments you can have "FOR KARL!" and "ROCK AND STONE!" I often find myself saying these lines in the real world with my friends who also play.

Solid mechanics, go into the deep with your other dwarf buddies to do a task for your mining corporation, seamlessly optimized and easy enough to run the game for even some old-ass PC's. Each mission has a similarity to others with variety in level generation, mission type, or unique modifiers. The mechanics of the game make that never go stale.

And the challenge, it comes in the deep dives. You just have to get far enough into the game to understand what I mean.

I did have fun playing DRG, but I think this game is still incredibly flawed and a little flat, which surprised me given it's overwhelmingly positive reception. After over a hundred hours of playing this game, I can say with absolute confidence that it is lacking content. You are introduced to the game by having to complete one of each mission type, which is a great way to start someone on a journey with proper expectations. The issue is that it doesn't scale into anything more grand, mechanically. There are just buffs and debuffs which make the same 10 missions more chaotic and difficult to handle. At some point, you will unlock Deep-dives, which may indicate that more diverse content and a deeper progression system should be locked behind it. No, this isn't the case either. Deep Dives are just a randomly selected three missions, out of the same 10 missions you've already done over and over, but with random debuffs and more bugs. 

This was really disappointing because you have to promote your dwarves to even unlock this feature (along with other side missions you can't participate in until you promote), only to do more of the same thing. This is a huge missed opportunity to have unique bosses and map layouts that deviate largely from the core 10 mission types, but could encourage the players to use the skills developed to overcome these weekly challenges.  


[b][i] Builds and Character Progression [/i][/b]

This part of the game is great, until you get to promotions, then it completely tapers off as there's no incentive to promote other than flexing how long you've been playing the game. All of the major playstyle changes come when you unlock passives on your armor, weapons, Pick-axe, robot helper and grenades. This is where the most fun in the game comes from, because all the features are new, your character is incomplete, and there is something significant to strive for. You feel the power of having 2 passives, and then 4 passives, etc, and start to establish a style for your gameplay. There are weapon alterations which you can make, but you won't have access to those until you've farmed some weeklies and deep dives post promotion. After promoting, there's nothing... Just empty levels, which don't reward you at all. No additional damage reduction, dmg dealt, enhanced passives or party buffs... Nothing that you would expect when you look at a player who has a 3-star gold promoted Dwarf, who then dies just as fast as you and outputs the same as you. This just doesn't make any sense to me. I recognize this is potentially design-space, which could be saved for a future update, but this game has been out almost 4 years at the time of writing and this studio is working a new project in the same world as DRG. 


[b][i] Customization [/i][/b]

This system is mostly good. I don't have a lot to say about the different cosmetics themselves, they are fun and interesting. My main criticism is actually regarding the way they are obtained. Each of the four dwarves have their own independent customization loadouts, but it's the same hairstyles, colors, armors, etc for each dwarf and you have to purchase them all separately. I think this is totally bullshit and could improved very easily. The full collection should be available to be used by any dwarf, just divide the cosmetic unlockables amongst the classes, so that there's an incentive to change classes. Like a mustache or a particular pair of chops? Well, you gotta play the Driller to get it or maybe the Engineer has a unique armor you want to unlock on your gunner. This facilitates each player spending some amount of time on each character and a proper reward for doing whatever the requirement is. Currently, it's just grind mats, buy hairline 1 on all 4 classes. Grind more mats, buy hairline 2 on all 4 classes, and that's awful.


[b][i] Music, Style and Charm [/i][/b]

This is where I honestly feel the game's identity is the strongest. The Jokes are funny, the characters are endearing, and the music when you're in the middle of the shit is freaking awesome. They've really captured the essence of a 9-5 job, and turned it into a game, which is hilarious and relatable!


[b][i] Closing Thoughts [/i][/b]

I had a unique experience with DRG, and there's a lot of things that are done right in this game. There's a lot of charm in this game, and it's clear that this project was loved by the Developers and it's community. Their seasonal pass is very generous and rewards effort over money. Their DLCs are reasonably priced. The game is fast-paced, and while is easy to get lost and very chaotic, it's still fun. But would I recommend it? Personally, no. I think the type of player who wants to play this game, knows who they are and will find this on their own. This is a an acquired-taste for sure, like black licorice.

Deep Rock Galactic would have been plenty fine regardless of gameplay purely for the fact that you can creatively replace the word "Rock" with one much funnier. But like that word, it stood out. I have thoroughly enjoyed and continue to enjoy playing it, no less for the fact that it lends itself to my theory, that you can fix every problem with violence. I'm absolutely buzzed when I get to act out my xenophobic inclinations on the inhabitants of another planet, purely for the fact that I categorize them as vermin from my past experiences. Each meaty shot to their domes brings about almost an orgasmic amount of excitement, as I only stop to say "tako jeee!", when "how is it", is the question. I've gotten so good at getting good, that now I'm great and still I have fun, for I can only be better than myself, and I am a worthy opponent. I play in a set way, build my two remote cheese grater towers, plop down a "PPPlatform" where I need go, and kill bugs the rest of the way. Man does not need much but hatred to make oneself happy. This is why I recommend DRG, and why you too, should play it.

This negative review is here as a form of protest. It will remain here until two things happen:

1) [strike]stingtails stop appearing with greater frequency than acid spitters AND are given an implementation that cannot slingshot you into insta-death on a hazard 1 mission.[/strike] With the battery of nerfs it has received, I can remove this complaint. It's still a very badly designed enemy for a lot of reasons, but at least new players are unlikely to get annihilated for no reason with no idea what killed them.

2) the godawful stain that is the rockpox spew and suck minigame is removed or sufficiently relegated so as to no longer be a meaningful addition to any mission. Whatever dumbf- idiot decided that a game about running around shooting bugs should instead be about not running and not shooting bugs should be banned from game design. Sure glad I collected all those overclocks that are now totally worthless as I use this POS vacuum cleaner to suck up a bunch of bubbles!

This used to be one of my favourite games. I could run missions for hours. Every part of it was fast-paced and engaging. These days, it feels like every mission is an endless chain of invulnerability phases, toxic zones, and death stuns. At this point, if I see a corrupter I just bail on the mission and close the game because I would have more fun watching Stockfish play chess than blow foam all over a giant sh- snail that takes 4000 minutes to kill.

I'm still gonna play the game, but I have to very carefully cherry pick my missions if I want to have any fun, and I can only do that because I have played it long enough to know exactly which missions are still fun. I genuinely don't recommend it to new players. There's just too much crap going on, too many overclocks to collect, too many things to unlock. I have no idea how you're supposed to catch up to someone that has hundreds of hours and has been playing since before season 1 even existed.

And as much as the positivity of the community is a boon, it's actually pretty toxic, because god forbid you complain about these things.

The worst part is, prior to season 4, I still would have recommended it. I feel incredibly sad to be writing this. It feels like my friend is slowly dying and there is nothing I can do except whine about it on the internet.

This game is fun. You should play it. It is more fun with friends, and even strangers. The devs did a really beautiful job of making the characters interact in a way that fosters good play.

They also say stuff that makes you laugh out loud. For example, while fighting for your life in a swarm of enormous spiders, the driller next to you will be heard to shout "god dammit, there's a pebble in my boot"

All the starter weapons are fun, which makes it really easy to enjoy the game at the start. There are no bad starter weapons that make you feel the need to grind for better ones. For example, the scout starts with an assault rifle and shotgun, and what a perfect combination that is. The driller has a flame thrower that you won't want to put down. The gunner's minigun is as satisfying as it is deadly.

Dwarven Delight: A Gem in Co-op Mining Madness!

Deep Rock Galactic is an absolute gem of a game that combines the thrill of cooperative gameplay with the satisfying chaos of dwarven mining expeditions. Despite my relatively short 4-hour playtime, I find myself compelled to share my initial impressions, as Deep Rock Galactic has already left a lasting impact on me.

Gameplay (5/5):
From the moment I stepped into the shoes of my trusty dwarven miner, I was hooked. The gameplay is a seamless blend of action, exploration, and strategic decision-making. The randomly generated caves ensure that each mission feels fresh and unpredictable, keeping the excitement levels high. The diversity of mission types, from point extraction to egg collection, adds a layer of variety that prevents the experience from ever feeling repetitive.

The heart of the game lies in its cooperative play. The synergy between the different dwarven classes—Gunner, Engineer, Driller, and Scout—is crucial for success. My limited playtime has already shown me that effective communication and teamwork are not just encouraged but absolutely essential for overcoming the challenges thrown at you. The sense of camaraderie and shared objectives elevates the experience to new heights.

Graphics and Atmosphere (4.5/5):
Deep Rock Galactic boasts a visually stunning underground world that captures the essence of a dwarven mining operation perfectly. The attention to detail in the caves, the lighting effects, and the distinctive character designs contribute to an immersive atmosphere. The game's aesthetic manages to be both charming and gritty, striking a balance that suits the theme of dwarven mining.

The dynamic lighting system deserves a special mention. As you traverse the dark, cavernous depths, the use of flares and the glow of precious minerals create an atmospheric tension that is both thrilling and beautiful. The game achieves a perfect blend of tension and excitement, especially when swarms of hostile creatures descend upon your team.

Progression and Customization (4/5):
Deep Rock Galactic offers a satisfying progression system that keeps you coming back for more. The ability to upgrade and customize your dwarf, both in terms of equipment and appearance, provides a sense of personalization. The variety of weapons, tools, and perks allows for different playstyles and strategies, adding a layer of depth to the overall experience.

However, I must admit that after only 4 hours, I have just scratched the surface of the progression system. It seems promising, but I look forward to exploring it further as I delve deeper into the game.

Community and Support (5/5):
One of the standout features of Deep Rock Galactic is the active and friendly community. Whether playing with friends or joining a random group, the community's cooperative spirit is infectious. The developers, Ghost Ship Games, have shown a commitment to the game with regular updates and engagement with the player base. It's evident that they genuinely care about the success and enjoyment of their creation.

Conclusion:
In my brief 4 hours with Deep Rock Galactic, I've found an engaging and thoroughly enjoyable cooperative experience. The game's blend of intense action, strategic teamwork, and dwarven charm has left a strong impression on me. With its promising progression system, stunning visuals, and an active community, Deep Rock Galactic is a must-play for anyone who enjoys cooperative games or just wants to embark on a thrilling mining adventure with a group of friends. I can't wait to see what the depths of Hoxxes have in store for me as I continue my journey with this delightful gem.

Genuinely speaking, I would really recommend this game. Whether you are a solo player or a person who likes to play coop games, this is the perfect game. I dont even know where to begin.

Solo game play is fun, immersive and you can get to really enjoy the game for its beauty. Or if you don't like solo, grab your friends. The games difficulty will scale and offers more of a challenge and reward for playing with more people. On top of that, if you don't have friends to play with you can always fall back on the community of Dwarves'.

"Leave No Dwarf Behind" is the motto of the game. This community is almost cult like and it makes it even more enjoyable. Are you down, in a hopeless situation? Your team is gonna fight tooth and nail to get you up and out on that drop pod or die with you. Are you unable to reach an ore needed for the mission? Just pull out your laser pointer and ping and someone will be right there to help.

I seriously recommend this game, especially if you are looking for a sense of comaraderie and something that is fun to pass time. It can be a little overwhelming at first but the amount of information you can get for this game whether from reddit or from those you play with, will ease that.

TL:DR: You will feel like you're not progressing at all at first, but then you realize you're 100 hours in. This game's trajectory is that of a parabola: it's slow at first but ramps up heavily at the end. 

Give it a chance. You will not regret it. Rock and Stone Greenbeard.

If you're here at this point, here is my honest review, and it's going to be long

TO THE DEVELOPERS: You have created my favorite game of all time, which has been previously held by Left 4 Dead 2! Thank you, from the bottom of my heart, not only for the simplicity, but for the sheer amount of community there is.

I started with a few friends, just to see this game through, and then my friends played offline more than I did, so it became a competition: who would get the highest first? And that only led me to love this game more and more. The four classes do not feel restricted, and the guns allow enough diversity that it does not matter what types of characters are in a party, and everyone can play whomever they want at any level, at any time. 

The guns are not restrictive as I originally thought, and the classes are more similar than I thought. 70 hours ago, I would've said that Scout has become my least favorite class. Now? He's played the last 40 of my 70 missions. I kid you not, PLAY. THIS. GAME.

You still doubt it? I would happily tell you hours upon hours of my favorite moments, of my favorite guns, and my favorite ways to play anything. Heck, I am finishing up video editing courses so I can MAKE CONTENT ABOUT MY LOVE FOR THIS GAME. I cannot wait to meet you all out on Hoxxess and Rock and Stone miners.

You're in for a ride.

This game is boring. After playing Role Playing Shooters consisting of enormous amounts of loot and game-changing skill trees, Deep Rock Galactic is simply not catching up. However, I'm writing this review as a total beginner and a solo player. I finished the beginner's assignments and did a couple of missions of my choice. As I said, I got bored... and frustrated. The rewards are displeasing. Perks give minor improvements rather than  introducing new movement/combat abilities... This is unsatisfactory. You just keep doing the same thing mission after mission, slowly grinding your way up just to get another minor boost. I can't recommend this game to solo players. Better install  one of the Borderlands games if you want to have fun. If you are a DRG veteran, however, feel free to write a comment and tell me what I'm missing (apart from friends willing to buy and play this game together).
I hate spiders

I've avoided DRG for some years because of p2p servers and no control over client modifications.
Would still prefer dedicated, controlled servers but player hosting and occasional cheaters indeed turned out to be much less of a problem than I thought it would be.

In regard to the gameplay, coop cave exploration/navigation is surprisingly enjoyable. Procedural level generation and classes with different builds provide variety. And I appreciate that DRG doesn't require time investment to get to the "real game", majority of the experience is opened pretty much from the start.

The game's very friendly monetization is often mentioned. All DLCs are cosmetic and, with plenty of comparable cosmetic available for free, could be seen more as an "voluntary donations"(with some DLCs marketed exactly like that).
I don't mind paying for continous game update/support and "single purchase is enough" doesn't excite me as much as it does many others but whatever works for the developers.

At the time of this review I had 173 hours in game, and in a lot of ways I feel I'm still just scratching the surface of this amazing game. DRG feels like an absolute labor of love, while the game can seem a little daunting to start, I quickly felt that I was able to understand what was going on. That being said I feel like I constantly learn something new while playing this game.

Solo or COOP I feel that I can play an endless amount of DRG, and so far I have been. This game is incredibly well balanced, and just about every build I've made is viable. Speaking of builds, there are thousands if not hundreds of thousands of possible unique builds. This on top of 4 different characters, each with 3 primary and 3 secondary weapons to choose from, makes for endless variety. As someone who enjoys switching playstyles frequently I feel like I still have thousands of hours of new playstyles and builds to use.

The possibility of nigh infinite build variety is further elevated by how fantastic the gunplay feels. On the highest difficulties you genuinely have to try at this game, and the tightness of the game feel makes that effort exhilarating.

DRG also has a very satisfying reward and progression system. Cosmetics, season pass, and materials for upgrades are all fantastic to provide something to work towards.

It's been a while since I was this addicted to a game, and I am so glad I took the plunge into this game.

In the heart of the mountains, where the shadows lie,
A tale of stout-hearted dwarves, beneath the sky.
With pickaxes and hammers, they carve through the stone,
In the caverns they dwell, in a world all their own.


Dwarves of the deep, with beards long and bold,
Legends untold, in the caverns they hold.
Mining for treasures, under moon and sun,
Dwarves united, a brotherhood begun.


Underneath the earth, where the jewels gleam,
Dwarven forges echo with a fiery theme.
Crafting the armor, forging the blade,
In the heart of the mountain, where secrets are laid.


Oh, the halls of stone, where the echoes ring,
A symphony of hammers, the anvils sing.
In the flickering torchlight, a tale unfolds,
Of dwarves so resilient, with hearts made of gold.


Dwarves of the deep, with beards long and bold,
Legends untold, in the caverns they hold.
Mining for treasures, under moon and sun,
Dwarves united, a brotherhood begun.

Through the dark tunnels, they march as one,
A fellowship strong, under the mountain's sun.
In the mines they toil, with a purpose clear,
Dwarves of the deep, free from doubt and fear.

Deep in their halls, where the ale flows free,
Dwarves raise their tankards in jubilant glee.
Songs of old, tales of the brave,
In the company of dwarves, memories they save.


Oh, the halls of stone, where the echoes ring,
A symphony of hammers, the anvils sing.
In the flickering torchlight, a tale unfolds,
Of dwarves so resilient, with hearts made of gold.

Dwarves of the deep, with beards long and bold,
Legends untold, in the caverns they hold.
Mining for treasures, under moon and sun,
Dwarves united, a brotherhood begun.

As the mountain stands, against time and tide,
The dwarves endure, with honor and pride.
In the depths they thrive, where the gems do gleam,
Dwarves of the deep, in the realm of a dream.

Deep Rock Galactic is one of the most well rounded FPS games out there. Though the genre itself is not huge (4P PvE FPS) I think DRG is easily the one game that got closest to L4D2 standards and even surpassed them. Showing the true amazing potential of this category. This game has near perfect gameplay and chemistry between players, it also has amazing developers that crafted a game for the players first, and passion second. Rather than most FPS games developed these days, made for profit first.

I think it's fair to start with the gameplay first. You are one of the four dwarves with unique load-outs and skills, you are dropped in a procedurally generated cave each time, your missions vary from mining out a specific ore, salvaging mini mules, or operating a machine such as defending the refinery or escorting a drilldozer. You are not alone in these caves, or rather this shattered scorched mineral rich planet. Bugs of various shape and form chase you down, climbing out of the soil. I will admit, unless you're playing a harder difficulty the types of bugs don't matter that much. But I think the true strength of the game lays in the chemistry between the four dwarf classes. Each one has unique abilities that help you throughout the game tremendously.

Now nothing is really stopping you from playing the same class, but playing a well rounded team with all four of the dwarves proves to be the most fun and functional way to play the game. The Scout's ability to use his grappling hook to reach places quickly, the Gunner's strong DPS, shield and zip-line, the Driller's ability to quickly drill away soil, and its above average fighting skills, and the Engineer's various gadgets such as the turret, and his platforms. All of these things compliment the team-play perfectly. The Scout is very useful during high stress clutch moments, with the ability to evade bugs quickly to get nitra (resupply currency) for his team. He is also useful to get to places most teammates can't get quickly to. The Driller's ability to dig through soil comes to use when drilling to the Drop Pod, or other objectives. You can even establish underground bunkers to survive bug swarms. The Gunner's ability is simple, yet powerful. He is the big tank, he shoots the big bullets and shreds through bugs, his shield is important when reviving downed teammates, or when you are in a pickle. His zip-line is also another useful movement gadget, especially if you are protecting a target. The Engineer's passive damage, and his platform gun pair well with the scouts movement.

While during lower difficulties you are simply growing accustomed to the game, when you start playing higher difficulties, bugs start to become a real problem. There is a lot of variants, big boys that spit out acid or freeze you, flying or walking spitters, things that can grab you and throw you around, or drop you from heights. There is also missions where you need to fight bosses, or robots. There is a lot of mission types, and they can be replayed many times, I won't mention each one but my favorites are definitely refinery and escort missions. Each involve protecting a target, and surviving waves of bugs coming at you. The refinery is especially fun on hard difficulties when you are scrambling to stay alive, preserve your ammo, and fixing the refinery itself. There is also other missions that are each very fun, but obviously some are better than others.

Another notable thing is that throughout the missions you go to, there is a chance you will come across other random missions, spicing up the game even more. There is also deep dives which you unlock as you level up, but in order to talk about those we first need to talk about perks and leveling up. Each mission you finish earns you in game cash, and XP. With XP you can unlock various perks and use up to five of them (three being passive and five being active) on your missions. You can also buy upgrades for your guns and gear, buy hundreds of different accessories (instead of paying real money for them) etc. In order to unlock different types of guns, and stations within the ship you need to pick up assignments. Which award you handsomely.

Now Deep Dives are just like regular missions, but deeper and more difficult. Especially Elite Deep Dives. Where you need to finish three missions consecutively. You need to ration your ammo, survive various hazards, and depend on each other. Until you are done with each mission and can return home. These missions earn you matrix cores and overlocks which you can use to even further upgrade your loadout. Though this part is usually controversial due to how grindy it can be.

I think that is all for the gameplay stuff I wanted to mention, it's time to quickly run through various stuff I enjoy about the game. It's well optimized, I never had frame issues with this game on the highest settings. The voice overs with mission control and between the dwarves can be hilarious. The amount of times me and my friends just kept pointing at a mushroom cuz of the funny voice lines is insane. Or the WE'RE RICH! The OST is phenomenal too, and the lobby... Good lord, I just love the lobby. Drink beer with your friends, kick barrels, piss off mission control. Dance on the dance floor, block your friends in their bedrooms. Try to clip out of the ship, find jetboots and fly to Hoxxes using them. Play the funny boot game and try to sabotage your friends, or just jump around.

 This game is an absolute masterpiece of passion and love. No microtransactions, no shitty policies, just pure old fun. This is what a game is supposed to be, so... ROCK AND STONE TO THE BONE!

Rock and Stone! But also, Rock and New Content, please!

DRG is where dwarves dig for gold, shout "Rock and Stone!" or "Mushroom!", and occasionally question their life choices while staring at the same cave missions for the 400th time. Don't get me wrong, blasting bugs and grappling through caverns with my bros is beard-strokingly good fun.

But after a while, the novelty of mining the same ol minerals and dodging the same ol critters starts to wear thin. It's like that feeling when you've memorized every line in your favorite movie - yeah, it's still a classic, but you wouldn't mind some fresh popcorn, am I right? We're practically dwarven archaeologists at this point, unearthing the same relics and fossils faster than Indiana Jones on a sugar rush.

So, the devs, bless their pointy ears, throw us a bone every now and then. New weapons, cosmetics, even the occasional biome shake-up. But let's be honest, it's like adding sprinkles to stale space cake. We crave a whole new bakery, a buffet of biomes, a smorgasbord of spooky crawlies to squish. Don't get me wrong, Deep Rock Galactic is still a blast, a guaranteed pick-me-up after a long day of not being a badass space dwarf. But like any good ale, it gets a little stale if you keep pouring from the same keg. Here's hoping the devs crack open a fresh one soon, because these pickaxes are itching for some uncharted rock!

I am a 44 year old father, probably one of the oldest people playing this game. I am a single father to my son, who is now 14. My son recently started this game and in less than a week, he had already played for over 20 hours. This was terrible for me, as it was already hard enough for me to spend time with my son, as he is always out with his friends or just watching videos on Tiktok. So I decided to make a Steam account and get this game to see if I could maybe play alongside him. I loaded into the game, did the tutorial but I was stuck on what you where supposed to do. I asked my Son for help and he hosted a game for me to join. I loved it as it was the best time I had spent with my Son since my wife had died. This game has ever since brought my son and I closer again and now we actually spend time together outside the house as well. This game reminded me that there's fun to be had in everything, and it has brought both me and my Son many happy memories.

This game has the best pve ive seen in any shooter, take notes overwatch. Diverse enemies in design and mechanics. There are: Medium walking bugs, three variants of them. Flying bugs, basic, armored, shotgun. Small bugs, walking and flying, all of them are very annoying. Big flying tank that spawns the small flying bugs. Two big walking bugs one tanky one very tanky, a nuke that chases you all the time until you kill it (its also tanky as hell). And that is not even all! There is more of this stuff everywhere. Off to the next topic, the environments are rich and alive, they look great. There is not a single region without its fans because they all are made with so much care and detail, Salt pit has the great combination of red and white. Crystal caverns... is there a person that thinks they DONT look excellent? You can see how much care the developers put into this game. And the weapons too, there are 10 equippable weapons for each class, four of which are grenades. All are extremely unique (maybe not the grenades at times though). With six weapons you can get upgrades to and overclocks it feels more like you have 30 or more. For now my favourite combo is the GK2 and Zhukov NUK with the embedded detonators overclock. I dont think i should say more about this game. Try it now, it is the highest quality (not just pve) shooter ive played.

This game is amazing, it's one of the if not the best coop games ever designed

I'll start this by making clear that this game is really less grindy, and the grind that it has it's really damn fun! a lot of types of missions + random maps? Hell yeah, and even the cave is your enemy, the cave won't make your life easier to get to the stuff you require.

Even if it seems complex at the start the game does a nice job guiding you, and you'll realise how simple the game really is, and you can always ask people around! This community is one of the least toxic ones (i ofc saw 1 toxic even if i had less than 10 hours, but let's be real.. toxicity will be anywhere).  Even if you find a toxic player your experience won't be really sour at all! Because of how this game is made it makes people be nicer and just work as a team.

Upgrades? I fucking love them! this is one of the few games that doesn't stress me to try to focus in the meta, most upgrades have their use, and you can do some strong or crazy loadouts with them, so yes any upgrade is better than having none.

Battlepass? damn it doesn't even matter if it ends! the cosmetics ain't gone, you can get them other times, even if it's slightly harder it's 10 times better than stressing your players by making them play for "exclusive" stuff, and after all they're cosmetics.

It's a really nice game and i hope it goes far, it offers a lot of replayability thanks to how it's designed, and the fact that they allow you to play on directx11.. it made me even more excited! 

Tip: if the game crashes try to launch on directx11 or safe mode, this usually fixes problems.

This is a pretty good game, I bought DRG back in the early access days and my >1300 hours of playtime speaks for itself. But the reason this review is marked Not recommended is that the game suffers from various issues, and I cannot in good conscience allow new players to buy in uninformed.

1. The game is very grindy. 

DRG relies on an absurd amount of loot RNG. Overclocks are your "keystone" equipment upgrades, but you can only loot them from a random pool. Do you play scout? Have a driller upgrade instead. Cosmetics are gated by the same system, but are even worse because they are split between three different loot pools. Matrix cores, lost backpacks and equipment crates have hundreds of possible drops and the chance of getting any particular item (ie, what you want) is miniscule. This is a grind that will take you months, possibly years for a more casual player and nothing has been done to alleviate it even as GSG piles more unlockables on top with each passing season.

2. The gameplay is very repetitive.

The basic gameplay of DRG has not changed much since the game was in early access. You dive into a cave, you mine minerals, you come back with the loot. What varies is the biome, the mission type, the enemies, the mutators etc. The pool of assets the map generator can pull from is pretty broad, but not as much you'd think. You will quickly start to recognize recurring elements, like "the spiral room", or "the vertical shaft", or "the salt cubes". The more you play the more things become rote and uninteresting because you've seen them so many times. If the game doesn't catch you within the first 2 hours of play I would recommend refunding and trying something else. What you see is what you get, the game does not expand much if at all, you just get more guns and hats to wear while you do the same content again.

3. The game doesn't respect the player's time.

When your dwarf gets a promotion to the next rank it used to be that you could just go to the class select terminal a few steps way from your bedroom spawn point and click a button to get promoted. Now you are forced to trudge all the way to the far end of the memorial hall every time, turning what should have been a point of pride into an irritation.

Sometimes when you try to join a lobby the last slot is filled by someone else just before you hit the button, in most other games this would just say "oops lobby full" and return you to the lobby browser to select a different mission. In DRG you get an error message, followed by a loading screen as the game forces you to respawn in your bedroom and run back over to the lobby browser before you can try again. There is a nearly identical error message called "UNKW Server Error" that does the same thing and you may encounter both of these multiple times per play session just for having the audacity to join a mission in progress.

A third example of this is crafting matrix cores at the forge. Every time you craft something it plays an unskippable cutscene. The playerbase has been begging for years on their hands and knees for a mass-crafting feature or at least the ability to skip the cutscene, to no avail.

4. The game relies too much on FOMO and other tricks used by Live Service Products tm and MMOs to cover for a lack of content.

Once you see the tricks the game uses to prod players into doing the same content over again you won't be able to unsee it. Better finish your Battlepass Dailies! Better finish your Weekly Assignments! Reminder that the Deep Dives will reset in X hours better complete them before they're gone for ever ever ever! It's the same stuff that MMOs and other predatory games do to keep players hooked, which is a shame because the game didn't need any of this. Deep dives have multiple objectives per mission instead of the primary and secondary of normal missions, that alone proves that they could easily iterate and expand on their core gameplay loop, but instead we got FOMO.

------

As a conclusion I'll mention a particular issue that saps a lot of the enthusiasm I have to play the game or support it going forwards.

The first two DLC bundles released were Dark Future and Megacorp containing an armour set, a weapon set, and paint jobs. There was also a free cosmetic set called Scale Brigade that players could earn by ranking up. What all three of these sets lack is a skin for pickaxes, unlike every other cosmetic set released to date. This is not because GSG doesn't care or put effort into things they make, it is simply because those three sets actually pre-date the pick customization system entirely. Scale brigade just happens to be my favourite set, so I (as well as many others) for years now have been asking for GSG to go back and update those old sets to include pickaxe skins. It seems like low hanging fruit since the skin texture already exists and the only possible result of adding fresh content to older DLC is the sale of more DLC.

And yet, even so many years later this and many more issues remain. It’s apparent that GSG is making the game they want to make and don't pay much attention to what the playerbase wants or needs. Instead of adding quality of life features, they would rather spend the time and effort to program, model and skin of all things, a flappy bird arcade machine for the space rig. To be fair, they have every right to do that as the owners of the IP, but it still comes off as profoundly tone deaf and is why I cannot fully recommend the game to anyone in 2024.

Deep Rock Galactic is a gem in the gaming world, offering an exhilarating experience that caters to the appetites of all thrill-seekers. This game seamlessly blends action, tactical thinking, and a humorous style that makes it irresistibly enjoyable.

One of the key elements that sets Deep Rock Galactic apart is its incredibly well-crafted world of mining on distant planets. Each mission presents a new, enchanting environment, filled with treacherous caverns, impressive caves, and mysterious spaces. Every dive into these underground mazes brings a sense of exploratory excitement.

Players are faced with challenges that require tactical thinking and cooperation, especially when playing with friends. Each of the four unique classes, with different skills and weapons, contributes to the team dynamic, encouraging collaboration to overcome demanding foes and obstacles. This teamwork creates a unique experience that will keep you hooked.

The game's graphic design deserves special praise. The combination of lighting effects, sensational animations, and carefully crafted characters creates a compelling atmosphere that keeps you glued to the screen. Additionally, the game's humor, from witty dialogues to quirky characters, adds an extra layer to the overall enjoyment.

The sound in Deep Rock Galactic is exceptionally well-done, with detailed sound effects enhancing the underground adventure. The music follows the game's rhythm and adds to the overall experience, creating an emotional connection with the surroundings.

In conclusion, Deep Rock Galactic is an incredibly addictive game that combines challenging tactics, a spirit of exploration, and humor into a perfect package. Are you ready for thrilling action, laughter, and exploration? Then, this game is undoubtedly the right choice for you!

I got this game shortly after season 4 came out (which is probably the least favoured of all this game's updates) and since then I've sunk over 500 hours into the game.

This game brings me back to the days where I'd get home from school and just sink HOURS into OG Call of Duty Zombies. The days where I'd just completely lose all track of time because the crew was trying to finish an easter egg or something. After playing COD zombies for so long, it just stopped being what it once was, and it left a hole in the games I played that was never really filled by anything.... until DRG came along.

I got it because of the funny memes my buddies sent me but, after a week or two of hesitation too, and man do I ever regret that time. The concept of the game is solid, you play as a team space-faring, cave-spelunking dwarves with the sole of objective of making it out alive. Using unique guns, grenades, and equipment you do your damnedest to keep up with the company's quotas and objectives. 

The voice lines are funny (even if you don't include the google translate mods), which is something you'd expect in a co-op shooter of this variety. But where Deep Rock really excels is with voicelines that have different rarities over others. There's times where I hear some for the first time today. Not only that, but the biomes are much more beautiful than they need to be. Even when I started playing on my own build (which struggled to maintain 40 frames at mid-high graphics cuz it was so old), there were times where I'd turn off the HUD and just meander through the caves with the only goal of taking it all in. ESPECIALLY in Azure Weald, place feels like you were sent to Pandora but instead of tall blue aliens you're up against crab/spider monsters.

Getting to Season 4, the elephant in the room, I really don't think it was as bad as people said it was at launch, even as green as I was at the time. Sure, sometimes a Stingtail would send you to a different area code, and sometimes a Corruptor would end your run before it started. But I still think they provided a good amount of challenge, not too much or too little, and they could be beaten easily so long as you and your team strategized accordingly. I think the saddest part of Season 4 was when the Devs made it possible to turn off the higher corruption odds in the November update. I see it as "hey Devs, we hate this thing you made SO MUCH that we want you to remove it completely", I just see it as an unnecessary kick in the face from the community.

The gameplay is top notch, I keep jumping into games whenever I can even though I've unlocked pretty much all there is to unlock because its that good. With friends, with randoms, and on your own, this game gives you everything you need to be successful, but makes it challenging every step of the way. Throwable flares both give you just the right amount of light and also nowhere near enough. There is endless customization with your weapons, equipment, cosmetics for it all, and even Bosco that i wonder if anyone has ever made the exact same loadout as someone else by accident (even though Infinite Monkey Theorem tells me otherwise). The new weapon maintenance feature adds on to that even more by rewarding you for playing with every gun. Before, I used to stick to maybe one or two loadouts, but now, I've fully built out every loadout the game gives you. Procedural generation really is the engine driving this game. It makes it so that typically easy challenges can go to impossible in the blink of an eye (like a tritilyte bomb dispenser in a pit). It makes it so that no to caves are the same. Even if some individual cave shapes are copied, the smaller terrain it generates can go anywhere which keeps these caves fresh game-over-game. The hordes are crushing, you can go from peacefully mining nitra to downed because you decided to finish the vein and not get ready when mission control said so. Sometimes it seems the horde spawn time is random, but the pacing is always just enough to test you for a couple minutes before dropping you back into the peaceful atmosphere. Even if you think it's too easy, the modding system this game has makes it unimaginably easy to make the game as hard as you want. Enemy design is spectacular too, you can look at two pixels of some bug and know exactly what it is, but they're also similar enough that in a horde you don't notice the slasher about to one-tap you. It only adds to the masterful balance the game puts forth for difficulty.

Man and I haven't even talked about the music yet. Remember when I talked about the ambiance of the caves? Well imagine you always had a perfectly fitting theme song for whatever you were doing. Booming drums for huge swarms, and softer horns for quiet spelunking. This game takes music to a whole new level. You'll never want to open up Spotify and bring your own music because the game pretty much has a DJ that perfectly fits whatever situation you'll find yourself in. And there's juuuuust enough music to have some songs feel new to you on occasion (maybe because you were too busy blasting bugs to notice).

Boy do I love this game, it really got me back into gaming after pretty much stopping altogether. I could go on forever about this game but I seriously doubt more than 3 people read all that^ up until this point. After playing games like Left4Dead, CoD Zombies, and other co-op shooters across many platforms, I can firmly say that DRG really has no rival. The only way I would improve this game is to add more mission types, that's it, maybe make it so cosmetics didn't come as suits but as individual pieces like with the pickaxe? It would be cool to see a mission where you recover the whole drilldozer or smtg, justify it by saying "management says the overhead on losing an entire drilldozer every time is too high, we need to bring em back now" and make that a whole new mission type. Or maybe one where you're saving a dwarf that was left behind? You get it up and it becomes an NPC aid like BET-C or smtg. I've played a lot, and more and more ideas for this game just keep popping into my head.

Idk, this game is great, get it if you haven't.

P.S. Apparently ^all that^ was 1200 words lmao

The co-op game to try if your friend group is burned out on competitive multiplayer shooters. It offers a great balance of silly fun and serious challenges. 

Tons of mission variety paired with endless swarms of bugs. You unlock upgrades and [i]free[/i] cosmetics at a perfect rate, with procedurally generated caves so it rarely gets old. There's seriously hundreds of hours worth of content to unlock, and it's an addicting process acquiring it all. Even the hub world between missions is full of places to explore, mini-games, and a bar with weird beers. Deep Rock Galactic is a fun, player-first experience that combines elements of horde shooters, resource management and the "Space-Dwarf" Genre. While matchmaking can certainly be fun, and playing alone can be rewarding in it's own right, a group of friends feels necessary to approach such a refreshingly cooperative yet casual experience. 

That said, DRG can be deceptively challenging at times. Difficulty can spike, but never in ways that feel unfair. After all, death is never very punishing, and you're always in control of adjusting the difficulty. The more complex elements of the game feel like the right kind of slow-burn, and will keep casual fans entertained for as long as this game is supported.

Simply, DRG is the perfect hang-out game where everyone can contribute without having to hyper focus on bosses or objectives. Seize the chance to enjoy some consequence free fun while you can because it doesn't come around very often.

Deep Rock Galactic is a class-based co-op horde shooter reminiscent of Left4Dead, with a fun dwarfy twist. Every class plays differently, each with a unique arsenal of weapons and their own tools for navigating environments. There's a good variety of missions and enemies, as well as randomly occurring events which sometimes pop up during missions which provide bonus rewards and progression as well as a fresh objective to keep your team on their toes. The music is arguably the best aspect of the game in my personal opinion, as some of the tracks surrounding the horde sieges are truly bangers. My only real complaint with this game is the progression system itself. It's not until 10-20 hours of playtime that you start to feel your character getting stronger with the perks and upgrades you unlock, as the XP reward system is very stingy and revolves very dependently around a battlepass. You cannot pay for tiers of the battlepass, which I generally consider a positive, however, in order to progress through the tiers you need to complete daily objectives, some of which the game outright does not allow you to do. All too often I've found myself loading into the game with the goal of levelling up, only to find that my daily objectives require me to complete missions of a certain type or in a specific region which I cannot access due to its absence from the current rotation. This leaves me feeling as though my time playing the game is wasted unless the proverbial stars have aligned to allow my progress, and ultimately drives me away from playing the game entirely. The rotations swap out relatively frequently, every half-hour or so, but if you don't get the region/mission type you need, waiting around for another chance at the region appearing in the next rotation is less than fun. In the scope of everything this game does right, it's a small complaint, but it's one that has consistently irked me. The game's community is notably quite friendly, but that is not without exception. Never trust a Driller. They can and will use their satchel charge to blow you and everyone else up in the final moments before extracting. If you've grown tired of Left4Dead after all these years, I would recommend this game. Otherwise, just play Left4Dead.

Deep Rock Galactic is a co-op shooter that puts you in the boots of a space dwarf, who must mine, fight, and drink his way through procedurally generated caves full of alien bugs and precious minerals. The game offers four distinct classes, each with their own unique weapons and tools, that complement each other in team play and create diverse gameplay scenarios. The game also features a rich progression system, with customizable cosmetics, perks, and upgrades for your gear and your personal space rig.

The game’s strongest point is its dynamic and immersive environment, where you can dig, build, and explore in any direction, creating your own paths and strategies. The lighting and sound effects create a tense and atmospheric mood, as you never know what lurks in the dark corners of the caves. The game also has a great sense of humor, with witty dialogue, hilarious animations, and a catchy soundtrack. The game is best enjoyed with friends, as the co-op mode allows you to coordinate your actions, share resources, and revive each other in case of trouble. The game also supports cross-play between PC and Xbox One, making it easier to find teammates.

The game’s main drawback is its lack of variety in terms of mission types, enemies, and biomes. After a while, the game can feel repetitive and grindy, as you do the same tasks over and over again, with little variation or challenge. The game also suffers from some technical issues, such as network lag, bugs, and crashes, that can ruin the experience. The game is still in active development, though, and the developers are constantly adding new content and fixing problems, so the game has a lot of potential to improve.

Overall, Deep Rock Galactic is a fun and addictive co-op shooter that offers a unique and satisfying gameplay experience. The game is not perfect, but it is definitely worth checking out if you are looking for a game that combines action, exploration, and comedy. Rock and stone, brothers!

I am a 55 year old biker and trucker father, and probably one of the oldest people playing this game. I am a single father to my Son, who is 15 now. My son got this game for from his uncle, so we installed it on his computer and he started playing. By the end of the week he had 12 hours on this game. This was horrible for me, as it was already hard for me to find ways to spend time with my son, as he is always out with his friends or just watching YouTube. So i decided to make a Steam account and get this game to see if I could maybe play alongside him. I loaded into the game and started playing but I was stuck on what you where supposed to do. I asked my Son for help and he let me borrow his controller. Me and my son then played in turns and I loved it as it was the best time I had spent with my Son since my wife had died. This game has ever since brought me and my son closer again and now we actually spend time together outside the house together as well. [h1]DRG, a unique game in an era where caring about your game is rare.[/h1]

[h2]Gameplay[/h2] 
I love how the game plays. It is a team co-op where you and your teammates have to complete an objective while being attacked by constant swarms of bugs. Thanks to the mission variety and the cave generation, each play session feels as refreshing as the last. But I think what most impacts the game’s lack of boredom is its characters and build variety. Currently, the game has 4 classes: [b]Gunner[/b], [b]Driller[/b], [b]Engineer[/b] (best class), and [b]Scout[/b]. Each one counts with 3 main weapons and 3 secondaries[spoiler], and each one of those has a variety of overclocks that change the gameplay completely[/spoiler].

[h2]Visuals and effects[/h2] 
There is no denying that this game looks awesome. It has a unique and flavorful art style that emphasizes the whole map’s destructibility, and it complements perfectly with the astonishing biomes. All of this is paired beautifuly with an awesome sound design that helps you immerse in the various caves that you encounter… and let’s not start with the soundtrack since I want to eventually finish this review. Finally, to round everything up, the interactions between [b]Mission control[/b] and the dwarves feel so natural and are extremely funny. I love the voice acting.

[h2]Ending Statements[/h2] 
Honestly, I love this game and its awesome community. I never knew people could be so kind and working towards an end goal, be it with strangers or [strike]friends[/strike]. It made me boot the game excitedly almost every day. And I have not mentioned the awesome perks, like a FOMO-less free battle pass, incredibly content-packed updates, or developers that actually listen to the community. I have spent around 300 hours when writing this review and the only thing I regret is buying the DLCs on a discount.

That would be it, miners. Thank you for reading me and hopefully we can meet in-game. ROCK AND STONE!

My name is Walter Hartwell White. I live at 308 Negra Arroyo Lane, Albuquerque, New Mexico, 87104. This is my confession. If you're watching this tape, I'm probably dead- murdered by my brother-in-law, Hank Schrader. Hank has been building a meth empire for over a year now and using me as his chemist. Shortly after my 50th birthday, he asked that I use my chemistry knowledge to cook methamphetamine, which he would then sell using connections that he made through his career with the DEA. I was… astounded. I… I always thought Hank was a very moral man, and I was particularly vulnerable at the time – something he knew and took advantage of. I was reeling from a cancer diagnosis that was poised to bankrupt my family. Hank took me in on a ride-along and showed me just how much money even a small meth operation could make. And I was weak. I didn't want my family to go into financial ruin, so I agreed. Hank had a partner, a businessman named Gustavo Fring. Hank sold me into servitude to this man. And when I tried to quit, Fring threatened my family. I didn't know where to turn. Eventually, Hank and Fring had a falling out. Things escalated. Fring was able to arrange – uh, I guess… I guess you call it a "hit" – on Hank, and failed, but Hank was seriously injured. And I wound up paying his medical bills, which amounted to a little over $177,000. Upon recovery, Hank was bent on revenge. Working with a man named Hector Salamanca, he plotted to kill Fring. The bomb that he used was built by me, and he gave me no option in it. I have often contemplated suicide, but I'm a coward. I wanted to go to the police, but I was frightened. Hank had risen to become the head of the Albuquerque DEA. To keep me in line, he took my children. For three months, he kept them. My wife had no idea of my criminal activities and was horrified to learn what I had done. I was in [heck]. I hated myself for what I had brought upon my family. Recently, I tried once again to quit, and in response, he gave me this. I can't take this anymore. I live in fear every day that Hank will kill me, or worse, hurt my family. All I could think to do was to make this video and hope that the world will finally see this man for what he really is.
