This game is freaking incredible! I can't even fathom how they managed to take such a repetitive game loop in theory, and make it stay fun game after game after game.

I don't know how they managed to make spamming voice lines a regular occurrence, but it's never annoying.

I don't know how they made the lobby where you wait for your friends to get ready for the next mission, so fun and satisfying to be in. The space rig somehow never gets old, and there's plenty to do! They even go crazy during the holidays and make it extra festive and decked out!

I love pissing off the boss at every possible opportunity, such as by kicking barrels into the launch bay. Or kicking barrels into the ship... or by... dancing? :D

Every single class feels fun, and I love playing all of them! I thought Engineer and Driller sounded dumb on paper, but they're probably my favorites!

I was also afraid to do public lobbies, but once I did I did not regret it. The community is very accepting, very tolerant, and very helpful. If you seem like you're lost, there's almost always someone coming down to show you the way. Get grabbed by a cave leech? Well, your whole squad is booking it to help you!

This game, and the community are absolutely wonderful, and this game deserves all the love it gets and more. Rock and Stone!

At its core DRG is a multiplayer extraction looter with four classes and procedural level design. While there is a relatively interesting game here it's buried under cosmetics and live service game design that leave it feeling hollow.

The gameplay itself is simple and engaging, you land, you dig out valuables and build up your horde, fight the monsters, and then make a dash back to the ship to escape. In practice however it can be a bit clunky and highly repetitive. The game is built around terrain deformation which can be tedious and unwieldy until you've upgraded your tools, and requires some blind digging upwards into walls to reach certain minerals. The procedural level design can also make navigation confusing as you dig down and have to make use of limited mobility tools to get around the map.

I can see the game being fun with friends but PUG play felt uncoordinated if at least cooperative and friendly. The most off-putting part for me was the live service framework - don't get me wrong, it's a free game but you're instantly met with a colossal grind in every aspect. Class levels, talents, equipment upgrades, unlockable equipment, cosmetics, shop points, buff beverages... it's one thing to have a lot of content but every one of these have progress bars and unlockables stretching off into the distance of the screen. While some might be excited at the prospect of so much content to discover, I found myself groaning at the chore of what laid ahead.

Ultimately this is a game that really wants you to no-life it in order to get anywhere, you start under-powered and unable to contribute much so the grind is a necessity from the start. Mission objectives are repetitive and gameplay is shallow as there might be a lot of minerals and mobs but gameplay is largely 'hold left or right mouse'. Friends can make doing anything fun, but seeing the daunting mountain of work and not really getting much out of the gameplay it's not an effort I have the time or interest to invest in. Also the voice acting is offensively bad. Overall a fun game for the right people but expect to put a lot in to get anything out.

[h1]A Must-Play Co-op Gem![/h1]

Deep Rock Galactic is an absolute blast, offering a delightful concoction of entertaining gameplay, a perfect blend of cartoonish graphics, dark corporate humor, and an ingenious selection of crazy craft beers that set the stage for an unparalleled fun-filled experience, especially when enjoyed with friends.

Even as a solo player, the game offers an engaging experience, but it truly shines in the cooperative multiplayer setting. The matchmaking system is top-notch, connecting you with a community that is not only helpful but genuinely eager to guide and share the excitement of the game.

What sets Deep Rock Galactic apart is not just its fantastic gameplay but also the solid commitment from the developers. The game follows a well-crafted roadmap, and the developers actively listen to the community's feedback, ensuring a constantly evolving and improving experience.

The asking price for Deep Rock Galactic is more than justified given the incredible value it delivers. If you're on the fence, don't hesitate – this game is a stellar investment that promises countless hours of laughter, teamwork, and memorable moments. Strap in for an interstellar adventure that's well worth every penny!

TLDR: I tried it, but I am clearly not the target audience.

I really wanted to like this game, especially after hearing my friends talking about the fun they had with it.  I tried the first couple of missions solo and it seemed intriguing enough.  Grouped up with those friends and tried a few more, but it never felt like I was making much of an impact, enemies soaking up everything I threw at them before downing me over and over.  I couldn't join them on regular, allegedly more fun missions since I hadn't finished the introductory batch, and helping me out was just holding them back from doing what they wanted.

I tried doing a couple more solo to catch up.  I still felt like everything was taking too long and that I must be doing something wrong, that there must be something that I was missing.  I got frustrated, I got bored, and I wasn't having fun, not caring if it gets better later.  I uninstalled and haven't played it since, and have no desire to return.  I would have applied for a refund if I could, but my game time was over the limit.

It's a shame since I can see that this game keeps getting a lot of praise.   But I'm not generally fond of multiplayer-focused shooters, and this game, as good as it seems to be for a lot of people, has not won me over.

I write this review as a veteran player, having played weekly for the past 3 years.
Never in that time have I ever had a doubt about the passion Ghost Ship Games has for this game: They remain grounded and active in the community, while their sensible approach to problems and criticism has earned my trust.


The game is very team-spirited, and encourages collaboration and camaraderie between you and your fellow Dwarves: Should you fail a mission, you failed it together (No doubt with a heroic last stand!); order a round of beer and try again.
I will naturally suggest playing with friends, but joining a random lobby is just as fun since there is no 'meta' so to speak.
Virtually any combination of weapons, upgrades and classes will work: A big part of this game's replay-ability comes from how many different play-styles and tweaks can be made to a given gun, specialising for certain missions or generalising for adaptability - I urge you to experiment with your loadout and class rather than stick with what is comfortable.

The procedural generation of the levels makes each mission a challenge, and gives each biome a different atmosphere.
The sound design evokes feelings of wonder and fear in equal measure, and that's not to mention the gloom.
Darkness is one of DRG's core mechanics, and makes it stand out amongst similar co-op games with destructible terrain.
A few dozen rare events and challenges allow for even more variety, without even mentioning modding.

Some may be discouraged to have heard about a season-pass - Do not fret! No content is locked behind any kind of paywall: The DLC are exclusively cosmetic, as are the rewards from progressing through the season.
It usually takes about 100 hours of playtime to unlock all the new content in a season, and it is possible to unlock everything you missed from past seasons and events, from Christmas Hats to Weapon Skins.

Grab a pick and try it out!
Be warned that if you reach Greybeard status as I have, you will struggle to play other games that include darkness without attempting to throw a flare. And the Rock and Stone! Shouting will start to become a genuine habit.

Despite only having 4 dwarves (playable characters), they are arguably all as useful and balanced. The enjoyment and success is often heavily dependent on teamwork, so be nice to your fellow dwarves and try being useful to the best of your capabilities From my experience in public matches, very nice and chill community.

I have to admit there's not much content (only 8 mission types and some missions modifiers), but the gameplay offers a high degree of replayability. Higher hazards (difficulty level) pose a real challenge, by increasing swarms, enemy damage and health, for those of you who want a tough, demanding experience.

All "microtransactions" you will see are purely cosmetics, which you can get by simply playing the game. Solid low-poly art style

Fun 4 player co-op FPS with semi rogue like elements. Weapons are fun to use for the most part, with a few outliers being just usable but not as good as their counterparts. The perk system is pretty bad and needs updating; only a few perks are viable which is the same on every class leaving not much room for build variety. 

Weapon build variety is slightly better with OC's (OVERCLOCKS) which change the way a weapon behaves but even amongst overclocks there are only a few viable ones for each weapon type, some overclocks being straight up WORST than their original overclockless variant. However, besides 1 or 2 bad weapons most were fun to use.  

The no-pay battle pass system is commendable and all the game modes are fun. The constant rotation of maps, hazards and random modifiers added with procedural generation freshens things up, keeping the game interesting.

Games were fairly easy to find so it is active in Oceania; Overall a pretty solid co-op experience.

This is one of THE greatest games of all time.  Its so good I had to get it twice(gifted a friend and may possibly gift another to another friend).  If you love adventurous games I highly recommend this game. I rate it up there with legend of Zelda games, The Witcher 3, and of course my favourite Skyrim. I thought I put in many hours into those games COMBINED, but this game has taken that podium. With over 670hrs into the game, I've not yet lost any interest which is saying a lot considering I play mostly RPG high profile games that requires a lot of hours into its game play.  Saying this game is a gem of a an indie game that should deserve more recognition that it currently has, isn't even cutting the ice. You can do so much in this game I don't even know where to begin so I'll just list random things off the top of my head that I love:
- customise your charter to whatever you can think of. I saw someone roll play as freaking Nardwuar and Bob Ross.
- SOO many collectable things to acquire in game. Such as gun mods, and skins for each and every gun/BOSCO 
- NO MICRO-TRANSACTIONS! YOU buy the game, you get access to the whole game!(well excluding a few cosmetics add ons, but its not needed to play the game)
- Procedural generated caves. Definitely one of my favourite aspects as its what keeps the game fresh and exciting. 
- And of course my favourite would be the community. The community is like none other. The players are all (at least in my 670hrs experience) very friendly. You want help completing tough missions? Need help getting certain achievements? Just ask and you'll be surprised the amount of people who will help. 

I know this is a long review, but just know that its, because this game is just this good.  It's a game I cant explain to you or tell you how great this game is. All I can say is give this game a try. Sooner or later you'll find yourself on the same position as I am right now, on the review section of Deep Rock Galactic and write away your experience.

So when I got this originally I didn't expect to enjoy the game as much as I have.  There is a lot of love from the developers in this game.  It's easy to tell from playing it. It's very fun to play with friends especially if each goes as a different dwarf class.  It's even easy to play on older computers that also don't got a lot of memory.  Definitely give this game a try.  It's really fun to play and really satisfying to kill the bugs and mine the ores.

An ongoing and still-blossoming passion project by an extremely talented group of devs and artists. The gameplay loop is on the level of Monster Hunter in terms of satisfaction, the gunplay is extremely diverse and satisfying, all four classes feel distinct and compliment each other perfectly, and the enemy variety is just about perfect. As a horde shooter I'd actually put it ABOVE Left for Dead. Environments are similarly fantastic with only one real stinker (fungus bogs, why are you the way that you are?).

Technically, the game is utterly exemplary when it comes to procedural generation. The systems they have in place make every single cave feel engaging to navigate and interesting to explore. Even with how complex the generations can be, it is incredibly rare for something to feel scuffed or broken. 

The community is also the best I've ever experienced in an online game. The absence of PvP, the emphasis on teamplay, and the amount of character and charm the game has are likely the biggest contributors to that sense of camaraderie. It's so non-toxic that it's genuinely jarring when someone puts down another player, even mildly. In my hundreds of hours I can count the number of negative interactions with randoms on one hand. 

Buy it, try it, enjoy it. Rock and Stone.

Two things I appreciate about this game are the  amount of personality and care put into it as well as  the user friendly and engaging game play.  There are so many fun items and messages in the hub that make me laugh when I find them.  The concept of the game play however had me worried as I felt that a game about mining would get boring after a few hours, to my surprise the game offers several new challenges and situations in each level that prevent the game play from getting stale.  Deep Rock Galactic is a solid game in my books and I wholeheartedly recommend it.

I'm not sure I really enjoy DRG. The actual gameplay, I mean. I can tell that the Devs very much enjoyed making it and I like playing with friends, but the gameplay isn't super interesting to me. 

I like other aspects of the game, like the silliness of the Space Rig and all the little details that the devs have put in, but the core aspect of the game seems like a time sink with little to no significant reward. The other thing is that the build structure seems completely played out.

There are optimized ways to perform each task or mission that have long since been discovered and laid out, but even with future updates, nothing new is being added to the game outside of additional threats in the form of New enemies or regions.

I see the appeal, but the game is too similar to the 'same-y-ness' of games like Left for Dead or Gears of War. You're essentially just running over the same ground (or under, as the case may be), indefinitely to pass time. Level ups feel less impactful knowing there's nothing significant waiting for me at the endgame outside of (again) long discovered and laid out modifiers for the existing abilities.

If you like the kinds of games that I listed above and enjoy a simplistic 'horde mode' with gradually increasing difficulty and lots of grind, then by all means, pick it up. The community is extensive and there's lots to enjoy. Ultimately though, its not engaging enough for me without more significant progression or story. 

As a cooperative experience its interesting, but if you're looking for personalization or uniqueness in your build or the way you play, you won't find it here.

Rock and stone lads. You are a dwarf, you mine, you blow up bugs and you get drunk. What else is there to ask for? A really fun game with a massive fanbase, great humour and something for every kind of player. 

[b]Story:[/b] No story, but fun characters that the fanbase has fully fleshed out into icons.

[b]Gameplay & controls:[/b] First person shooter and a run bind! My pinky is very happy. I don’t think I’m ever playing the game and getting mad about the controls.

[b]Visual design:[/b] Love the way the game looks, very simple while still allowing for some cool and gorgeous caves, while also not sacrificing my PC’s hardware.

[b]Music and SFX:[/b] So good, one of the few games I would not mind just listening to without having spotify on in the background. Guns make a very satisfying sound and all bugs and events are identifiable by different sounds.

[b]Enjoyment:[/b] A really fun game, solo, with friends or with randoms! If you like shooters, what the hell are you even doing? Go get the game.

[b]Achievements:[/b] 69 achievements in total, not hard, but very time consuming. You will need friends for a couple of them like Car pool and Karl would be proud. 

Overall, completely deserved the labour of love award. Such a great game that I am unable to explain in just a review, you have to go play it. Literally my only issue is that some of the missions get stale after playing for 300 hours and there’s no cross play with steam and console. Hopefully the next update brings in a ton of new stuff!

Absolutely amazing gameplay, great music, classes that synergize with teamwork and a NON TOXIC GAMING COMMUNITY?!?! Basically everything I would ask out of a multiplayer shooter, plus despite the game being filled with spiders the game doesn't trigger my arachniphobia (except for my insectophobia with those grabby flying insects which is rare to find)!
Also this game is SO BEAUTIFUL and immersive with it's worldbuilding despite mostly being procedurally generated, and everything moves so fluidly and alive that it just immerses you even more!

Overall it is a banger game and should definitely be recommended, and even if you aren't the best with shooters or gaming in general, my mother (who barely actually plays games) actually enjoyed it a LOT, so i just wish the best for this game!

Great game! After over 200 hours, I'm still having a lot of fun with it. The caves are procedurally generated, so every game is unique. The community is not toxic, cheaters are extremely rare. It's fun to upgrade the (four) characters. The dwarves' sayings are funny and never get boring. There are regular seasonal events where you can earn skins or other upgrades.

I used to enjoy playing "Left4Dead(2)". Deep Rock Galactic is not directly comparable, but it is similar in terms of game mechanics and replay value. Although a single-player mode is possible, the game is really fun in multiplayer, as each dwarf has his own skills, which can be combined well with the others.

Both the community and the developers are very active. Just as it should be.

An absolute recommendation!

Deep Rock Galactic really grabbed me by the rocks'n'stones, in a way that no other co-op experience has since Left 4 Dead first dropped. The atmosphere! The soundtrack! The [b]bugs[/b]! Insects, I mean. Game runs like [i]butter[/i].

Each class brings something to the table, interacting with the environment (and other players) in clever ways - not to mention the wealth of weapons, mods and skills you can play around with to cater to your preferred playstyle. The procedural generation and mission variety, combined with the random modifiers and events, also put a unique spin on every session. Even after 250+ hours, Deep Rock keeps me guessing. 

It's also very silly, if you like that sort of thing. 

Honestly, this is one of the smoothest and most enjoyable gameplay experiences I've ever had, jam-packed with action down to the last detail. The devs clearly have had fun making this one - every single aspect of the game simply oozes with charm, innovation and quality, to an frequently [i]ridiculous[/i] degree. 

An absolute [b]labour of love[/b]~

A fun fast-paced, funny, challenging  game, that is best played with friends (solo play is possible).

Procedural generation of maps means never seeing the same map twice and often weird surprises or combinations of mission situations.  So, objectives require more searching and fun, to locate.

The game has funny content, hidden stuff to find, seasonal rewards, updates, and events.

Deep Rock Galactic is easy on computer resources, working exceptionally with with DirectX 12, and the latest video features, such as AMD FSR or nVidia DLAA.

The game supports modding from the mods.io website.  It helps if all party members are using the same mods.  Activate the mod API key from the website first.  Then choose the game, then connect to your Steam account.  Mods can be added and removed from the website.  Restart the game a few times to update mods automatically.
**  I do not recommend using mods through the Steam Workshop, as the process often does not work properly.

One of the few games that makes me truly love the game studio behind it. The love for this game from both the community and devs is something you see very rarely.

This game is (as the developers said themselves) [quote=devs]"A mix of Left 4 Dead 2 and Minecraft"[/quote]4 player co-op against hoards of AI enemies. This combination works very well together and when combined with the aspect of procedurally generated maps (all of which having stunning ambience and visuals) makes for something that no other game could accomplish.
My favourite aspects of this game are the friendly and welcoming community and how visible it is that this isn't another cash grab from a greedy publisher. There is no premium battlepass, there are no microtransactions within the game, all customisations can only be gotten through playing the game.

If you have't played it yet, go and try it out, you won't regret it.
Rock and stone fellow miners.

DRG is an outright fun time. the objectives keep everything fresh and the live service model seriously impressed me.

Getting down to tacks, the gameplay is amazing, a PVE, objective-based horde shooter with Four classes and four distinctly different styles of play, with many opportunities for great synergy.
they also have plenty of extra content there with them to shape how you play.
the levels have varied objectives that keep things interesting, from the simple mining of a specific ore, to eliminating a bunch of boss monsters. side objectives included! 

i wanted to add this to my reasoning.
 in this day and age where games are constantly swarming you with battle passes and other such subscription services, DRG never does that in the traditional way. in fact it makes itself distinct by making last season's "battle pass" [and cosmetics grid] items obtainable through the normal loot pool. the "battle pass" is also completely free, you don't have to buy it, and it's not subscription based.
This. This is what a live service model should be. a reward for doing something you were going to have fun with anyway. not something you fork money over and grind forcibly because you want one thing, and you feel obligated to do rest of because of the money you spent.

with all of this in place, the DLCs that are here are purely cosmetic, and nothing more. if you like what you see there, i'd encourage you to get it, buying the DLCs are one way to support the devs! in fact there's two DLCs dedicated to that.
there are other ways in game to get cosmetics, if you were worried about cosmetics only being sold by DLC don't be, this game won't pull F2P garbage on you.

while i don't think i'm the best at utterly describing how good this game has been to me and my friends who have played it, i still definitely think it's worth full price. if you grab it on sale that's alright too, the game's great and has genuinely been a good time.

love the game it has constant replay ability and its so much fun! been playing since the game released and i play every Wednesday! the devs are amazing and have done so much work for the game! highly recommend!

This game is easily one of the best games I have played in a very long time. Every aspect of the game is a executed incredibly well and you could spend countless hours playing this game. The game play is excellent. You mine some rocks and stones and get rich. The whole time you're doing this with your friends or very friendly people online, or by yourself I suppose. The baddies are big bugs called glypids and their varieties create very interesting scenarios. The art style is very unique and pretty as well. Another great thing is the game is very player friendly, in the sense that the actual company making the game is not trying to steal your money. You buy the game and you have the game. There are no scammy loot boxes or in game stores. 10/10

There is definitely something to be said about the somewhat tedious amount of grinding it takes to unlock basic features for the game when first starting. There is also something to be said about the mission assignments that really do nothing but force you to choose between a mission that will give you something actually worthwhile versus one you actually want to play. That said, 10/10 would kick barrels again

Worth every penny!

Rock and Stone to the bone.

[h1]Positives[/h1]
One of the best games I've played so far, and even after lots of hours it's still just as enjoyable. Thanks to procedural cave generation every mission feels new, you see different challenges in each cave which keeps the gameplay fresh
[list]
[*]Jet Boots are great and fun to use, it's always exciting when you find their create in a cave
[*]The class system is excellent, all 4 types are unique with diverse weapons and gear, and all of them are very enjoyable to play. Despite having different movement tools, you can climb and descent almost anywhere with any of the classes with each tool
[*]Weapons and tools have great visual and audio feedback, all of them sound and feel exactly how you'd expect them
[*]Every input is instant and you can animation cancel almost anything. Every time you move, shoot, climb etc. the effects happen instantly and it feels great. It's hard to explain without trying yourself, but everything you do feels snappy and satisfying
[*]Great class synergy, all the weapons and tools can be used together and you never really feel like you're the weak link or not as powerful as other classes. They're all unique, they can all deal with pretty much any enemy alone and in a team
[*]Great custom crosshairs for each weapon and tool, they're really neat. The only thing I dislike is the M1000's crosshair because the exact center of it isn't visible enough compared to the rest of it, which often throws my aim off
[*]Nice built-in modding support with automatic updates
[*]You can play solo with a small drone companion, or in a team with friends or randoms. In most mission types you can join in mid-game too
[*]Good enemy designs and excellent variety. There's a lot of them and they all feel, look and behave uniquely with different counter plays
[*]The art style is great, and the audio design is excellently done. Positional audio, unique enemy noises, sound queues etc. are all really well done
[*]The developers seem to listen to the community which is great to see <3
[/list]


[h1]Mixed[/h1]
[list]
[*]Although the animations are top notch, some weapons kinda feel meh to use imho. The Warthog has a strangely unsatisfying recoil effect and reload animation. The EPC and Sludge Pump often don't feel responsive, you have to click and hold for a bit for them to fire sometimes, rather than just spam clicking. It's kinda annoying especially when you have bugs swarming around you and the gun just doesn't want to shoot
[*]Some features work differenly based on if you're the host or a client in a team. Hoverclock, Jet Boots etc. can be really annoying to get used to when you're the client as they behave differently than how you'd expect them to. I can't get used to Hoverclock as a client player, it's considered a buff but I don't see it, imho it's clunky and annoying. And Jet Boots activate when you only want to jump and I find that they overheat quicker because of it, since you build up the heat meter when you didn't even want to use them
[*]The new player experience is poor, you have no clue where anything is on the Space Rig. Once you get used to things everything's fine, but it's quite miserable and overwhelming trying to understand what's what as a new player
[*]A lot of things on the UI are great, but a lot of things could be improved and made more intuitive
[/list]


[h1]Negatives[/h1]
[list]
[*]Cave generation can be complete bs sometimes with its heights and tunnel entrances
[*]The OMEN machine event is unfair if it has a Drone Replicator module. The other 2 options are fine and enjoyable to play against, but since the bottom module is always a Radial Pulse-Gun, you can't focus on both its projectiles and the drones, while also dodging the 3rd module, staying on the maintenance spots, and shooting the weak spots all at the same time. The drones make this fight complete bs
[*][strike]Some enemies are horrendously imbalanced, such as the Rockpox infected ones. They have what feels like 99% damage reduction everywhere apart from a few random weak spots which are tiny and hard to hit as the bugs more around. And every time you do they release a cloud of Rockpox that lasts for way too long, having complete area denial wherever they shoot their projectiles or where they're are killed. Not to mention some enemies have their weak spots on a side you can't even attack, such as Macterra or the Breeder, so good luck killing them. Blasting their weak spots, and cleaning Lithophage spikes are satisfying, but everything else about Rockpox is a headache. I get that it's the lore and whatever, but the gameplay is awful. It's not even about the difficulty, they're just irritating and unfun to play against. I actively avoid every single Lithophage mission as much as possible, literally never want to see them again until they're rebalanced.[/strike] The November 2023 update fixed a lot of these issues imho
[*]Some maps have environmental effects which imho are annoying and don't add much to gameplay. Things like earthquakes in Magma Core, ice storms in Glacial Strata and sandstorms in Sandblasted Corridors. The last 2 significantly limit your vision, and all of them reduce your movement speed by a lot. These don't do anything, just annoy the player
[*]Septic Spreaders are frustrating to deal with because they fire in an arc even if they don't have direct line of sight on you, and their toxic projectile deals too much damage imho
[*]The difficulty spike in some cases is terrible imho. The Glyphid Dreadnought for example has a close range stomp attack which is really slow and easy to dodge as a solo player. But as soon as you have 1 more player with you the Dread's attack speed makes it almost impossible to dodge; if you're within its range when it starts the stomp you're basically dead
[*]Hazard scaling is sometimes inconsistent. Haz4 (second highest difficulty) is sometimes surprisingly easy, other times it spawns way more bugs than haz5 would. I don't see why this difficulty level is so whack. Sometimes it's so insane the mission becomes undoable because the game spawns an unreasonable amount of bugs that are impossible to deal with
[*]Rival Shredders and Naedocyte Shockers are irritating to fight against, I wish they were removed from the game
[*]The Rockpox Corruptor is tedious and imbalanced to fight against, and I hate how it can hyperspeed jump away during the battle, so you have to waste even more time trying to track it down. If you don't, you'll have puddles of Rockpox on the ground which deal way too much damage, so you're kinda forced to deal with the Corruptor if you want to enjoy the rest of the mission
[*]Some machine events can spawn in areas that make them impossible to complete within the given time. I get that it's procedural generation so you can't implement failsafes like that, but in some rare cases you have zero hope of completing the event
[*]Similarly, primary objectives can (extremely rarely, bit still) land in inaccessible spots. We had a Deep Dive where the Gunner with the Coil Gun shot a tiny hole that went deep into the wall during a fight, which is where Hack-C ended up landing afterwards. If we didn't have a Driller that would have been a nightmare
[*]In solo, Bosco is absolutely useless when it comes to defending Doretta. Quite often enemies can clip inside the drilldozer's hitbox which might be what's causing this issue, but even if they don't Bosco refuses to shoot anything at all even if the bug is literally right in front of him. It's mind blowing how this hasn't been fixed yet, which is funny because Engineer's turrets can find and shoot bugs regardless of where they are around Doretta
[*]Bosco sometimes fails to launch missiles on command. For some reason he stops engaging the enemies and just floats there doing nothing at all. And when you recall him or tel him to attack something else, he'll fire the missile you had ordered previously anywhere between a few seconds to a few minutes afterwards
[/list]

Best Co-op game ever, highly recommended.
You can play one mission per session or how ever much you want in a row.

Not to mention the different classes and their own unique and varied arsenal to choose from and customize.

One of my favorite things is actually the community, very friendly and good to newbies.
There is a button to salute, and it is used very frequently by everyone.
Players barely use the chat to communicate, there are very simple & useful contextual pings instead.

I keep playing even after achieving all the mechanical upgrades that exist, I'm not even playing for the cosmetic upgrades, this game is just so great and has perfected its genre.
The developers keep supporting it and releasing new updates frequently, this is a must play game for everyone (even if FPS aren't really you thing).

Deep Rock Galactic - Where Space Dwarves Dig with Attitude!

Deep Rock Galactic is the co-op FPS you never knew you needed, featuring space Dwarves with more attitude than a supernova. Grab your pickaxe, call dibs on your favorite class, and get ready for a wild ride through procedurally-generated caves filled with destructible environments and enough alien monsters to make even Ripley blush.

1-4 Player Co-op:
You and your buddies better stick together like beard hairs in a minecart because these caves are no joke. Team up, dig deep, and fend off hordes of extraterrestrial nasties. Remember, in space, no one can hear you scream... but your fellow Dwarves can definitely hear you if you don't share those valuable resources.

4 Unique Classes:
Whether you're mowing down enemies as the Gunner, scouting ahead as the over-enthusiastic Scout, drilling through rocks like it's your day job as the Driller, or engineering the heck out of everything as the wise-cracking Engineer - there's a Dwarf for every personality, and they're all ready to bring the boom.

Fully Destructible Environments:
Who needs a carefully paved path when you can make your own? Destroy everything in your way, whether it's rocks, alien critters, or the Engineer's questionable taste in music. The cave's your canvas, and your pickaxe is the brush.

Procedurally Generated Cave Network:
Every cave is a new adventure. With procedurally generated caves, you'll never get bored. It's like playing hide and seek with aliens, except they're not hiding, and they definitely want to seek you. Good luck!

High-Tech Gadgets and Weapons:
Dwarves don't mess around. Flamethrowers, gatling guns, portable platform launchers - it's like an interstellar Home Depot on steroids. If it doesn't explode, is it even worth using?

Light Your Path:
In the darkness of space, you're not alone. Equip your own lights because these caves make the abyss look like a cozy campfire. Remember, if it's not illuminated, it's probably hungry and coming for you.

In Deep Rock Galactic, the only thing deeper than the caves is the camaraderie among Dwarves. It's a riotous journey through space where the only thing more explosive than the alien onslaught is the banter between friends. So grab your helmet, tighten your beard braids, and let the deep-space mining party begin!
hot single dwarves in your area

This is probably one of the most fun games I've played. Each match is a new experience, no two are alike. There is always some combination of challenging terrain to traverse, unique enemies to ward off, varied challenges and objectives to focus on, and strengths of my chosen class to play around with.

There is a near-perfect balance between butt-clenching tension, grappling away from a hoard of bugs with just a sliver of hp and the faint red glow of healing sugar in the distant tunnels, and between peacefully picking away at some gold veins, exploring beautiful and diverse underground ecosystems, and petting lootbugs of course. It never gets stale, and I find that I actually play because the game is fun, and NOT because I'm grinding to unlock some item that'll only give me +0.02 defense against poison damage when submerged in water.

If you enjoy dwarfs, mining, space, shooting, or devs who actually care about their work and aren't just pumping out a cheap cash grab, the mines of Hoxxes are the place for you. Rock and stone, brother!

Deep Rock Galactic is a very fun game. The graphics can be odd at first, but it's a very stylized game in a good way. In my review, I'll tell you all the ins- and outs of this game.

In Deep Rock Galactic you role-play as a dwarf miner, and you have to mine ore for management while fighting hordes of monsters in the depths of procedurally-generated caves. 'Deep Rock Galactic' is a competitive multi-species company that uses dwarves as cheap, disposable labor force for the dirtiest, most dangerous jobs. We also know that other mining ventures deemed Hoxxes IV “too dangerous” to be profitable.

Pros:
- Fun game-play loop
- Friendly community
- (Completely optional) modding support
- Knowledge is rewarding and powerful (although there is a steep learning curve)
- Character customization available in terms of visual looks and gameplay
- Variety of different mission styles
- Fun ingame voice-over character that reacts to gameplay
- This game actually puts role-playing in the genre"Action ROLE-PLAYING Game"
- Seasonal rewards can still be earned even if the season has already progressed - and this is a play 2 earn mechanic!
- All in-game content can be purchased via credits as a PLAY 2 EARN mechanic! You do not have to worry about having to spend more money to actually play the game. Looking at you, Destiny 2.....
- Remember to ROCK & STONE and drink your BEER!
- We're rich!

Cons:
- The promotion system can be exhausting. If you want to main a particular class in this game, this is discouraged. You are forced to play other characters during your promotion, as you do not gain experience on the class you are currently promoting. Playing 5 missions on the promoting class is really not efficient if you could be gaining levels on another class. It's understandable that this is implemented so that players rotate classes and experience the full game, but this could be enforced in a more main-alt friendly manner.
- The grind in this game can be tedious. Leveling up and promoting your dwarf can take a huge amount of time. There are achievements that require high ranks on every class, essentially forcing you to play hundreds of hours if you ever wish to obtain these achievements.
- You'll be spending at the least 5-10 hours or so on each class unlocking every weapon option. This is can be fun. What is less fun is having to buy the same cosmetics for each class individually. I've totally bought plenty of cosmetic items thinking I could put them on each character, only to be disappointed that I have spent all my resources and credits on items I can only use on a class I didn't intend it for. This is totally a valid excuse to continue mining for another 10 hours though...
- This game is cursed and ever so often the game will greet you with the 'Lost Connection To Server' error and you will lose all progress in your active mission. If you were almost back in the drop pod, say goodbye to your credits, experience and materials!
- When hosting a mission, a single player can completely sabotage the run. If you are alone and one miner joins, Bosco will no longer accompany you. If you are down and your 'friend' dwarf decides to leave the game, your mission fails even though Bosco would normally be able to revive you.
- Unlocking matrix cores, which are used to create very powerful weapon upgrades (absolutely mandatory for end-game content), is time-gated by a weekly deep dive mission. As you can only receive rewards once per unique weekly deep dive, this is not farmable without waiting many weeks. You could theoretically farm them by promoting classes, but this is not realistic to be doing every time you play. Leveling up and promoting takes a lot of time.
- The forging animation, that will play when forging using matrix cores, plays every time and cannot be skipped. It can easily take a few minutes if you saved up some cores.
- Even though the procedural generation of levels in this game is really good, I wish there was more gameplay variety so a dwarf could take a break from mining once in a while. Of course, management would never agree to this.

Overall: 8/10

It's a game I always find myself going back to. It's a hilarious FPS with dialogue that always makes me laugh. The atmosphere is rich (but not in the "makes your voice high pitched" sort of way). I'm always intrigued by the flora in the biomes and it always makes you feel like you're diving into an alien ecosystem. All four classes looks unique and fun to play ...but I'll always be a Driller at heart. There's also many different builds you can make and you can play the way you want since pretty much everything is viable. 

Very rarely does it feel repetitive due to the procedural generation, random events, weekly stuff, and seasonal events. There's also new stuff to look forward to since the devs consider the game a labor of love. They listen to the community and they still update and add new content to the game even to this day. Plus, playing with company always makes it better. It's a great game to mess around with friends. I wouldn't sleep on randoms either. The community is so close that it's almost like a cult, which may sound bad to say but it's hard to compare close everyone is otherwise. For example, every dwarf knows that when find Compressed Gold you have to ping it repeatedly, exclaiming "We're Rich!" maybe until mission control yells at you to stop. Even though it's mostly a multiplayer game, going solo is also still a blast with Bosco, the bestest boi in the game probably next to Lloyd. 

I think the only gripes are RNG for getting the overclocks and cosmetic cores you want (I always end up with other stuff for other classes except what I want for Driller) and small stuff like how each class is mostly forced to have a color, like Driller is stuck with yellow a lot (which I don't mind but someone else might). Most of this can be fixed with mods as modding is really easy to do as well.

[h2] (Not so) in-depth review for Deep Rock Galactic [/h2]
Recommended by one of my friend on Discord. This game is very fun to play, has great gameplay and amazing co-op experience, although best enjoyed in multiplayer but one always able to experience it in Solo mode.
[hr][/hr]
[h2] Pros & Cons [/h2]
[h3] Pros [/h3]
- Surprisingly very welcoming community and they all friendly during mission, something i rarely found in other game that require teamwork. In my 800 hours of playtime i'm only came across 1-3 toxic player, which is incredible!!
- The game aesthetic really match with the artstyle, love it.
- Gunplay feel so good and each gun feel unique, can be customize with frameworks and paintjobs (also that M1000 "ping" sound)
- Mood-boosting soundtracks especially on the right moment like swarm and mad dash during extraction.
- Support tool that actually can be use for teamwork.
- You can drunk during the mission. 
- Procedural generation mean different experiences and feel less repetitive.
- 4 different flavors for the dwarf with their tools and weapons unique to each class.
- Performance pass are free, no need to spend money to finish or to unlock extra reward mean no microtransaction. Previous season cosmetic still obtainable too, by finding Lost Equipment and Cargo Crate (based GSG).
- DLC only contain cosmetics, buy it to support the Dev.
- If you want to immerse yourself to breathtaking view of some planetary region like Azure Weald but didn't want to bother your teammate. Don't worry, Solo mode in this game isn't harsh, and you will be accompanied by a drone that has puppy-like personality Bosco.
- Lots of enemies variety.

[h3] Cons [/h3]
- The Rockpox Corruptor has too much particles that cause FPS drop, it's also bit hard and annoying to fight in Solo mode.
- Sadly, unlike weapons. No customization available for support and traversal tools, if the Dev add this it would be great.
[hr][/hr]
Well that's all my opinion in this review for DRG, best co-op game i ever played.

Grindcore claustrophobic coop game with [u]zero story[/u], and repetitive chores/activities, boring to play solo, and is probably not very fun with friends either.
Has a ridiculous amount of grind that doesn't even unlocks anything interesting,  a dozen insignificant upgrades, skins, and a few hats/beards that are mostly invisible under the blocky armor.
The game thinks it is a MMO, and starts on a "season" page that gives nothing, it uses the same cheap tactics as a MMO or gacha game, with multiple currencies, diminishing returns grind, timegated events and drops, while offering only maybe 5% the content of an average MMO, and not being free. And you can't encounter other players with your team, you either play together on your own server, play solo with a bot, or join a team of randoms on a public server.
Even if your group of friends have a passion for digging and mining, good luck keeping them invested in this boring game for longer than 4/5 missions. That's the number of different types of missions, and you'll just be doing the same sh*t/different day on progressively more difficult maps, killing the same boring waves of insects coming at you every 5 minutes like clockwork.
The levels are pitch black with splotches of light in the distance, and it's often difficult to visually process what's on the screen (just look at the screenshots) and you lose sense of depth. The semi-cartoony WoW-like graphic style didn't help either, but that's just personal preference.
The overwhelmingly positive reviews are probably due to a toxic juvenile audience. Just go play a MMO instead. Or literally any other coop game.

TLDR - Deep Rock Galactic is an overwhelmingly, phenomenally fun game that has an incredible community behind it. If you like swarm shooters, even a little, buy this game. You will not regret it. Even at full price. The Dev’s of this game, somehow, have not given into modern corporate greed, and continue to churn out amazing content for this game that can be unlocked… Get this… By. Just. Playing. The. Game... Unreal. 

Rock & Stone Miner!

Pros - 

You are one of four hilariously voiced dwarf men. A Scout, Driller, Gunner, or Engi. All of these classes play exceptionally differently, and are ALL an absolute thrill to play as in their own rights once you get used to them.

The music… It’s so catchy and iconic.

The UI and controls are pretty much all very intuitive and simple! The gunplay is just, fantastic.

The upgrade system… The overclock system… The dwarf customization… *Chefs Kiss*

Hilarious joke Beers in the hub. Not even to mention all the random garbage lying around in the hub that you can mess with that will either scratch your ADHD riddled brain or make mission control pissed at you.

This game is EASILY enjoyable in just about any mood, at any level of soberness. You can play it seriously and sweat your balls off in Haz 4 - 5 missions or an EDD, or, you can be drunk as all high hell IRL and play Haz 1-3, laughing the entire time at random crap, and still win… Or hilariously lose.

The rando’s that you can queue up with in this game are some of the best rando’s in the entire gaming community. Nice people, helpful people, meme lords that just, kill you with laughter… All sorts.

Karl. The Dwarfs. Mission Control. Bosco. Lloyd. BETTC. Dorretta. Mini-Mules. Molly… Steve. Even the Bugs. There is SO much character poured into all the models, animations, voice lines and characters. It’s really awesome, even after roughly 500 hours in DRG, I find myself chuckling at certain voice lines or animations I’ve heard / seen many times over.

The map generation system ensures that every mission always feels slightly different than the last. Enough different biomes and mission types to keep you quite interested.

Mod support. Official mod support. There are TONS of really, really good mods for this game that will not disable progress or achievements. 

Nearly EVERY item (Bar some seasonal stuff that you can get during the respective seasonal events that come around every year) that has ever been added to this game can be obtained simply by playing. No extra money to buy previous seasons passes… None of that. Just play the damn game and earn those old cosmetics.

The install size is sub 5GB, and can be run on potato devices at decently stable frame-rates. The optimization of this game is INCREDIBLY well done.

Great mod support from the Dev's!

Mids - Having to redo the Promotion missions every time a Dwarf reaches level 25 can get old pretty quick. 

Some mission types can wear on you, making you want to avoid them. Morkite is one that wears on me.

Cons - What Cons?

DRG is a great coop horde shooter. Game sessions are typically within 20 min chunks, so if you wanted to jump in and jump out, its easy and fun. If you wanted to go for a longer session, you can do deep dives: fun 3-mission epics that give great rewards.

You don't really level up with "more powerful stuff". Progression is more about weapon choices (some are better than others in different situations) and cosmetics. "Promoting" a class is more of a cosmetic thing than anything else, but it looks cool and the grind is fun.
Great game, extra enjoyable with friends and community.

I highly recommend this for it's Coop Gameplay, the diversity the 4 Classes bring, while all having similarish enough components (Mainweapon, Secondary weapon, Traversal Tool, Utility Item) to be able to switch easy enough between them and also so many things to keep you playing again and again without the feeling of boring repetition.
Keep it up GSG / DRG!

Early on, this game will seem unfocused, weird and gimmicky. They drop you into missions and you finish it then wonder "is that it?"

If you embrace the premise, and view it through the lens of a co-operative game, you will quickly learn why the missions can become so fun. Each dwarf has advantages and weaknesses, and each dwarf can cover eachothers weaknesses. Missions require very active participation from everyone in the cave. The scout needs the engineer to make platforms, the gunner needs the driller to create pathways, etc. The more thorough a team is about collecting resources, the more everyone benefits in terms of currency, materials, xp and so on. These resources serve as the players progression, weapon unlocks, cosmetics, everything that matters is 100% accessible through gameplay- no real money needed. You can unlock everything yourself, in a timely manner, and you can always have something to do, and the game doesnt gouge or entice you into doing it like a second job. there is no FOMO, no predatory daylies or battle passes, there is just gameplay and then rewards for gameplay. 

But most importantly? it's a FUN game. the dwarves can interact verbally, they can reach insane topspeeds and they can do insane damage to the enemies, environments or their own teammates. It is a game that approves of any playstyle, the objectives are diverse and challenging but not frustrating (mostly- save for korloks and corruptors). Just play it

Definitely a fun time, especially with friends. Mission based progress provides nice bite sized progression. Well made and planned out game. Can get a little boring/repetitive but still worth the money.

I don't normally play first person shooter games, and Deep Rock Galactic has been a very fun adventure for me to get into. Each of the classes are easy to pick up, and you can learn a lot just by watching how other players handle things or by asking for a little extra guidance. While each class also starts off relatively simple, you can also add little adjustments to really turn your build into your own with perks and other enhancements. I have found it extremely friendly towards beginners, but great to sink your teeth into if you're looking for a game that requires more involved expertise in higher difficulties.

Really, though, what hooked me is that this is just Splatoon's Salmon Run but with dwarves. If you liked that, you'll love this. They've even got their own booyah.

I've been playing since beta. This is one of the best co op shooters that exists. Overall, it's structured like Left 4 Dead with mining/extraction gameplay. The developers of Back 4 Blood made terrible design choices so this is the next best things to play if you miss L4D like I do. The devs continue to support the game and the community is non toxic. It's worth the full price.

For a laugh, I had AI write a review for this game with this prompt: write me a game review about "rock and stone", dwarves, mining, bug shooting, dancing and beer. Make it comical and use "rock and stone" as many times as you can.
Here is the AI review:

"Rock and stone my fellow gamers! Have I got a game for you! Imagine a world where you can live out all your dwarf fantasies (and no, I'm not talking about those tiny garden gnomes). I'm talking about a world where you can mine for hours, shoot bugs, dance like there's no tomorrow, and drink beer until you can't tell the difference between a rock and a stone.

In "Rock and Stone: The Ultimate Dwarf Adventure," you play as a stout and sturdy dwarf on a mission to collect as much precious minerals as possible. But don't let the simplicity of the premise fool you, this game is anything but dull. From the moment you start, you'll be chanting "rock and stone!" along with your fellow dwarves as you embark on your epic journey.

The graphics in this game are as solid as a rock (pun intended). Every mountain, every cave, and every bug you encounter is beautifully designed, making you feel like you're actually in the game. And speaking of bugs, get ready to shoot them with your trusty pickaxe. Nothing says "rock and stone" like taking down creepy crawlies with a good old-fashioned mining tool.

But let's not forget about the real highlight of this game - the dancing. Yes, you read that right. These dwarves know how to bust a move and they're not afraid to show it. Whether you're taking a break from mining or celebrating a successful mission, the dancing in this game will have you laughing and grooving along. Just make sure to hold onto your beer while you boogie, we don't want any spills now.

And speaking of beer, it's practically a currency in this game. As you progress through levels and complete tasks, you'll earn beer that you can use to upgrade your gear and abilities. Because let's face it, what's a dwarf without a good supply of beer?

Overall, "Rock and Stone: The Ultimate Dwarf Adventure" is a hilarious and addictive game that will have you shouting "rock and stone!" every chance you get. So gather your fellow dwarves and get ready to mine, shoot bugs, dance, and drink your way to victory. Just remember, in this world, there's no such thing as too much "rock and stone". Cheers!"

DRG may be hands down, one of the best cooperative shooters on Steam. The game is incredibly fun, with loads of gameplay and mission variety. Every class, weapon, and piece of gear has massive flexibility, with their customizable tech trees, allowing for an insane amount of potential variety in load out and how you play. The devs are great, have offered a massive amount of support for the game, and are clearly passionate about the game they have made. Above all else, the community for this game is excellent, friendly, and incredibly welcoming. You would be hard pressed to find a better time than this.

This game gives me 'That feeling'

C'mon, you know the one... 'That feeling' back in highschool, perhaps middle school. Back when you rolled with a chronically-online clique. You met at the lunch table to discuss the night, rushed through your homework and scarfed down your dinner, then you grabbed soda and some snacks as you marched to your computer. That's where your REAL day starts...

And even when I'm playing with randoms, it feels like I've always known them. That's how strong the community is here. We have unspoken rules, compassion for rookies, a refusal to leave your coworkers behind, a favorite beer and a setup 'you just GODDA try it!'

Nothing short of a culture.

We can talk about what we like and dislike about DRG without a hint of tribalism. Some people hate certain mobs and objectives, others hate aspects of [strike]Random Number Generation[/strike]  luck during key moments, while I just say "Thank Karl, I was getting bored!" instead of "You hear that? Sounds like a skill issue..."

This is it, everyone. This is the game we've been waiting for. 'That Game.'

DRG is still one of the best games I have ever played in my entire life. 

If you're reading reviews, you've probably heard about DRG before. In my opinion, here's what you need to know.

There is no P2W or predatory micro-transactions, never has been, and never will be. You buy the game and you have everything needed to enjoy it to the fullest, no DLC content expansions or locked content. Each season has a battlepass with no premium or real-money version to get more loot or accelerate your progress, it isn't even an option. Once the season ends, all rewards from it are put into the game's overall loot pool, so you can still obtain anything you missed. The only exception to this are some (always free) holiday cosmetics which can only be obtained during the game's seasonal celebration events, but I do not fault the game for this. Otherwise, everything is 100% obtainable and paying isn't an option. All DLC listings in the store are cosmetic-only if you want to support the developers and look super cool. Overall, the monetization of this game is 100% consumer-focused which is incredibly rare these days. 

The class design and balance were built from the ground up to facilitate teamwork and camaraderie. In my 700+ hours, the vast majority of these were spent joining lobbies with random people I don't know. Of those literally hundreds of lobbies, I have encountered 3 rude/unpleasant people. Others may not be as lucky as me, but my point is that this game's community is famous for how wholesome and welcoming it is, and this is due to the incredible design efforts of its developers. 

The scout has a grappling hook to reach ore on walls and ceilings. The engineer has a platform gun to give scout and the team more ground to stand on. The gunner has ziplines for faster traversal and a bubble shield for protection. The driller drills real good and sculpts terrain which is essential when you're mining in a cave. The game has an intuitive and simple ping system, so it is very easy to communicate without voice chat or text chat. There is a dedicated action, set by default as the V key, where your dwarf raises their pickaxe and yells some form of "ROCK AND STONE!" in an arbitrary celebration that still makes me chuckle. If your squad does something cool, ROCK AND STONE! If someone falls off a ledge and dies, ROCK AND STONE! before reviving them. If someone clutches a swarm and then revives the whole squad, ROCK AND STONE! If a teammate blows another teammate up by accident, ROCK AND STONE! You cheer for the stupidest stuff constantly, it's amazing, and it never gets old. 

It is very hard to ever be toxic when playing DRG. With the aforementioned ping system, (just hold ctrl and click on something), there are also funny voicelines when you ping a fellow dwarf. "Engi, do you sleep with your sentries?" (Engi has turrets) "Did you borrow my underwear?" "Gunner, are you compensating for something?" (Gunner's guns are huge). The classic and brief, "You're cute!" and the list goes on and on. 

Each mission type has voicelines unique to its objectives that gives the game so much personality and makes everything lighthearted. When you're in the hub space rig selecting a mission, you can dance to a juke box and drink beer while you wait for people to finish their builds. Beers have goofy effects that may or may not persist into the mission itself, and there's always a featured beer that does bring a buff into the mission. 

The gameplay loop and progression is good. Each class currently has 3 primary weapons and 3 secondaries, which each have their own traits you can select based on your preference and playstyle. Each weapon also has several overclocks which can completely change its behavior and open up a new playstyle that wasn't possible without it. Guns and traits within a class or across classes can have interactions leading to synergies that are fun but never required. If scout uses his grenade that shocks enemies, engineer can select weapon traits that deal more damage to shocked enemies. If engineer chooses to bring 2 turrets instead of 1, with the right overclocks he can shoot them with his SMG and arc lightning between them, or trigger an electricity explosion. If you enjoy the core gameplay, the build variety and progression will only deepen your experience. 

Overall, this game is a rock and stone/10. If you think you might like it, buy it and try it.

Ah, Gruffnir, me good buddy! So, ye've decided to try yer hand at the Deep Rock Galactic life on Hoxxes IV, eh? Well, let me tell ye, it's a wild ride, that it is.

Picture this, lad. You, me, and a bunch of other dwarves, armed to the teeth, descending into the very belly of Hoxxes IV. The camaraderie, it's like nothin' else, forged in the fires of the caverns. "Leave no dwarf behind" is more than just words; it's a way of life down there.

The mining, aye, it's hard work, but the hauls are shinier than the gems we dig out. The aliens, though, they're nastier than a gang of soused orcs. Every swing of the pickaxe is a dance with danger, and "Rock and Stone" becomes a battle cry, echoing through the tunnels to keep our spirits high.

Now, when the work's done, we gather on the Space Rig. It's a giant metal beast hurtling through the stars. We hoist our mugs, shout "Rock and Stone" again, and let the stories flow like a river of ale. It's a celebration, aye, but there's always that shadow, that weight on the heart.

"Leave no dwarf behind," it's the creed, but the reality is harsh. Not every dwarf makes it back to the Rig. There's joy for the haul, but also a direct hit on the heart. I've seen mates get devoured by Glyphids, Gruffnir, right in front of me. It's a nightmare etched into the very core of your soul. The darkness takes its toll, Gruffnir, a constant battle between the riches and the cost.

So, me lad, as ye embark on this journey, remember, the Space Rig parties are grand, the riches are sweet, but the darkness takes its toll. Rock and Stone, Gruffnir, Rock and Stone.

I'm sorry but I am just outright going to say it.

The game is BORING.

The initial gameplay is pretty fun. Leveling up, getting new weapons, getting to know the enemies and procedurally generated maps. It is all pretty fun. But after that as with every horde-shooter there is not much to do after you hit the level cap. Yes there are deep dives, but they are just harder and more meta-focused levels with pretty much same enemies and objectives, so you know what to expect.
This game suffers from lack of diversification, even though maps are random their layouts are similar. Enemies are also theoretically random but they just have different names and do slightly different type of damage.
That being said I would not recommend the game for its price. In the limited genre of horde shooters 25 euros is not a bad price, but the amount of very limited (not short) quality of content is too weak compared to other games that offer the same for less. Warframe is free and although it is scammy-grinding it offers so much more in terms of different levels, types of enemies + has a story. Vermintide 2 is pretty much same price but graphically and gameplay-wise much better than Deep Rock.
Each to their own, I just wish people would stop having a stick up their asses. Yeah, AAA companies are bad, we get it. Does not mean all indie games are way better,

After playing this game nearly every single day for the past 3 weeks, I'm ready to give a review from the eyes of a (still relatively greenbearded) Rock and Stoner

Positives I have experienced:
-Incredible art style and game atmosphere
-Fantastic movement feel
-Every class feels important and down right mandatory for higher hazard levels
-The community feels like a breath of fresh welcoming air compared to other co-op PvE games I have played in the past
-Customization is out of this world and literally everyone, given enough hours in gameplay time, will look totally different
-BOSCO!!!!!!!!!
-MOLLEY!!!!!11!!!!!!!1111!!!!!!
-Weapon design and feel is better than 80% of shooter games I've played in the last 5 years
-Sound design is TIGHT as HELL
-Getting plastered with THE BOYSSSSSSS
-Fat Boy :))))))
-Neigh-infinite replay ability
-And the Soundtrack is phenomenal

(The few) Negatives I have experienced:
-RNG turning me ass-down and just having weird spawns for objectives or infuriating modifiers
-Not being able to abandon assignments sometimes
-Dreadnoughts feel dated and more annoying to fight rather than difficult
-AI pathing being super jank and sometimes getting me killed
-Lithophage.
-Dash being a perk and not a mechanic (just a lil pet peeve preference and my Scoutbrain wanting more general schmovement in the game)

Overall 8.75/10, definitely worth playing for well over 100+ hours, maybe into the quad-digit zone if my hyperfixation tends to stick like the glue it is

^ That was 146 hours. I now have almost 700 and I'd like to touch on a few points from the perspective of a true Greybeard, here since the beginning (or super close I don't actually remember).

What Greybeards LOVE
1. When you press V
2. When you use brain.exe
3. Pissing off Management
4. When team stays close together and no one wanders off.
5. Being recognized for playing game way too much (We Greybeards are very proud of our stars)
6. Buying beers for team (We are literally millionaires, let us buy you nice things bro, don't be weird.)
7. Annoying management by pinging gold or Bittergem chunks
8. Showing off our totally un-called for ability to absolutely SHIT on hoards of bugs for Greenbeards
9. Flexing our frigging SICK overclocked gear
10. Stunting on Greenbeards with our overwhelming and totally overdressed dwarves clad in the shiniest gear known to all 9 realms.
11. When Drillers actually drill for team to get from A to C (Skipping B).
12. When Gunners use their shields and tank for team (Your a Gunner, don't be a wimp)
13. When Scouts use their flare guns and actually mine the ores high up and grab the things the rest of us can't or would struggle to obtain.
14. When engineers throw platforms under ores, secondaries etc for scouts

What Greybeards HATE
1. When you don't press V
2. When you don't respond to constructive or informational chat
3. Drillers who C4 engineer platform fortresses (I will nuke you into oblivion including anyone who tries to rez you until you apologize to me, Karl, and Molly. We do not care.)
4. Greenbeards who run off all alone (like Karl) and get downed 347 meters away bc they can't kill bugs on low haz missions (or high haz tbh).
5. Greenbeard Engineers who DON'T throw platforms for scouts
6. Greenbeard Gunners who DON'T use their damn shield when it is warranted, or at all. 
7. Greenbeard Scouts who don't use their frigging flare guns or mine/grab the ores, objects etc.
8. Greenbeard Drillers (General blanket statement. Driller has like the highest skill cap in game if you know what you are doing. If you don't you just suck and your playing the dumbest dwarf so your gonna get bullied, *spits*.)
9. Greenbeards who call the drop pod before we complete an event (Omen or Kursite or Tritilyte etc etc)
10. Greenbeards who DON'T drink the beers we Greybeards buy for you (You suck)
11. Greenbeards who do the things we Greybeards hate joining any deep dive or elite deep dive (Go back to haz 2 you gutless mud miner).

In Summary, I have sunk far too many hours into mining Hoxxes V. I have platinum and gold for all dwarves, my lowest being Scout @ Gold 2. So yeah, don't be shit, and if nothing else press V to keep from being harassed by disgruntled Greybeards. If you are a Greybeard who does not press V (Yes they exist) F**K YOU!

If there is one game I can honestly say I love for nearly everything it's got. It has to be Deep Rock Galactic. GET THIS GAME, AND YOU WON'T REGRET IT.

The artstyle is fun. The jokes and voicelines are gold. And when those crazy bug waves hit the blood starts pumping. Nothing beats a final stand with 3 downed teammates on HAZ 5. There is unlimited replayability. The caves don't get stale, because they are never the same. Every cave is a surprise, and that makes the game even better. 

You can play alone, with randoms and meet some new friends. Or play with friends you already have. The community is mostly very friendly to new people. Just don't join the Haz 4 & 5 missions when you first try the game out! Start at lower levels and work your way up as you gain experience with the mechanics of the game. Trust me, Haz 5 when you start off is not a good idea.

The guns are also very fun. The variety is good. And some guns are really creative. Sure, some of the weapons probably violate the Geneva convention. But that does not count here. We are slaughtering bugs here. Who likes them?

This game is just really enjoyable. If you want a game you can return to a few times a year to grind out and commit Genocide for the good of a faceless megacorp. This is the game for you!

So, at first I thought a simple "Rock and Stone" would suffice for this game, but it doesn't. Chill mining game with such insane waves if you aren't prepared for it. The grind to your first prestige is slow, but once the ball gets rolling the game opens up and becomes a lot more enjoyable. Stick with it miners, and get that sweet sweet promotion.

Legitimately the most supportive, positive multiplayer environment I've ever seen in a game. I attribute this mostly to the fact that the game design makes every member of the team supportive to their allies, even if they're played selfishly or poorly. Every character is a support class on some level - from the Driller who digs tunnels that the whole team can use, to the Engineer who creates turrets and platforms, to the Gunner who can place ziplines across the map. Even the Scout can illuminate areas for their entire team and save other team members a lot of trouble by grabbing faraway resources.

Buy this game and play it with your friends. Maybe even go LFG. I've never regretted it. 10/10

Very fun horde shooter & exploration experience. The little details & undeniable character of this game make it instantly endearing. Easy to pick up, yet surprisingly mechanically deep & demanding, especially at higher hazard levels. I'm not usually one for online play, but the multiplayer experience makes it very easy to drop in and out quickly or form a consistent group, whichever you prefer, across a largely positive, helpful, considerate community. Looking forward to playing for many hours to come.

Edit: 700 hours later and all this still rings true. Game is fresh and exhilarating as ever (minus lithophage which can go kick rocks), and the years of dev support can not go unnoted. No other co-op experience quite like it, can confidently recommend it to all.

A non-exhaustive list of everything wrong with this game, I'll be adding more as they come to mind:

* Mods that are not supposed to be game-changing are being allowed while a simple mod like a slightly-improved flashlight is considered game-changing and gets blacklisted, which limits the lobbies you can play in
* The flashlight in the game sucks and the dark nature of the game can cause your eyes to irritate if you're not used to it. When one of the most common suggestions is to increase the gamma of your game, take the hint that the default flashlight sucks.
* No chat sound notification so people aren't aware when others are trying to communicate with them
* Friendly-Fire is enabled and it creates more in-fighting than it actually affects gameplay
* The mineral deposit (Molly/Mule) has no queue system. This means means you can be stuck waiting for a long time before it arrives to you even though you called for it first, which can get you killed if you're in a bad spot, and it can create in-fighting when players are trying to call for the Mule at the same time
* The game's replay value is largely based on grinding
* The game is very grindy by nature; items and upgrades are locked behind RnG or timegated with no way to purchase them outright
* The game's highest difficulty is generally a joke
* No option to leave immediately after game is over; most people leave after the game is over, but you have to wait until the end-of-game review to wrap up before you can actually leave the lobby.

Erst ein begrüßendes "Rock and Stone" und ein Bier an der Abyss Bar mit dem Team, dann in die Kapsel und ab zur Mission auf Hoxxes IV auf.
Dort wartet ein Mission von 8 Missionstypen auf einer prozedural generierten Karte in einem der 10 Biome von Hoxxes IV auf uns Außerdem erwarten uns (je nach einem der 5 Schwierigkeitsgrade) einige bis Horden von ausgehungerten, blutrünstigen Hoxxes IV Einwohnern auf uns.
Jedes der 4 Team Mitglieder bringt einzigartige Fähigkeiten mit sich, um die Mission zu einem erfolgreichen Abschluss zu führen und letztendlich das nächste Bier an der Abyss Bar auf der Raumstation zu genießen.
Neben der eigentlichen Mission gibt es dann noch eine zufällige optionale Zusatzmission von 8 Zusatzmissionstypen, wobei sich 7 von diesen auf Sammeln von Materialien beschränken.
Für noch mehr Varianz ist dadurch gesorgt, dass Missionen mehrere Mutatoren enthalten können von 13 negativen und 8 positiven Mutatoren. Diese können einen großen Einfluss auf das Gameplay haben und für zusätzliche Schwierigkeit sorgen.
Es gibt dann mitunter schonmal Missionen, bei denen man auf dem höchsten Schwierigkeitsgrad nicht mehr als 3 min überlebt, auch nach mehrmaligen Versuchen. (bei jedem Versuch ist die Karte neu generiert).
Die 4 Zwergenklassen sammeln permanent XP an und können auf einen höheren Rang leveln. Durch die XP können Waffenupgrades freigeschaltet und mit den im Spiel gesammelten Resourcen bezahlt werden, sowie Perks. Es können auch neue Waffen freigespielt werden.
Nach der ersten Beförderung werden dann auch die Deep Dives freigeschaltet, bei denen man mit dem gleichen Team hintereinander 3 Misssionen spielt (soweit man kommt). Für diese erhält man dann auch besondere Belohnungen in Form von starken Waffenmodifikationen und kosmetischen Items.
Das Spiel wird momentan aktiv weiterentwickelt in Form von Seasons mit neuem Content.

Fazit: Den Entwicklern scheint ihr Spiel sehr am Herzen zu liegen. Es macht Spaß, als eingeschworene Gemeinschaft mit seinen Zwergenbrüdern in die Schlacht auf Hoxxes IV zu ziehen. Rock and Stone!

Deep Rock Galactic is a fantastic game and I would recommend it to most people. 
The gameplay is quite good and while it is better to play with friends, there is a solo option where you are given a semi autonomous drone to help you through missions. Each of the four classes has a selection of different weapons to unlock and multiple modifications to each weapon which leads to a high variety of gameplay. There are also various mission types and secret challenges within the missions to keep players on their toes.
The character customization in this game is okay. Most cosmetics take quite a bit of playtime to unlock and what you are given to purchase at level 1 can leave a lot to be desired. On top of character customization, there is also pickaxe customization and you are allowed to change the skin and color palette on each of  your weapons.
