In light of seeing Ghost Ship getting robbed of the 2023 Labor of Love award for Deep Rock Galactic, losing it to Red Dead Redemption 2, a game that Rockstar stopped updating over a year ago due to not reaching profit targets, i find myself compelled to write a review. 

Deep Rock Galactic is a PvE shooter that pits you and up to 3 other dwarven brothers up against an endless horde of entomological horrors, whether they crawl, burrow or fly, in 8 different mission variants. 4 classes, each with their own strengths and weaknesses in what they can do both combat and movement wise, be it the lightbringing grapple hook shooting scout, the zipline flinging lead slinging gunner, the platform launching sentry dropping engineer, or the driller who also has bricks of plastic explosive to go with his big drill hands.

Progression is dependent on 3 things: your credits, your precious minerals management lets you keep, and your diligence in completing your assignments. Doing mission will give you credits and precious minerals, assignments will allow you to unlock new weapons, their respective upgrades and customization options for your dwarf by completeing a string of missions. Run enough missions and eventually you'll be up for a promotion, in which you cough up some minerals and minerals and you are sent back to level one with not only a shiny star, but a key to the late game content that you can't interact with until you have it and access to the weekly Deep Dives; three missions wearing a trenchcoat that reward you with upgrade cores that you can use credits and minerals to craft and even further upgrade (usually) your weapons to do even more neat stuff.

Your Possible Doubts:
"Buuuuut Womp I don't have 1-3 friends to play this with and i hate queuing with randoms!!!"
In most games like this I would sympathize with your plight, but not here. You are never alone on the Space Rig, you have BOSCO. Thats right, instead of playing with random dwarves or even the other three classes propped up by braindead AI and half function navmeshes you get a little flying robot buddy who will accompany you on your solo endeavors. Not only can he mine or that you can't reach and provide you with some targeted light, but he can also revive you, shoot missiles at targets of your choosing, and carry heavy objective objects or mineral deposits. Your loyal companion will even dig them out of the wall if you tell him to.

"Buuuuut Womp I bet this game has a battlepass and exploits FOMO and has an in-game currency to leech money out of my wallet like every other game that has come out in the past decade!!!"

No in-game currency, no FOMO that i can be bothered with, and a free battlepass that goes with the seasonal event. If you want to support the devs beyond your initial purchase there are bundles of cosmetics that you can pay for.

"Buuuuuuut Womp that progression system sounds like it will bore me and I'll stop playing it!!!"

Yeah maybe, but Hoxxes ain't going anywhere, it hasn't over the years i have been playing and i don't foresee it going anywhere either. I have put the game down a few times before and won't lie and say that I won't in the future. That's the beauty of it, DRG is always there. The Space Rig is always waiting for you to come off your sabbatical and get back to work. As long as you enjoy the game, there is no shame in putting it down and coming back at a later date. 

In all seriousness, buy the game on sale or not. It is one of the most fun PvE horde shooters to play even solo where most games of this style falter massively like Payday or the Fatshark Warhammer games. Hopefully the spite fueled tirade about a game that should have won Labor of Love 2023 will convince you, the reader wanting a reason to buy the game, to do just that. Buy the game, rock and stone to the bone.

DRG very quickly became one of my favourite games after only a few hours of playing, and I've since happily wasted many many more.

It is best experienced with friends, up to 3 others, or many more if you choose to dabble in mods, although it is not hard to find games with randoms, and everyone, in my experience, is super chill and friendly.
If you can't, or don't want to play with randoms, single player, while not as rewarding, is still very fun.
Even the lobby (known as the Space Rig) is fun to spend time in, with many things scattered around, such as the arcade games, the dance floor and bar, the no-gravity switch, and let's not forget all the barrels. You know you love to kick the barrels.

DRG features 4 main classes, each with a uniwue play style. They are extremely well balanced with respects to one another, and although it may not be as fun as a team of all Scouts, generally speaking most missions will work best with all classes represented in your team. The mechanics of the game are easy to master, and the ability to ramp up or down the difficulty of each mission ensures you'll never get bored. Weapon combustibility, as well as many extra 'overclocks' to boost certain stats of each weapon, mean there is a million different ways to play each class.

This game has  had a lot of love and care put into it by the devs to. It's obvious when looking at the Space Rig, as there are so many tiny details, easter eggs, and hidden interact-ables everywhere. Missions are no different, with tons of different types of enemies, biomes, events, mission types, available weapons and weapon mods, and the fact that every cave is unique, meaning you will never play the same mission twice.

Really the only reason I'd recommend against getting this game, is if you have a fear of spiders, or bugs, as most enemies resemble these, albeit very stylised.

So pull up a seat at the Abyss Bar, grab a Blackout Stout, and don't forget to Rock and Stone!

The best, most approachable, and most fun, addicting coop horde shooter I've ever played.
Probably the friendliest community I've ever experienced in any game, Big range of difficulty from a friendly stroll through the caves to hell on Hoxxes IV.
If you're worried people might kick you (never happened to me, as long as you're not explicitly griefing people are rather accepting of mistakes), there is always an option to open your own lobby, type in a funny game server name and eventually someone will join you.

Oh, did I mention mod support? Yeah this game has mods raging from QoL, joke mods, model and sfx replacement, and even content mods.

I seriously cannot recommend this game enough, please give it a try. I recommend buying it on sale without any dlcs, as they are cosmetic only, Maybe buy them later, all but the 2 newest dlc go on sale for pretty cheap

This is the kind of teamplay game that rewards drop in, drop out gameplay comfortably. With four distinct roles, there won't be overlap in what you can do compared to the others in the party unless you actively try to overstack - and even then, each dwarf has three unique primary and secondary weapons with their own playstyles, each of which can be further modified with unlockable and craftable Overlocks that are Clean, Balanced, or Unstable and either are flat buffs, trade offers, or entire playstyle changes respectively for that weapon. No two engineers will feel the same by luck alone, nor driller, scout, or gunner. 

That said, hosts have the ability to role lock and require one of each, further distancing players from one another and assuring that a full party has all four support equipment that each class would carry, and no dwarf is truly alone even in the depths of a solo excursion with BOSCO, a helpful drone that can perform nearly all tasks a dwarf can but can [i]fly[/i] to make up for it! BOSCO's revive reserves are limited unlike players', but the little fella can be upgraded like any equipment Management has sent down. While the drone can't supply barriers, ziplines, and the likes, it can fly to your waypoint and mine, light up the area on command, and fire missiles on cooldown at designated targets as well as supplement your own firepower with light machinegun fire and take the load off a mission that you can't or won't find help for.

Deep Rock Galactic is probably the most fun I've had on a consistent basis playing a four-person horde-based shooter. The game is just *fun*, the dwarves are interesting despite being fairly static, and it's not hyper-serious. The learning curve is not too steep and the player base is generally very friendly - if you see someone doing something weird, just join them in it. Someone spamming their ping tool on something? Keeping up the traditions!

Deep Rock doesn't lack in variety - weapons and builds for each of the 4 dwarves, with 3 primary weapons, 3 secondary weapons, 4 grenades, and plenty of customization options makes for a multitude of flexible loadouts you can bring to any of the 8 mission types in the 10 biomes (tilesets) available. There is a rotating maplist to play through each cave generation, plus Deep Dives to expand the challenge later on.

The game is non-exploitative in its DLC/microtransactions, providing a small set of cosmetics that cost a specific and defined amount of money, as compared to other companies playing games to obfuscate how much you're actually spending. It's a breath of fresh air in the heavy haze of today's gaming environment, and I sincerely appreciate it.

I know I can always come play DRG if I feel like it, and they don't pressure me to play every waking moment via excessive missions or exclusive "get it now or it's gone" battlepasses. The devs are expanding their franchise, so while updates have slowed, the game has still been receiving new enemies, weapons, or other content as time goes on. I look forward to returning to Deep Rock every time I've put it down. It's still my favorite game in the genre, and one of my go-to answers when people ask for my favorite games or recommendations.

рок и камень

Deep Rock sounded too repetitive before I played it. Just a looter? Same thing over and over? The world generation, different types of environments, different Dwarf classes and weapons and upgrades, objectives, and enemies all come together dynamically for repeatable fun.

Drop-in and out co-op works great! I rarely leave an incomplete mission, but when I do, I know the difficulty will scale and it won't be too long before someone else drops in to replace me. Along those same lines, if I open a public game, I know it will only be a few minutes until someone joins or I even have a full party.

I don't know how they do it, but I pretty much never experience griefers in Deep Rock.

It's hard to review DRG because it's a lovely game that has improved significantly since Early Access, yet it left me with a bittersweet feeling. I still recommend this game but there is a huge catch.
While I find this game very enjoyable, especially when played with friends, I can't help but feel it's a missed opportunity to become the game of the century. 

It offers a decent amount of content that can keep you engaged for hours, but it falls short in terms of weapon variety and enemy diversity. The talent tree, identical for every class, is tediously monotonous, possibly the worst I've ever encountered. It quickly becomes repetitive and grindy without providing enough satisfaction.

Each upgrade simply means more damage, more ammo, or more of something without introducing interesting combos or special abilities. Resources are predominantly spent on superficial aesthetic features. Increasing mission difficulty only adds challenge without providing sufficient incentives to keep playing.

Even the classes feel artificial. They're essentially the same hero with different loadouts, having a hook instead of an excavator doesn't make a class. They lack unique abilities or distinguishing characteristics. Once the initial fun wanes, the game reveals its emptiness, repetitive nature.

This game could be an absolute masterpiece if it adopted a weapon system akin to Borderlands/Diablo, incorporated enemies with diverse abilities and random traits, and introduced more mission types and mechanics. As it stands, it's a solid game for $10/15, enjoyable for a laugh with friends, but not much beyond that. 

Considering the plethora of trash games out there with overwhelmingly positive scores, this one at least has some valid reasons to earn its rating. However, the reviews are still overinflated, for sure. So, expect a decent 7/7.5 out of 10 game, not a masterpiece

I was skeptical of this game at first after watching a lot of videos on YouTube. However, I still decided to try the game out on sale, and wow, not only was I surprised, I was blown away. 
The game has a LOT of content from different regions, objectives, enemies, classes, and cosmetics, there's seemingly hundreds of hours worth of content packed into this game. The combat in the game is enjoyable and although it might get a bit repetitive, the randomly generated maps can help spice things up a bit.
Whats even better is that the battlepass and cosmetics are not locked behind a paywall. Unlike almost every other modern game, the developers of Deep Rock Galactic give away the battlepass for free and let you earn almost every cosmetic. This game definitely deserves the "Labor of Love" award.

Almost gave up the first time I played this game. Couldn't find the objectives (Morkite), hated having to wait for flares constantly to reload, and constantly got lost. Gave the game a break for a week, then decided to give it one more shot. Best. Decision. Ever.

This game is so much more fun socially. Friends and randoms are all so much fun to play with, and each class fills unique enough roles that every class feels impact-full without any one overshadowing the other. The mission types are all varied enough to make every next objective feel interesting and rewarding. The weapon and character customization options are varied, especially once you unlock overclocks. I've had so much fun that I almost missed out on and never tried, I can't recommend this game enough.

It's rare to find a game that is so full of personality that you actually don't realize that there's no linear campaign of any sort. It's full of humor, style, and sheer content. The upgrades, guns, and perks are reminiscent of Borderlands, which is a very good thing. The hub world features a bar with sensational brews that the player unlocks as the game goes on. It seems like everybody and their grandma has been playing this game for years, and after recently caving in and trying it out, I can see why. The core gameplay loop is satisfying and addictive, the characters are all zany and charismatic, and don't even get me started on the community.

This feels like the kind of game you can pick up and play for 20 minutes to an hour and then put it back down, but often times you simply don't want to.

The best part for me, though, is the lack of FOMO. I missed so many amazing events since I haven't played until now, but the content that was added from those events is still available for everyone. So even though I wasn't around to participate, I can still enjoy all of the excellent content from those events.

10/10 without a doubt. Easiest rating of my life.

DRG is the first multiplayer game I've played in over 10 years. The game is well designed to encourage cooperation; it's amazing how much you can communicate just by using laser pointers! The mix of classes are fun to play; the customisation on offer really allows you to tailor your look and build to your own personal style. 

The community is great; new players are customarily greeted with a "ROCK AND STONE!" Veteran Greybeards will often drop into new players' missions to help out. It's typical for you and your fellow dwarves to all cheer at the end of a mission, you might even hit the bar afterwards to grab some virtual beers! 

The procedural generation and variety of missions keep the gameplay loop feeling fresh. You can scale the difficulty of missions to your ability; which is great when you're a fresh Greenbeard, new to the game, or when you're playing solo, or crank it up if you're looking for a real challenge. The assignments, levelling system and seasonal events keep you invested, it's not plagued with microtransactions and paid lootboxes; you can really feel the love the DRG devs have for their game.

I'm just over 20 hours in (at time of writing) and I think I'll be playing for a *lot* more. ROCK AND STONE!

Started playing this game on the [b] 31 of July 2023 [/b] and haven't been disappointed by it even once.

With a nice 300.0 hours on DRG so far I can definitely say that this game is absolutely worth both your time and money.

One of the biggest surprises for me personally was that pretty much every bit of customization is available for free, that goes for guns skins, colors (both for the guns and for the armor) and different outfits for your dwarfs. You won't get everything for the start, of course there is grinding and rng involved, but you don't [b] need [/b] to buy battle passes or skin bundles at all.((unless you want to support the devs))
And I believe that it's genuinely cool and very admirable to not put useless premiums and battle passes, which only give you items if you pay, into your game. Exactly because of how easy it would be to add. 

Gameplay, guns and of course [b] The Dwarfs [/b] are all also absolutely brilliant, but this review is already long enough.
The Devs deserve all the love in the world for their hard work and dedication. 
Can't wait for the future of DRG and all the other projects related to it!

- simple but really fun gameplay loop that is designed in a way that heavily discourages competition, frustration and toxicity, instead encouraging teamwork and just doing stupid shit with your friends
- four thoughtfully designed classes that work together really well and are written as very likable characters
- One of the best and friendliest communities in all of gaming
- Great support and communication from the devs with said community
- The most player-friendly monetisation system I've ever seen in an online multiplayer service game (30 bucks for the game, regularly on sale for about 10; free battlepasses for everyone every season; huge pool of cosmetics that can be unlocked by working for them instead of paying money; no fomo bs because every cosmetic that you miss in the battle pass enters this pool of unlockables and seasonal events always let you unlock every item that was in a past event; paid cosmetics don't really look better than stuff you can get for free, acting more as a way to support the devs)

Honestly it's crazy that I haven't written a review for this game yet. At the time of writing this I have 633 hours on record and I'm sure I'll keep playing into the future. 

Deep Rock Galactic has been a necessary gaming staple for me for years now. Starting DRG in the days of early access and watching it grow from it's very solid but simple base game to what it is today has been one of the most satisfying early access experiences. The now diverse and complex collection of objectives, biomes, upgrades, and gameplay elements all started from a simple core game that was always good for those that like the basic premise of hoard fighting + Minecraft style cave exploration.

The ways the team has filled out the game since then has allowed me to still find reasons to keep playing even after promoting all 4 classes and unlocking every weapon. Endgame content will take at least as much time as the pre-end game stuff. Combined with Deep Dives (special missions that are persistent and the same for all players online and are updated live) really add challenge and fun reasons to get in at least 1-2 games a week with friends. Doing so awards players with "Overclocks" changing weapon styles and adding new abilities.  

Even after unlocking all Overclocks, there are tons of cosmetics to unlock, Seasonal events and cosmetics, as well as relatively regular new content in season updates a few times a year. DRG has never been bigger or better, I recommend it for anyone that wants to find a game that plays really well on mic with friends, or even a game to find new friends. DRG has one of the best online communities I've has the honor to be a part of.

This game is really amazing with it's original and visually-induced "aliens" and with the addition to the variety of the weapons that you get to choose from. I definitely recommend buying this game on discount while it's worth it. You get to choose from 4 classes to complete your adventure throught shooting an infinite rally of mobs with a clear index of their traits and their weakness so you have an advantage. You can even use mods on weapons so you can get "elements" (pyro-element, cryo-element, etc.) and fight against mobs with advantages. I recommend playing with at least 3 teammates because the game is highly challenging alone. You can also increasse the difficulty by choosing a "Hazard Difficulty". For casual players, I recommend "Hazard Level 1" and for more experienced players "Hazard Level 3" and for the veterans "Hazard Level 5". The difficulty is based from "Hazard 1 through 5, each number following it's precedessor and by increasing the difficulty. The DLC for the weapons are a bargain, they are incredibly useful in some challenges and make your experience much easiser with the right element-type advantage.

Frequent disconnects from the server, making it impossible to complete about 75% of the missions. The problem has been known for years and has been traced back to the Stem Datagram Relay (SDR), but no one can fix it. 
Factors that make it painful for a small fraction of people, while others never see it, are not known.
So if you are in that part of humanity that has constant disconnects, refund this game until you can.

This game has the best community ever. Alright, maybe occasionally, you'll encounter an angry nerd who's been retrying the same deep dive over and over again, but that rarely ever happens. 

How does this game have such a great community? There is a video on YouTube that already explains all of it, but in short: It's the way the game works. It discourages toxicity and encourages team work. You get nothing for fighting with your teammates, and complete the missions faster when you work as a team. But why would that be important? Well, the longer the mission lasts, the more enemies will come for you with every wave. 

If you're a new player and you join a game with OGs, they won't see you as a waste of space that could be used up by another, more skilled player, But instead, they are eager to help you out with the game. All you have to do is ask in chat.

Also, you can buy and consume booze in this game.

One of the very few games where the community is entirely friendly and helpful. Even randoms are surprisingly attentive, knowledgeable, and competent considering my prior experiences with other FPS games where randoms are practically a toss-up between toxic flamer, drunk troll, and *[mute]*. 

Short story - I once got downed on my way to the escape pod during a mission with 3 randoms (I was clueless and wandering). Despite all 3 of them already being at the escape pod well before me, and neither them nor me having anything to lose (I would still have gotten all rewards even if they left me to die), literally all 3 of them left to locate, revive, and escort me back. This was in spite of the massive horde of enemies that autospawn along the escape route once the escape pod is ready. There was no material benefit in it for them, but they did it anyway for a random noob. Why? Because Leave No Dwarf Behind. Plus, you don't treat a new player like that.

I have not encountered a single flamer yet, and I hear from veterans that even they are surprised to encounter the (very) rare toxic player after thousands of hours played, which is a testament to the quality of community this game fosters.

The dev team is no less worthy of praise - no microtransactions, no paywalled content, no keys + crates, no artificially lengthened grind just so they can sell you XP boosters and shortcuts. Everything is free, forever. Even the seasonal pass is free and if you didn't manage to unlock all the rewards this season, no problem! Get them next season for a paltry amount of in-game currency. The only things you pay real world $ for is the base game and a handful of optional cosmetic DLCs to show your support to the devs.

I heard tons of high praise for this game, and while it lived up to the hype for the first few hours, by mission 4 or 5 I couldn’t help but think: That’s it?

Don’t get me wrong. The gameplay is fun and addictive, and the sound design especially satisfying. But despite the variety of mission types and biomes, it all feels extremely samey. When I finally got the hang of perks and weapon upgrades, I realized that this is all I can look forward to. Thousands of tiny, barely noticeable upgrades. That, and the same lines of dwarf banter, over and over.

And somehow, despite being a coop shooter, I felt very little incentive to stick with the team. In my time with the game, people generally went wherever the heck they pleased, and as long as you have a decent grasp of the movement abilities, there was almost no punishment for doing the same. Compare that to L4D2, where separation from the group for longer than 60s or so gets you incapacitated, which forces that stick-together camaraderie that I look for in coop shooters.

Speaking of L4D2, somehow that game still holds my attention to this day, and it does it without currency, weapon upgrades, cosmetic upgrades, character leveling, promotions, or any of that stuff. It holds my attention because the gameplay is fun and tense all on its own.

Here’s the thing, though. This game nearly hooked me. I found myself itching to get that next upgrade, to get that next level, to finish one or two missions before bed. I stopped playing when I realized that urge came from the game’s uncanny ability to scratch that psychological itch for arbitrary progression, rather than simply because it was fun.

I honestly felt a little bad for the level 1000 dwarves, with their master chief armor and guns that fire blue lasers instead of red lasers. I was able to hang up my pickaxe and leave Deep Rock Galactic, but it’s probably way too late for them!

Just got done playing through the starting assignment with a couple friends and I can confidently say I'll be playing this game for many more hours. We were able to get most of the missions done on either the first or second try depending on what luck we got with some random grabber, but overall it's a really rewarding game. The mechanics, art style, and sound of the game all compound with each other to make it a really enjoyable experience. 

The one gripe I have in any capacity is that the extra risk curve in terms of difficulty feels REALLY steep. We did one of the missions where you follow the drill on the +75% and failed 3 times in a row, barely making it past the first couple stages of the final drilling. After that we switched to the +50% difficulty and breezed through it with little to no sweat. It's probably just a skill issue and partially due to still having early-game equipment, but that seemed pretty extreme.

I am a 56 yo father, probably one of the oldest people playing this game. I am a single father to my daughter, who is 13 now. My daughter got this game for Christmas in 2023 from her uncle, so we installed it on her computer and she started playing. By the end of the week she had 40 hours on this game. This was horrible for me, as it was already hard for me to find ways to spend time with my daughter, as she is always out with her friends or just watching overweight men eating large amounts of food and crying on YouTube. So i decided to make a Steam account and get this game to see if I could maybe play alongside her. I loaded into the game, picked my character and world and started playing but I was stuck on what you where supposed to do. I asked my daughter for help and she hosted a game for me to join. I loved it as it was the best time I had spent with my daughter since my wife had died. This game has ever since brought me and my daughter closer again and now we actually spend time together outside the house together as well. This game reminded me that there's fun to be had in everything, and it has brought both me and my daughter many happy memories.
